LocationInCountry: Belait district: scattered; Tutong district: Kampung Kiudang.

ProfileText.Summary: There are only a couple hundred people who still speak Belait in either Brunei or Malaysia. This language is being replaced by Malay, even in Belait District where it originated. The government of Brunei is building a museum in the Belait district to preserve this dying culture.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: His master said to him, Well done, good and faithful servant. You have been faithful over a little; I will set you over much. Enter into the joy of your master.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Belait people are losing their identity as their language and culture gives way to the dominant Malay culture.
ProfileText.HowReach: As it stands, there are no Christian resources in the Belait language. If there were gospel recordings in the dying Belait language, they could be distributed to those who speak this language.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are no followers of Christ who speak the Belait language. Pray that this will soon change.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for the Lord to visit Belait leaders through dreams, visions, and through His word.
Pray for this people group to be drawn to the person of Jesus Christ.
Pray for believers to find ways to reach these people in a way they can understand.
Pray for a disciple making movement among the Belait people.

LocationInCountry: Widespread.

ProfileText.Summary: Brunei Malay is the name used to refer to several very closely related and assimilated groups of indigenous peoples in Brunei. Although they are ethnically related to the Malay and share the Islamic religion, there are many cultural and linguistic differences that make the Brunei Malay distinct from the larger Malay populations. They write in Bahasa Malaysia but they speak in Brunei Malay, which is uniquely different in sound from spoken Malay. As the indigenous people of the land, the Brunei Malay generally enjoy special privileges and benefit from oil wealth. All Brunei Malay are classified as Muslims at birth. However, individual beliefs will often be influenced by tribal religions of their ancestors.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Father of the fatherless and protector of widows is God in his holy habitation.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Material wealth often prevents people from accepting that they are spiritually paupers, when they don't have Christ.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray that persons and households of peace will be found among the Brunei Malay who will catalyze movements to Jesus among their own people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are very few believers in this group. Pray that they may see that the Great Commission compels them to take the Good News to their neighbors.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray these prosperous people will increasingly see the poverty of anyone without Christ, and will seek true wealth.

LocationInCountry: Widespread.

ProfileText.Summary: The Kadazandusun people groups are primarily agriculturalists with rice growing supplemented by vegetable gardening and animal husbandry. Many have also found jobs in the timber industry that has boomed in the last two decades. Village life is usually communal, but those in urban areas tend to be less so. Although many hold on to certain aspects of their culture, the lifestyle of the Kadazandusun in the urban and developed areas is quite different from those in the remote rural areas.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The heavens declare the glory of God, and the sky above proclaims his handiwork.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Islamic teachers usually tell people that Christianity is inaccurate, and that their prophet Mohammed had the final word. Brunei is also a very difficult place to go as a Christ bearer.
ProfileText.HowReach: Members of this people group from Malaysia are believers. They can go to those in Brunei with the gospel.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that believers from Malaysia will have the compassion and mercy of Christ to go to the Kadazandusun people in Brunei.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for Jesus movements to bless extended families so the gospel will spread rapidly among this people group. Pray for the lives and culture of the Kadazandusun people to evidence the rule and reign of the Kingdom of God as they open to the gospel, and for the beauty of Jesus to be seen in them.

ProfileText.Summary: The Kadazan Dusun are primarily agriculturalists who grow rice and vegetables and raise animals. Many are employed in the timber industry. Village life is usually communal, but those in urban areas tend to be less so. Although many hold on to certain aspects of their culture, the lifestyle of the Kadazan Dusun in the urban and developed areas is quite different from the lifestyle in remote rural areas.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Wash me thoroughly from my iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin! For I know my transgressions, and my sin is ever before me.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Islamic teachers usually tell people that Christianity is inaccurate and that their prophet Mohammed had the final word. Brunei is also a difficult place to go as a Christ bearer.
ProfileText.HowReach: Some members of this people group from Malaysia are believers. They can go to Brunei with the gospel, leading people into the eternal light of Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that believers from Malaysia would have the compassion and mercy of Christ to go to the Kadazan Dusun people in Brunei.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for Jesus movements to bless extended families so the gospel will spread rapidly among this people group. Pray for the lives and culture of the Kadazan Dusun people to evidence the rule and reign of the Kingdom of God as they open to the gospel and for the beauty of Jesus to be seen in them.

ProfileText.Summary: The Bajau have traditionally been known as sea-nomads, involved in extensive maritime trading and dwelling in boats. However, the great majority of Bajau are now sedentary house dwellers and have adopted an agrarian way of life. In many ways the Bajau are a very individualistic people, but the shared identity of Islam creates a powerful unifying bond among them. Traditional beliefs (spiritism) interact in complex ways with Islamic beliefs (the more recent system). Most people subscribe to a variety of both traditional and more current beliefs, and it is difficult if not impossible to separate them. Various folk beliefs from former times still have some prevalence among the West Coast Bajau.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: I will instruct you and teach you in the way you should go; I will counsel you with my eye upon you.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The worldview and religion of the Bajau is tightly bound to their self-identity, making change quite unlikely for most individuals.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray that Christians of Malaysia and Indonesia may develop an interest in the Bajau people of Brunei, and will find ways to minister to their needs.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There is an indication there may be a few followers of Christ among the Bajau people. They very much need our prayers. May the Lord send someone to help them become firmly established in the faith.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Bajau people will be set free from fear of going out at night and fear of ghoulish creatures that seek to eat babies or the flesh of recently deceased people.

ProfileText.Summary: Many Hainanese people live in Cambodia's Kampot Province. One can find a large number of them in Phnom Penh. They work hard, rarely taking time off from work. They have distinguished themselves as experts in the food catering business. Many manage coffee shops, Chinese noodle houses, and other businesses in the food industry. Parents encourage their children to study hard in school. With much of their time spent in school or at work, the Hainanese have little time for entertainment or socializing.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Do not neglect to show hospitality to strangers, for thereby some have entertained angels unawares.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Fear of the spirit world and secularism are both obstacles to faith in Christ among the Hainanese people in Cambodia.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are many Hainanese believers from other parts of the world that can go to them as Christ bearers.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the Hainanese believers will be filled with the fruit and the power of the Holy Spirit so they can be effective in reaching those in Cambodia.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for a "Book of Acts" type of movement to Christ among the Hainanese people in Cambodia. Pray for a movement in which the Holy Spirit leads and empowers disciples to make more disciples. Pray for a movement of Jesus to heal and strengthen Hainanese communities and families.

LocationInCountry: Ratanakiri province: Laos border area, mainly between Sesan and Sprepok rivers; Stung Treng province: southeast corner.

ProfileText.Summary: Indigenous ethnic groups of the mountains are known collectively as "Montagnards", and the Krung are one of these. They are culturally distant from modern Khmers. Most of these groups are matrilineal, tracing ancestry through maternal rather than paternal bloodlines. The Krung are very poor, with little access to schooling, health care, and electricity. Traditionally the Krung depend heavily on the forest for their livelihood and grow upland dry rice. Cash crops like cashew nuts and cassava provide limited income. Hunting, fishing, and raising animals provide protein in their diet. Rolling forested hills of red volcanic earth cover much of the Krung homeland and several major rivers traverse flat floodplains. They are not Buddhists, but practice their traditional religion.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: and what you have heard from me in the presence of many witnesses entrust to faithful men, who will be able to teach others also.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The literacy rate of these poor people suggests the need for oral presentations of the Gospel. Bible portions are also available in their language.
ProfileText.HowReach: Located somewhat nearby is the Jarai people group, with a larger number of believers. Pray they won't keep the gospel blessing to themselves, but rather that they would share it with their Krung neighbors.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few Krung who would identify themselves as Christians. Pray they will understand what it means to follow Jesus as Savior and Lord, not mixing traditional beliefs with the purity of the Gospel.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for fair treatment for the Krung by the government of Cambodia, protecting their land from encroachment by logging companies.

LocationInCountry: Ratanakiri province: principally Andoung Meas, Bar Kaev, and Ou Ya Dav districts; northeast border near Viet Nam.
Widespread

ProfileText.Summary: The Khmer civilization once ruled much of Southeast Asia. In the 1200s, the Thais and Vietnamese defeated the Khmer and pushed them into Cambodia, where most live today. The huge Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia gives evidence of past glories. They have been primarily Buddhist since the 13th century, but elements of Hinduism and animism are mingled with Buddhist beliefs.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: For I will pour water on the thirsty land, and streams on the dry ground; I will pour my Spirit upon your offspring, and my blessing on your descendants.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Centuries of devotion to their past belief system are not quickly overcome, but there is much progress.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for discovery Bible studies to spread rapidly as they bless Khmer families and communities.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the steady growth of the church among the Khmer, that they will continue to have a heart of fire for God and a passion for the souls of their countrymen.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Khmer will heal from the tragedies brought by the Khmer Rouge, and that this past suffering will prepare them for the love and forgiveness found only in Jesus Christ.

ProfileText.Summary: When you think of the Khmer you may think of Cambodia, the country where they are in the majority. The Khmer civilization once ruled much of Southeast Asia. In the 1200s, the Thai and Vietnamese defeated the Khmer and pushed them into Cambodia, where most live today. The huge Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia gives evidence of past glories. They have been primarily Buddhist since the 13th century, but elements of Hinduism and animism are mingled with Buddhist beliefs.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And you warned them in order to turn them back to your law. Yet they acted presumptuously and did not obey your commandments, but sinned against your rules, which if a person does them, he shall live by them, and they turned a stubborn shoulder and stiffened their neck and would not obey.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Centuries of devotion to their past belief system are not quickly overcome, but there is much progress.
ProfileText.HowReach: Discovery Bible Studies can spread rapidly and bless Khmer families and communities.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the steady growth of the church among the Khmer, that they would continue to have a heart of fire for God and a passion for the souls of their countrymen.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Khmer would heal from the tragedies brought by the Khmer Rouge, and that this past suffering would prepare them for the love and forgiveness found only in Jesus Christ.

LocationInCountry: Phnom Penh; generally dispersed longstanding population; communities in urban areas, including Siemreab, Preah Sihanouk, Ta Khmau, others.

ProfileText.Summary: The Vietnamese living in Cambodia today are a people without a country. They are not citizens of Cambodia. They are not allowed to take jobs that could be filled by a Cambodian. Vietnam will not permit them to return to their original home. The Vietnamese came to Cambodia for many reasons. In 1863, when Cambodia became a French colony, many Vietnamese were brought to Cambodia by the French to work on plantations and occupy civil service positions.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And Ezra opened the book in the sight of all the people, for he was above all the people, and as he opened it all the people stood. And Ezra blessed the LORD, the great God, and all the people answered, Amen, Amen, lifting up their hands. And they bowed their heads and worshiped the LORD with their faces to the ground.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Buddhism and animism are deeply ingrained in the Vietnamese and Cambodian cultures. If a Vietnamese person becomes a believer, he or she risks being alienated by his or her family and neighbors.
ProfileText.HowReach: Christians can start and run schools that cater to Vietnamese children. Medical teams can come and help the Vietnamese whose needs are often neglected by the Cambodian government.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that Cambodian Vietnamese believers would grow strong in the faith and be able to meet the needs of their families.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray that the Vietnamese in Cambodia would be able to gain a better legal position, so they are able to gain jobs and own businesses and homes. Pray that God would multiply local churches among the Vietnamese in Cambodia this decade.

LocationInCountry: Ratanakiri province: Sesan river area south to Srepok river.

ProfileText.Summary: The Tampuan people follow an animistic religion, dominated by fear of evil spirits and various sacrifices. Some have become Christians in the last several years, although many professed faith briefly only to fall away. The gospel was first brought to the Tampuans by Khmers, but some have been evangelized by the neighboring Jarai people group. Some Tampuans are curious and receptive to the Christian gospel, and others are resistant. The people inhabit hills in the northeastern corner of Cambodia and are mostly farmers. The literacy rate in the Tampuan language has been given as 5%.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Lead me in your truth and teach me, for you are the God of my salvation; for you I wait all the day long.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Lack of prayer and lack of workers hinder the advance of the good news about Jesus in Cambodia.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Jarai people of Cambodia have substantial numbers of Christians, and they are a neighboring tribe to the Tampuan people. Please pray for Christian Jarai to be given a desire to see disciples made among the Tampuan people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the Christians among the Tampuan people to become zealous to know and follow Jesus, not wavering in their faith.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Lord will set the Tampuan people completely free from fear of evil spirits and show them the way to freedom by trusting Jesus.

LocationInCountry: Scattered, nearly half of the Cham in Cambodia live in Kampong Cham and Tbong Khmum provinces, where they are about 6% of the total population. Cham also live dispersed through all other provinces especially Kampong Chhnang and Krati provinces.

ProfileText.Summary: Long ago, the Cham had a strong empire, called Champa, located in southern Vietnam. In 1471, Champa was invaded and destroyed by the Vietnamese, and most freemen and aristocrats fled to Cambodia. In 1975, more than 250,000 Muslim Cham lived in Cambodia. With the rise of the Khmer Rouge regime, however, their population was decimated. Captured and removed from their homes, they were forbidden to speak their native language and forced to eat pork, which is an abomination to Muslims. About 100,000 Cham were said to have been executed. Cham villagers are extremely poor, and their settlements convey a sense of impermanence. They are now largely integrated into the Cambodian lifestyle and many now speak Khmer (Cambodian).
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: O God, you are my God; earnestly I seek you; my soul thirsts for you; my flesh faints for you, as in a dry and weary land where there is no water.
ProfileText.Obstacles: This Muslim community living in Buddhist Cambodia may have become especially protective of their culture and their religion.
ProfileText.HowReach: Sustained prayer is needed to prepare hearts of the Cham. Gospel recordings and the Jesus film can both be useful in communicating the good news of Jesus.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are some believers in Christ among the Cham of Cambodia. Pray the Jesus film and Gospel recordings (which are available) will be taken to these believers. Workers are needed.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for improved living conditions for the Cham, for employment opportunities, and for good schools to be available for the children.

ProfileText.Summary: Long ago, the Cham had a strong empire, called Champa, located in southern Vietnam. In 1471, Champa was invaded and destroyed by the Vietnamese and most freemen and aristocrats fled to Cambodia. In 1975, more than 250,000 Muslim Cham lived in Cambodia. With the rise of the Khmer Rouge regime, however, their population was decimated. Captured and removed from their homes, they were forbidden to speak their own language and forced to eat pork, which is an abomination to Muslims. About 100,000 Cham were said to have been executed. Cham villagers are extremely poor and their settlements convey a sense of impermanence. They are now largely integrated into the Cambodian lifestyle and many now speak Khmer.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: You have kept count of my tossings; put my tears in your bottle. Are they not in your book?
ProfileText.Obstacles: This Muslim community living in Buddhist Cambodia may have become especially protective of their religious tradition.
ProfileText.HowReach: There is a need for sustained prayer to prepare hearts of the Cham. Gospel recordings and the JESUS Film can both be useful in communicating the good news of Jesus.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are some believers in Christ among the Cham of Cambodia. Pray the JESUS Film and gospel recordings (which are available) would be taken to these believers. Workers need to rise up in courage to share the gospel with the Western Cham people of Cambodia.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for improved living conditions for the Cham, for employment opportunities and for good schools to be available for the children.

LocationInCountry: Widespread

ProfileText.Summary: There are at least 250,000 Kampuchea Krom (descendants of the original Khmer inhabitants of what is now southern South Vietnam) who have migrated from Vietnam and now live within the borders of Cambodia. Because of linguistic, political, and social factors they are distinct in many ways from the wider Khmer population in Cambodia. Theravada Buddhism is the public veneer of Kampuchea Krom religion, but animistic belief in the spirit world may have more of a hold on their daily lives. The Kampuchea Krom keep an altar outside their homes where they offer food and incense to the spirit world on a daily basis.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Shout for joy to God, all the earth; sing the glory of his name; give to him glorious praise!
ProfileText.Obstacles: These Buddhist people may not have a full understanding of the reality of sin and their need for a Savior. Altering one's world view is painful and difficult.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Bible is available, and many language-based resources are available in the language of these people. Workers are needed to take these resources to the people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the relatively few Christian believers to be accurately taught the ways of Christ; they need qualified teachers.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for this people group to have the opportunity to hear of Christ, in their mother tongue, and in a manner they will both understand and accept. Pray for several opportunities for each individual during their lifetime.

ProfileText.Summary: A significant number of Kampuchea Krom (descendants of the original Khmer inhabitants of what is now southern Vietnam) have migrated from Vietnam and now live within the borders of Cambodia. Because of linguistic, political and social factors, they are distinct in many ways from the wider Khmer population in Cambodia. Buddhism is the public veneer of Kampuchea Krom religion, but animistic belief in the spirit world may have more influence in their daily lives. The Kampuchea Krom often keep an altar outside their homes where they offer food and incense to the spirit world on a daily basis.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit; a broken and contrite heart, O God, you will not despise.
ProfileText.Obstacles: As Buddhists, the Khmer Krom may not have an understanding of the reality of sin and their need for Jesus as their Savior. Altering one's world view is painful and difficult.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Bible is available and many language-based resources are available in the Khmer language. Workers are needed to take these resources to the people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the relatively few Christian believers to be accurately taught the ways of Christ; they need qualified teachers.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for this people group to have the opportunity to hear of Christ in their mother tongue and in a manner they will both understand and accept. Pray for workers to plant and water seeds of the gospel in the Khmer Krom community.

LocationInCountry: Sumatra, east Lampung Province. 3 enclaves situated between Kanan and Seputih rivers.

ProfileText.Summary: The Lampung Abung people are known as mountain dwellers, and have a unique history as headhunters. The majority make their living as rice farmers. After they harvest the rice, the best fields are then used to plant pepper. The other important source of livelihood for the Lampung Abung is fishing. The Lampung Abung live in traditional communities known as tiuh, in which each clan has its own permanent house. Currently, every Lampung Abung is theoretically a Muslim. However, the Lampung Abung also have strong beliefs in spirits. They often call a dukun (shaman/healer/occultist) to heal the sick or cast out demons.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Come and hear, all you who fear God, and I will tell what he has done for my soul.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The island of Sumatra does not provide ready access to Christian workers.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray the Lord will start a movement of Lampung Abung families experiencing God's blessings.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are few if any followers of Jesus Christ among the Lampung Abung. Pray the Lord will be calling many of these people to a personal relationship with himself, and will build a holy church among them, zealous to honor him with their lives.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The main need of the Lampung Abung is improved farm management, especially with the goal of raising more export-quality pepper. Pray for an improving standard of living, with employment opportunities for all who need employment.

LocationInCountry: North tip of Sumatra, both coasts, Aceh Province, Aceh Besar, Aceh Jaya, Aceh Barat, Nagan Raya, Aceh Barat Daya, Aceh Selatan, Aceh Sinkil, Aceh Tamiang, Kota Langsa, Aceh Timr, Aceh Utara, Kota Lhokseumawe, Bireuen, Pidie Jaya, and Pidie regencies; Weh and neighboring islands off north tip; into Sumatera Utara Province, Tapanuli Tengah regency, south coast enclave.

ProfileText.Summary: The Aceh are a blend of many races, which explains why they are fairer skinned and taller than most other Indonesians. Most are either farmers or fishermen. Traditionally, most Aceh, both men and women, wore a sarong, a modest and colorful skirt. In recent years there has been a move towards Islamic dress and now the majority of women wear a head covering. Most men have no say in matters that deal with the home or even child rearing. The Aceh people are strict Sunni Muslims and have been very instrumental in spreading Islam throughout Indonesia and other parts of Southeast Asia.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Hear, O my people, while I admonish you! O Israel, if you would but listen to me!
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Aceh people are one of the most strongly resistant people groups in the world to the good news of Jesus.
ProfileText.HowReach: Much focused, sustained prayer is needed for the Aceh people. Spiritual things are spiritually discerned. The Lord's Spirit can work in Aceh hearts to hunger to know Jesus, the Savior.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are very few followers of Jesus among the Aceh people. They need prayer support. Pray for their physical protection, and spiritual protection. Pray they will be tactful yet forthright in their quiet testimony for Christ. Pray they will consistently know the joy of Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the fervency of the Aceh people toward Islam to be gradually redirected toward its proper object. Pray for a growing desire to know Jesus (whom Muslims call Isa al-Masih).

ProfileText.Summary: The Acehnese are a blend of many peoples, which explains why they are fairer skinned and taller than most other Indonesians. Traditionally most Acehnese, both men and women, wore a sarong - a modest and colorful skirt. In recent years there has been a move towards Islamic dress and now the majority of women wear a head covering. Most men have no say in matters that deal with the home or even child rearing. The Acehnese are strict Sunni Muslims and have been very instrumental in spreading Islam throughout Indonesia and other parts of Southeast Asia.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Beloved, do not imitate evil but imitate good. Whoever does good is from God; whoever does evil has not seen God.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Acehnese are one of the most strongly resistant people groups anywhere to the gospel.
ProfileText.HowReach: There is a need for much focused, sustained prayer for the Acehnese. The Lord's Spirit can work in Acehnese hearts to give them a hunger to know Jesus, the only Savior.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are very few followers of Jesus among the Acehnese. They need prayer support. Pray for their physical and spiritual protection. Pray they would be tactful yet forthright in their testimony for Christ. Pray they would consistently know the joy and love of Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the fervency of the Acehnese toward Islam to be redirected toward faith in the only one who is worthy of praise and worship. Pray for them to become a missionary sending base.

Resources.WebText: Download audio Bible app from Google Play Store

LocationInCountry: Maluku Province, Seram Bagian Barat regency, Kota Ambon, Hoamoa peninsula, coastal strip on Piru bay, east shore of bay from Kamarian to Seriholu; Makulu Tengah regency, Banda seacoast, Kota Ambon, Nusa Laut island, upper Elpaputih bay past Amahai, east to Sepa; Ceram sea coast from Karlutu east around Cape Namaa to Sawai on Sawai bay; Kepulauan Aru regency, northwest Aru island group, Wamar island.

LocationInCountry: Bali Province, widespread throughout entire island, including Penida; to east, Nusa Tenggara Barat Province, Kota Mataram and Lombok Barat regency, west central Lombok island.

ProfileText.Summary: The Bali people are those who live on or originated from the island of Bali. Most Balinese live in very close-knit villages with strong family, social, religious and economic interrelationships. The Balinese are known throughout the world for their artistic abilities. Hinduism is the primary religion of the Balinese. Even though Hinduism has greatly affected the culture, the Balinese have managed to maintain their original culture, so that Balinese Hinduism differs from Indian Hinduism.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The heavens proclaim his righteousness, and all the peoples see his glory.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Close-knit societies make it especially difficult for any one member to follow a different religion.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for the Lord to multiply the reception and influence of His Word among the Balinese, leading them to love Him with their whole being.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the followers of Christ among the people of Bali to grow in their love for the Lord and for each other. Pray they will have power to grasp how wide and long and high and deep is the love of Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: A great need in Bali is a government plan for tourism development. Well-conceived and well-executed laws could preserve the beauty and culture of Bali as well as promote its tourist trade for many years to come.

ProfileText.Summary: Throughout the world, people know the Balinese for their artistic abilities. They live on or originated from the island of Bali. Most Balinese live in very close-knit villages with strong family, social, religious, and economic interrelationships. Hinduism is the primary religion of the Balinese. Even though Hinduism has greatly affected the culture, the Balinese have managed to maintain their original culture, so Balinese Hinduism differs from Indian Hinduism.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But they who wait for the LORD shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings like eagles; they shall run and not be weary; they shall walk and not faint.
ProfileText.Obstacles: These close-knit societies make it particularly challenging for any member to find spiritual truths outside of what they already believe.
ProfileText.HowReach: A great need in Bali is a plan for tourism development. Well-conceived and well-executed strategies to build tourism and expand job opportunities could be an excellent gospel ministry.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that Christian Balinese would find community and fellowship together. Pray that they would find ways to share the holiness and power of Christ with family and community.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray that God would grant repentance and grace to those who need Christ and would provide them opportunities to receive him without fear.

LocationInCountry: Widespread throughout north central Indonesia, Sulawesi island; also throughout Maluku Utara Province on Bacan, Obi, Kayoa, and Sula islands, southwest of Halmahera island.

ProfileText.Summary: The Bajau (sometimes referred to as Sea Gypsies) are a highly mobile maritime people group found throughout the coastal areas of Sulawesi, Maluku, Kalimantan, Sumatra, and East Nusa Tenggara. Two to six families will group together in an alliance to regularly fish and anchor together, often sharing food, nets, and gear, and pooling labor. The Bajau are Sunni Muslim of the Shafi 'I school. Claims to religious piety and learning are an important source of individual prestige. Among boat dwelling communities in particular, community shamans (dukun) assemble at least once a year for a public sance and nightly trance dancing.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: You turn things upside down! Shall the potter be regarded as the clay, that the thing made should say of its maker, He did not make me; or the thing formed say of him who formed it, He has no understanding?
ProfileText.Obstacles: The nomadic lifestyle of these people makes it difficult to establish any kind of long term relationship with them.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for the distribution of Gospel recordings (which are available) to the Bajau people. Pray these will be valued by the people, and passed from person to person.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are few if any followers of Jesus among the Bajau, but pray for those who will soon come to Christ. Pray they will clearly understand who Jesus is, and not mix the purity of the Gospel with folk beliefs and a religion of works.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Bajau need infrastructure development and renovations in the areas of health and education. Medical workers, facilities, and services in their communities are very inadequate. Many Bajau are illiterate, partially due to their nomadic lifestyle.

Resources.WebText: Jesus Film: view in Bajau, Indonesian

LocationInCountry: Kalimantan south and southeastern coasts, Java Sea and Makassar Strait; Kalimantan Tengah Province as far as Pangkalanbun, Sampit, and Palangkaraya; Kalimantan Selatan Province, around Banjarmasin, to south then east; Kalimantan Timur Province, coastal regions of Pulau Laut, Kutai, and Pasir, north towards Samarinda city and Mahakan delta; smaller region, Kalimantan Barat Province, coastal Matua.

ProfileText.Summary: Although they are devout Muslims, the Banjar proudly trace their origins to a legendary Hindu kingdom, the Negara Dipa. In 1526, Banjar Prince Samudera accepted Islam and took the name of Sultan Suriansyah as a condition of receiving help from a Jawa army in overthrowing his uncle. The Banjar people do not look positively upon modern methods and technologies, nor do they mix much with other people groups. This isolation has limited the development of education, health care, sanitation, and water purification.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: I stretch out my hands to you; my soul thirsts for you like a parched land. Selah
ProfileText.Obstacles: To follow Christ in this strongly Muslim people group is to risk losing so much that is important to a person, including friends, family, social status, and perhaps employment.
ProfileText.HowReach: Much prayer, coupled with ways to serve these people, is needed.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray there will soon be a growing number of Christ-followers among the Bangjara, that the Lord is even now preparing hearts to have faith to believe. Pray these new believers will become firmly established, not swayed by every wind of doctrine.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Banjar community will open up to outsiders, and will benefit by an improved standard of living. Pray for improved health care, clean water and good schools.

ProfileText.Summary: Although they are devout Muslims, the Banjar proudly trace their origins to a legendary Hindu kingdom, the Negara Dipa. In 1526, Banjar Prince Samudera accepted Islam and took the name of Sultan Suriansyah as a condition of receiving help from a Javanese army in overthrowing his uncle. The Banjar people do not look positively upon modern methods and technologies, nor do they mix socially with other people groups. This isolation has limited their development in education, health care, sanitation and water purification.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Have you not known? Have you not heard? The LORD is the everlasting God, the Creator of the ends of the earth. He does not faint or grow weary; his understanding is unsearchable.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Because of their lack of urban and cross-cultural engagement, their society has not progressed with surrounding cultures. They shun most who become Christians for the rest of their lives, making it difficult to spread the name of Jesus.
ProfileText.HowReach: Missionaries could build schools to encourage education and cultural engagement.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that Christian Banjar would find community and fellowship together. Pray for Banjar believers to be disciples who make other disciples.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray that God would grant repentance and grace to those who need Christ and provide them opportunities to receive him without fear. Pray for a move of the Holy Spirit among the Banjar people, leading to many faithful disciples.

Resources.WebText: Animated  short Scripture videos in Banjar

LocationInCountry: Widespread throughout Indonesia; mainly in Jawa Tengah, Yogyakarta, Jawa Timur, and Lampung provinces; scattered enclaves on Sumatra island and resettlements in Papua, Sulawesi, Maluku, and Kalimantan.

ProfileText.Summary: The Banten people grow rice and other crops, such as coffee, cloves, jengkol, and petai. Working the land is done in cooperative groups. One type of cooperative work is royongan. In royongan, workers are not paid directly; rather, wages are collected and stored by a community elder to be used for repair of mosques and smaller prayer houses. Another form of cooperative work is called liliuran, which is helping one another work the rice fields without any expectation of payment. Cooperation of this kind is expected of community members. They are obedient Muslims, but they still have deep involvement in black magic and the occult.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Be exalted, O LORD, in your strength! We will sing and praise your power.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The worldview and religion of the Banten people can be traced back many centuries. Much prayer is needed to prepare hearts to receive and believe the good news of Jesus Christ.
ProfileText.HowReach: Christian businessmen can work to form business ventures with the people, helping provide employment and training.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray the few followers of Jesus among the Banten tribe will be united in mind and heart, faithfully fellowshipping together.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The people need better education facilities as well as joint business ventures with outside companies.

LocationInCountry: Sumatra, Kepulauan Bangka Belitung Province, widespread, Bangka island.

ProfileText.Summary: The Bangka live on the island of Bangka in the South China Sea, off the east coast of Sumatra. Inhabitants of the island are composed of two groups: those descended from the Malay and those descended from the Chinese. Both of these groups call themselves Bangka; nevertheless, differences exist between the groups including physical traits, economic status, and place of residence. Many Bangka residents choose to move to other areas for work, particularly Jakarta and Palembang. Pillars of the local economy are the rubber and palm oil plantations. The Bangka Malay are Muslims, however they are not particularly orthodox in their beliefs. Mosques are not heavily visited during the sunset ritual prayers. However, during the more important Friday prayers the mosques tend to be full. There are not many Muslim educational institutions like Quranic reading centers, Islamic religious schools, or mosque youth group activities.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Truly, truly, I say to you, whoever hears my word and believes him who sent me has eternal life. He does not come into judgment, but has passed from death to life.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Spiritual opposition can be expected whenever Jesus is presented to a people, especially to a Muslim people.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are a wealth of resources available in the Malay language, which is a secondary language for these people. Pray for workers to share these with the Bangka people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for those within the Bangka tribe who identify themselves as Christians. Pray they will understand the distinction that must be made between cultural identification with the Christian religion and a life-changing commitment to the person of Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The tin mining industry has decreased because little recoverable tin is left to mine. It is very difficult to find alternative livelihoods due to the people's lack of skills. Because of this, the greatest need at this time is to develop the skills of the Bangka community. Please pray for this important need.

LocationInCountry: Jawa Timur Province, Banyuwangi regency area, easternmost extent of Java island; facing Bali strait.

ProfileText.Summary: The Java Osing never experience water shortages because they live on the slopes of the Ijen-Merapi volcano. They take great care and highly value preserving their relationships with relatives, whether they are near or far. Good relationships with others are also maintained through mutual sharing and giving, as well as trying to understand other people's feelings and abilities. This practice is summarized as tepo seliro, which means not doing something one would not want done to oneself. The Jawa Osing are known as hospitable and well-mannered people. Islam became the dominant religion of the Jawa Osing after Hinduism was pushed from their area to Bali. The Jawa Osing believe that a dukun's magical powers can heal or destroy whoever or whatever is a cause of problems.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And there is salvation in no one else, for there is no other name under heaven given among men by which we must be saved.
ProfileText.Obstacles: No scripture is reported to be available in the Osing language.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Java Osing people need to hear of Jesus and his teaching to "do unto others as you would have them do unto you." This would be a wonderful bridge into what they already believe and practice.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few Java Osing people who identify themselves as Christians. They need to clearly understand the distinction that must be made between a cultural identification with Christianity and a dynamic and living relationship with Jesus Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray for this gentle tribe to learn more accurately who Jesus is and what he has done for them. Pray the Lord will give them understanding and faith to believe.

LocationInCountry: Sumatera Utara Province; southern interior area extending from Padang Sidempuan, across borders with Riau and Sumatera Barat provinces.

ProfileText.Summary: The Mandailing strongly identify themselves with the Islamic religion. This is a distinct departure from other Batak people groups which are predominantly Christian. The Mandailing constantly have to explain the fact that they are Muslims, since most Indonesians believe that all Batak peoples are Christian. The Mandailing people's religion in ancient times was a mixture of Hindu beliefs and a local traditional religion called Parmalin. Almost all Mandailing have been Muslims ever since Minangkabau Muslims forcibly introduced Islam. Many of their traditions have been adapted to Islam. Children and land are viewed as sources of personal pride by the Mandailing that cause one to receive status and respect.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: I will praise the LORD as long as I live; I will sing praises to my God while I have my being.
ProfileText.Obstacles: No scripture or other Christian resources are reported in the language of these people. And, they live in a strongly Muslim environment.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for prayer warriors to be raised up to pray for the Mandailing people, and pray these warriors will persist in prayer until real breakthroughs occur.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few followers of Christ among the Mandiling, that they will not succumb to pressure to renounce their faith. Pray they will fellowship together, encouraging and instructing each other.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The area is rich in natural resources such as zinc, sulfur, limestone, granite, gold, copper, tin, petroleum, and kaolin. There is tremendous potential that should be developed, but investment is needed in order for this to happen.

LocationInCountry: Java island, Jawa Barat Province, Bogar, Bekasi, and Karawang regencies including Depok and Bekasi cities; Banten Province, from Tangerang recency and city; dominant in Jakarta special capital territory.

ProfileText.Summary: The Betawi people are descendants of the people who came to what is now Jakarta in the 15th century, and they currently live in areas surrounding Jakarta. Most farm rice, grow fruit and fish. Those in Jakarta are servants to the wealthy, craftsmen, or traders, and they are often resistant to public education, preferring instead to be educated at local Islamic schools. Though they are Muslim, the tenets of their religion have been changed to fit their culture. They are: 1) greet each other with a peace blessing, 2) pray five times a day, 3) marry daughters at youngest marital age, and 4) be hospitable. They blend their Islam with belief in spirits. These people struggle to keep up with Jakartas ever-increasing urbanization and modernization.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: To whom then will you liken God, or what likeness compare with him? An idol! A craftsman casts it, and a goldsmith overlays it with gold and casts for it silver chains.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Betawi are resistant to outside ideas, and most automatically reject the gospel.
ProfileText.HowReach: Hospitals are a wonderful method to demonstrate the love and compassion of the Lord. Job training run by lovers of Christ might open doors to the gospel.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the Holy Spirit to direct the few Betawi believers to be a blessing to their Muslim neighbors and family members.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for Betawi believers to disciple others in Christs ways and that these new believers will disciple others as well.

LocationInCountry: Sulawesi island, widespread in Sulawesi Selatan Province, peninsular interior (except for area south and east of Makassar city) eastward through to head of Bone bay, contiguous coastal area; scattered communities generally on various coasts and interior enclaves in other provinces, including Sulawesi Tenggara Province, interior near Sulawesi Tenggara, Lake Towuti, along east coast of Bone bay, 3 enclaves, Kasiputih area facing Muna island; Sulawesi Tengah Province, west side, areas at Oti, Toaya, and Donggola; east side, 3 enclaves on Tolo bay; Sulawesi Barat Province, Mandar bay, 2 more enclaves (More, Pasangkayu) along Makassar strait; possible other small concentrations in Kalimantan, Maluku, Papua, and Sumatra provinces.

ProfileText.Summary: The Bugis are a dynamic and highly mobile people, considered by many to be the dominant people group in South Sulawesi. Many Bugis have left their home area to seek success and wealth. The Bugis believe very strongly that certain days are good days, with good fortune for events and activities held on the first Wednesday and last Thursday of each month. Conversely, they consider Saturday to be a bad day, with misfortune more likely to happen on this day. The Bugis people are famous for their fervent adherence to Sunni Islam. However, many still follow their traditional system of animistic beliefs.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom; all those who practice it have a good understanding. His praise endures forever!
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Bugis people have a history of strong commitment to Islam.
ProfileText.HowReach: Ask God to deliver families and communities within the Bugis people from fears that hinder them from embracing His blessings.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for those few people among the Bugis community who follow Christ. Pray they will be sent teachers and study materials to help them grow in Christ. Pray they will be faithful to fellowship together, and to spur one another on to love and good deeds.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Bugis need financial investment and modernization in public shipping and the fishing industry, because there is large potential in these sectors. Also, South Sulawesi's potential in the mining and industrial sectors is still largely untapped, due to a lack of expertise and investment.

ProfileText.Summary: Many consider the Bugis to be the dominant people group in South Sulawesi Island, though many have moved elsewhere to seek success and wealth. The Bugis believe that certain days are good days and hold events and activities on the first Wednesday and last Thursday of each month. Conversely, they consider Saturday to be a bad day, with misfortune more likely to happen. The Bugis people are known for their fervent adherence to Sunni Islam, though many still follow their traditional system of animist beliefs.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Blessed is the man who remains steadfast under trial, for when he has stood the test he will receive the crown of life, which God has promised to those who love him.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Bugis have a history of strong commitment to Islam which leaves their hearts closed to outside ideas.
ProfileText.HowReach: It might take miracles of God to show them that he is sovereign over circumstances. They need to meet Christ followers who love unconditionally.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray the few people believers among the Bugis community would be devoted to fellowship together and to spur one another on to love and good deeds.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the Lord to bless the Bugis financially as a demonstration of his power and love. Pray for a powerful movement to Christ among them this decade.

LocationInCountry: Aceh Province, Central Aceh, East Aceh, Gayo Lues, and Southeast Aceh regencies. North Sumatra highland region near Mount Sembuang.

ProfileText.Summary: The Gayo of Indonesia live in the remote central highlands of Aceh Province on the island of Sumatra, an area difficult for Christians to enter. The Gayo do not have a written language. Folk tales and oral stories are passed down in the form of poetry. The Gayo people are mostly Muslim, but their understanding and conviction are lacking. Most Gayo still believe in good and bad spirits and holy men both dead and alive.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The LORD repay you for what you have done, and a full reward be given you by the LORD, the God of Israel, under whose wings you have come to take refuge!
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Gayo live among the strongly Muslim Aceh people, making access especially difficult to outsiders.
ProfileText.HowReach: Sustained, focused prayer for the Gayo is needed. Christians need to find ways to help the Gayo with needs such as improved health care.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: The few Christians among the Gayo tribe very much need our prayers. Pray they will cling to Christ, resting in his commitment to them.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Gayo need medical workers to improve health conditions, as local understanding about health matters is very low. Pray for improved medical care.

LocationInCountry: Gorontalo Province, widespread along both coasts, Sulawesi sea north, and Maluku sea south; Sulawesi Utara Province, incursion into Bolaang Mongondon Utare regency, northeast from Gorontalo city.

ProfileText.Summary: The Gorontalo live in the northern part of Sulawesi island between the provinces of Central Sulawesi and North Sulawesi with the Sulawesi Sea to the north and Tomini Bay to the south. A number of Gorontalo are powerful national figures. Within the immediate family, children are not allowed to joke with their father, but must act respectfully. The Gorontalo have been Muslim since the 16th century. They observe Friday prayers with colleagues from work. Many residents also walk to their neighborhood mosque for evening prayers. Each village contains one to three mosques. Despite being strongly Islamic, many Gorontalo still believe in motolohuta (supernatural creatures) and hulobalangi (mysterious powers) of which they are both fearful and fascinated.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But in your hearts honor Christ the Lord as holy, always being prepared to make a defense to anyone who asks you for a reason for the hope that is in you; yet do it with gentleness and respect,
ProfileText.Obstacles: Christian workers should be prepared for spiritual opposition as Jesus is presented to the Gorontalo, who have been Muslim for many generations.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps some in the Gorontalo community will learn of Christian resources available on the Internet, such as the Jesus film and recordings. Pray they will download these, and that the Lord will give them understanding as they view and listen.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for those in the Gorontalo tribe who identify themselves as Christians. Pray they will not lose their zeal to know and serve the Lord, and will represent him honorably.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Gorontalo officially gained provincial status in the year 2000. Gorontalo leaders are aware of the challenges inherent in organizing and governing a new province. Please pray this work will be well done.

Resources.WebText: Download audio Bible app from Google Play Store

LocationInCountry: Southeast Sumatra island, Jambi Province, widely spoken throughout; Sumatera Selatan Province, thin shared language zone running length of northern border; Riau Province, small corner areas, Indragiri Hulu and Indragiri Hilir regencies; Sumatera Barat Province, Pessisir Selantan regency, border enclave; Bengkulu Province, small area south of Lake Dipatipan.

ProfileText.Summary: Most of the area inhabited by the Jambi is a lowland basin of dense jungles, peat bogs, swamps, and rivers. This area is drained by the mighty Batang Hari River and its many tributaries. The river system, which is 409 miles/655 km long, is important both as a means of transportation and as a source of fish. The Jambi are a very proud people due to their links with the ancient Malay kingdom that flourished from the 7th century AD until the Middle Ages. Sadly, this pride now threatens their economic development due to their unwillingness to accept modernization and reform. Almost all of the Jambi are Muslim. Every village has a mosque or prayer house and typically also an Islamic religious school (madrasah). They also believe that religious leaders, dwarves, and shamans have supernatural powers.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: My mouth will speak the praise of the LORD, and let all flesh bless his holy name forever and ever.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Jambi are strongly Muslim, mixed with traditional religions, and have been for generations. And they are a proud people.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for Gospel radio to be available in the Jambi Malay language, and that the people will learn of these broadcasts. Pray the Lord will give them understanding as they listen.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are a few individuals in the Jambi tribe who identify themselves as Christians. They need prayer support, living in a strongly Muslim environment.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Greater educational assistance will help them learn skills that will make them more competitive with other ethnic groups who have moved into the area. Better medical care is also needed.

ProfileText.Summary: The Jambi, also known as the Jambi Malay, inhabit a lowland basin of dense jungles, peat bogs, swamps, and rivers. The Batang Hari River system is an important means of transportation and a source of fish for them. The Jambi are very proud of their links with an ancient Malay kingdom that flourished from the 7th century until the Middle Ages. Sadly, this pride now threatens their economic development. Many are unwilling to accept modernization and reform. Almost all Jambi are Muslim, and every village has a mosque or prayer house, and often an Islamic religious school (madrasah). The Jambi sometimes believe that religious leaders, dwarfs, and shamans have supernatural powers.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: You turn things upside down! Shall the potter be regarded as the clay, that the thing made should say of its maker, He did not make me; or the thing formed say of him who formed it, He has no understanding?
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Jambi put their identity in the Islamic religious system, so few are open to hearing about the finished work of Christ.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for gospel radio to be heard and embraced among the Jambi people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Very few Jambi follow Christ. Those who are believers need prayer support as they seek to live faithfully in a strongly Muslim environment.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for greater educational help. Pray for the Jambi to learn new skills that will make them more competitive in the job market. Pray for more of the Jambi to hear and respond to the gospel message.

Resources.WebText: Jesus Film: view in Malay, Jambi

LocationInCountry: Widespread throughout Indonesia; mainly in Jawa Tengah, Yogyakarta, Jawa Timur, and Lampung provinces; scattered enclaves on Sumatra island and resettlements in Papua, Sulawesi, Maluku, and Kalimantan.

ProfileText.Summary: Most of the Jawa Banyumasan people make their living from farming, and they are fairly advanced in agricultural production. The majority are Muslim, however, most are nominal Muslims. The other one-fifth are serious Muslims who strictly follow Islamic teachings and are faithful in worship. In addition, there are some Jawa Banyumasan who follow animistic beliefs. They believe there are spirits that come from the unseen world.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And one called to another and said: Holy, holy, holy is the LORD of hosts; the whole earth is full of his glory!
ProfileText.Obstacles: The majority of the Jawa Banyumasan people are Muslim, although most are not strongly committed to Islam.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray that the Christians in this people group will grow in maturity and numbers such that they can carry the good news of Christ to their own people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for workers needed to sow God's Word into Jawa Banyumasan families, healing and strengthening households with God's blessings. There are followers of Christ among the Jawa Banyumasan people. Pray they will be faithful to fellowship together, encouraging each other and teaching each other. Pray they will be zealous to be real disciples of Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Jawa Banyumasan people still need assistance to increase their agricultural production. They need more dams; a better irrigation system would help them harvest more than three times as much per year. Development of new industry is still needed outside the city of Cilacap.

ProfileText.Summary: Most of the Java Banyumasan people make their living from farming. They are fairly advanced in agricultural production. Although the majority are Muslim, most are nominal Muslims who also practice animism. Only few strictly follow Islamic teachings and are faithful in worship.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And the glory of the LORD shall be revealed, and all flesh shall see it together, for the mouth of the LORD has spoken.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Many Java Banyumasan look to spirits to protect them from disaster and bless their work and families. They have no idea that there is a loving Savior who came to destroy the works of the devil.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are Christian believers among this Javanese subgroup who can take the good news to others.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the followers of Christ among this people group would mature and grow in number. Pray they would be faithful to fellowship together, encouraging and teaching one another. Pray for them to share the gospel with their people.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the Lord to send mission workers to the Java Banyumasan to share his love and assist them in their agricultural efforts. Pray for a hunger for righteousness that will lead them to the cross and the empty grave. Pray for a massive harvest among the Java Banyumasan people this decade.

LocationInCountry: Widespread throughout Indonesia; mainly in Jawa Tengah, Yogyakarta, Jawa Timur, and Lampung provinces; scattered enclaves on Sumatra island and resettlements in Papua, Sulawesi, Maluku, and Kalimantan.

ProfileText.Summary: The Jawa Pesisir Kulon people tend to be open and spontaneous in their social interactions. This is evident in their vibrant, colorful, and artistic clothing. Their culture leans more toward Islamic culture than towards their own historical Jawa culture. Islam is looked at as the national cultural foundation that takes precedence over traditional Jawa cultural values. Despite the adherence to Islam, the practice of occultism is very evident. Dukun (shaman/healer/occultist) are heavily relied upon. Various ceremonies that include meals are done to obtain happiness, safety, and peace.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And I said: Woe is me! For I am lost; for I am a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips; for my eyes have seen the King, the LORD of hosts!
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Jawa Pesisir Kulon people may not have a proper understanding of what Jesus taught, and who He claimed to be. Pray for accuracy in their understanding.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray that persons and households of peace will be found among the Java Pesisir Kulon people who will catalyze movements to Jesus among their own people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for those who know and follow Jesus among the Jawa Pesisir Kulon people. Pray they will be firmly established in the faith, not doubting or wavering like shifting shadow. Pray they will be rooted and established in love.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Jawa Pesisir Kulon need high quality, practical, vocational training, including appropriate technology. Present industries need to be expanded. The transportation infrastructure needs to be developed.

ProfileText.Summary: The Java Pesisir Kulon people are often open and spontaneous in their social interactions. Their attire tends to be vibrant, colorful and artistic. In terms of culture, they are heavily influenced by Islam. They also practice occultism, consult shamans and engage in a variety of ceremonies to invoke happiness, safety and peace.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: For "All flesh is like grass and all its glory like the flower of grass. The grass withers, and the flower falls, but the word of the Lord remains forever." And this word is the good news that was preached to you.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Most of the Java Pesisir Kulon have either not heard or do not understand the good news. Years of following Islam and folk religion have made them resistant to the gospel.
ProfileText.HowReach: Persons and households of peace can be found among the Java Pesisir Kulon to catalyze movements to Jesus.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the Christ followers among the Java Pesisir Kulon to grow in their faith. Ask God to give them boldness to share Jesus with their family and friends.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the Lord to send workers to the Java Pesisir Kulon to preach and demonstrate his kingdom through practical vocational and technology training. Pray for this people group to have the spiritual hunger it takes to seek and find the Savior.

LocationInCountry: Widespread throughout Indonesia; mainly in Jawa Tengah, Yogyakarta, Jawa Timur, and Lampung provinces; scattered enclaves on Sumatra island and resettlements in Papua, Sulawesi, Maluku, and Kalimantan.

ProfileText.Summary: The Jawa Pesisir Lor are known to express their convictions with action and emotion, not just words. Many view traditional Jawa culture as backward and are proud of what they consider to be their more modern worldview and stronger Islamic commitment. Most Jawa Pesisir Lor people consider sacred the graves of two holy men, Sunan Kalijaga and Sunan Ja'far Shodiq. People come to both of these graves to worship and to seek blessing.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And I heard the voice of the Lord saying, Whom shall I send, and who will go for us? Then I said, Here I am! Send me.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Gospel of grace, found only through Jesus Christ, is difficult for people with this background to comprehend and accept.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Bible and many good tools such as the Jesus film are available in the language of these people. Pray for workers.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the believers among this people, that they will hunger and thirst for righteousness, and will be well instructed in the faith. Pray they will present a favorable witness to those around them.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Lord will open the hearts of the Jawa Pesisir Lor people to desire God's blessings through a movement of family-based discovery Bible studies. Pray for more effective irrigation systems and for improved employment opportunities for these people.

ProfileText.Summary: The Java Pesisir Lor often express their convictions with action and emotion. Many view traditional Javanese culture as backward and are proud of their worldview, which they consider to be more modern. This includes a stronger commitment to Islam. They also consider the graves of two holy men, Sunan Kalijaga and Sunan Ja'far Shodiq, to be sacred. The Java Pesisir Lor visit these graves to worship and to seek blessings.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: You keep him in perfect peace whose mind is stayed on you, because he trusts in you.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Javanese practice a mix of Islam and Sufi mysticism, which is a barrier to the gospel message.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Javanese can send workers to their lost neighbors. Pray for the Lord of the Harvest to send more workers into this waiting harvest field.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that believers in this people group would hunger and thirst for righteousness and would grow in the faith. Pray for them to boldly witness to those around them.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Ask the Lord to soften the hearts of the Java Pesisir Lor people. Pray for family-based Bible studies. Pray for more effective irrigation systems and for improved employment opportunities for these people.

LocationInCountry: Sumatra, Jambi Province, Kerinci regency, western mountains, Sungaipenuh area, north and west; also into Sumatera Barat Province, Solok Selatan regency.

ProfileText.Summary: A village of Keinci is called a dusun and is inhabited by one clan that has descended from one common female ancestor. A mother's clan is called the kelbu. This kelbu is considered the most important family unit. Islam is the majority religion of the Kerinci, but they still hold to animism, especially as it is exhibited by their use of traditional healers and magic. In their everyday life they often refer to tataman (meeting ghosts), tatampo (being hit by ghosts), and tapijek anaok antau (being stepped on by ghosts).
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But they who wait for the LORD shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings like eagles; they shall run and not be weary; they shall walk and not faint.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Following Jesus can bring fear of upsetting the spirits, as well as upsetting the community.
ProfileText.HowReach: Christians need to minister to the physical and material needs of the Kerinci, building bridges of trust.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are few Christian believers among the Kerinci community today. Pray for these few, and pray for the additional believers that will soon join them. Pray they will faithfully fellowship together, and will grow in understanding and applying the truth of Scripture.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: This group is quite fortunate to live in a fertile area. But they need to increase their use of appropriate technology to improve their farming and rain-forest productivity.

LocationInCountry: Sumatera Selatan Province, Ogan Komering Ulu Selatan, Ogan Komering Ulu Timur, Ogan Komering Ulu, and Ogan Ilir regencies; separate areas along Komering river from Ranaumeer to near Palembang city.

ProfileText.Summary: The name "Komering" comes from the Komering River, which is their life source. There are two subgroups within the Komering people - the Komering Ilir ("downstream") and Komering Ulu ("upstream"). The Komering generally live on both sides of the Komering river. The side of the river that has a main road normally has more people and is more prosperous. As a result, the people in villages on the side of the river without a main road tend to move to villages that have a road. Most Komering are followers of Islam, which strongly influences their culture. However they also still believe in spirits. They often call a shaman to heal sick people or to cast out demons. Marriages between Komering and people from other ethnic groups who are not Muslims are forbidden.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: On the glorious splendor of your majesty, and on your wondrous works, I will meditate.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Komering have followed Islam and animism for centuries.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Javanese are near neighbors to the Komering and there are quite a number of believers among them. Pray they will understand the Great Commission compels them to cross cultural barriers to share the gospel with the Komering.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few Komering individuals who identify themselves as Christians. Pray they will be zealous to know and serve Jesus Christ, and will have their faith strengthened through fellowship with each other.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Komering River has the potential to become an irrigation source. If this could be done, it would enable year-round planting of rice. Additionally, instruction about the use of 4-month rice would increase agricultural productivity.

LocationInCountry: Sulawesi Selatan Province, Sinjai, Bulukumba, and Bantaeng regencies; southeasternmost corner of peninsula, Salayer strait.

ProfileText.Summary: The Coastal Konjo are a community which maintains traditional ways of living, such as wearing black clothes, not using tools and practicing occultism as part of their animistic worship. They have never had a king and do not follow a system of social stratification like other Konjo groups. They tend to be materialistic and proud. They demonstrate a competitive desire to gain more wealth but spend lavishly to impress others. They also feel that they must protect their siri (honor/self-esteem), as well as that of the community. They are Muslim, however animistic practices are still maintained and the Islamic religious leader does not have much influence. The people choose him for leading religious ceremonies and duties in the mosque. An Amma Toa (old father) from the Konjo Hitam is regarded as the religious leader in the area and is feared because of his magical powers.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Now war arose in heaven, Michael and his angels fighting against the dragon. And the dragon and his angels fought back, but he was defeated, and there was no longer any place for them in heaven.
ProfileText.Obstacles: This people group is strongly committed to their traditions, and they are a proud people.
ProfileText.HowReach: Gospel recordings are available in their language. Pray for workers to take these to the people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for those few individuals in this tribe who are Christians. Pray they will clearly understand what it means to know Jesus as Lord and Savior, trusting him fully for forgiveness of sin and for power to live this life.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Coastal Konjo need to be prepared for encountering the changes of the modern world so that they can adapt to the changing world without losing their identity. They need leaders who understand loyalty to traditional customs while also introducing new and beneficial practices. Pray for these things.

LocationInCountry: Nusa Tenggara Timur Province, Flores Timur regency, also Solor island; possibly in pockets on north Pantar coast, northwest Alor, surrounding islands.

Southernmost Sumatra island, 3 provinces, many communities near or on Selat Sunda, west, central, and south Lampung Province, regencies: Lampung Barat and Tanggamus, southwest coast and coastline around Semangko bay, Way Kanan, Lampung Utara, and Pringsewu, inland, southeast tip, Lampung Selatan, east coast of Lampung bay and nearby islands Sebuku, Sebesi, Tabuan, and Legundi; Sumatera Selatan Province, Ogan Komering Ulu Selatan, Ogan Komering Ulu Timur, and Ogan Komering Ulu regencies, near headwaters of Kanan river; south Bengkulu Province, Kaur regency.

ProfileText.Summary: One of the key principles of the Lampung Peminggir is that of Pi-il Pesenggiri, which means, "guarding one's dignity above all else." They usually live a simple life, yet they love to receive honor or praise. They typically do not hesitate to spend huge sums on ritual celebrations. The Lampung Peminggir are followers of Sunni Shafi'i Islam.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: They shall speak of the might of your awesome deeds, and I will declare your greatness.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The good news of grace found in the finished work of Jesus Christ is difficult for these people to comprehend and accept.
ProfileText.HowReach: Scriptures, the Jesus film, and Gospel recordings are available in the language of these people. Pray for workers.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the believers among this people group, that they will know that it is by grace they have been saved, not of works that they may not boast.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the Gospel to soon be made available to each individual in this community, in their own language, and in a manner they can understand and believe.

LocationInCountry: Sumatera Selatan Province, widespread in northern 2 thirds of province; Musi river upstream to Bukit Barisan mountains, downstream to eastern coastal swamplands; into northeast Lampung Province; a few small border areas in Jambi and Bengkulu provinces.

ProfileText.Summary: The Lematang people are very hospitable and friendly when welcoming newcomers. They have a strong sense of community togetherness proven by their adherence to "gotong royong" (neighborhood mutual service and assistance), not only to the Lematang community itself, but also to outside communities. They currently embrace Islam, yet still hold to ancient beliefs concerning magic and mystical powers.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Let the wicked forsake his way, and the unrighteous man his thoughts; let him return to the LORD, that he may have compassion on him, and to our God, for he will abundantly pardon.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Scripture is not available in the language of the Lematang, requiring other means to convery Biblical truth.
ProfileText.HowReach: Christians may be able to minister to the Lematang through schooling for the children, and through micro-enterprise.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are only a few known believers among the Lematang. Pray the eyes of their hearts may be enlightened in order that they may know the hope to which they have been called, the riches of their glorious inheritance.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for improved schools for the children of the Lematang, and that parents will place priority on education for their children.

LocationInCountry: Sumatra, Sumatera Selatan and Bengkulu provinces, Lubuklinggau and Muaraklingi areas south, east, and north generally; very small enclave just east of Bengkulu city.

Sumatra island, Sumatera Selatan Province; east down Lematang and Ogan river valleys, south of Muaraenim town, east and southeast of Lahat town; Bengkulu Province; central Bukit Barisan highlands west to Indian Ocean along Bengkulu coast; Lampung Province, 4 separate enclaves.

ProfileText.Summary: The Madura are the third largest people group in Indonesia. They are renowned for their harsh character and lifestyles. This is probably caused by their natural surroundings and their history of oppression by others. The majority of Madura people are known for being very devout Sunni Muslims. Nevertheless, many Madura people seek security by the use of magic spells that are used in an attempt to control both good and evil spirits.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Their offspring shall be known among the nations, and their descendants in the midst of the peoples; all who see them shall acknowledge them, that they are an offspring the LORD has blessed.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The large Madura community has long resisted the Gospel of Jesus Christ, but that can change.
ProfileText.HowReach: Much sustained, focused prayer is needed to prepare the hearts of the Madura to understand and believe the good news of Jesus. Prayer prepares the ground.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are only a few Christian believers among the large Madura people group. Pray they will rest firmly upon Jesus and his finished work on the cross, being zealous to know and serve him, and living consistently in the power of His Spirit. Pray they will be tactful yet bold witnesses for Christ to their own people.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the Lord to multiply the reception and influence of His Word among the Madura, leading them to love Him with their whole being. Madura people generally have a low income. Medical services, better nutrition and education are greatly needed. Education, especially jobs skills education, is an immense need.

ProfileText.Summary: The Madura are the third largest people group in Indonesia. They are known for their harsh character and lifestyles. This may be the result of their environment and a history of being oppressed by other people groups. The majority of the Madura are very devout Sunni Muslims. Nevertheless, many seek security through the use of magic spells and other attempts to control good and evil spirits.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The grass withers, the flower fades, but the word of our God will stand forever.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Madura community has traditionally been resistant to the gospel of Jesus Christ. Few local believers will dare to reach out to them.
ProfileText.HowReach: Sustained, focused prayer is needed to prepare the hearts of the Madura to receive Gods message.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are only a few Christian believers among the large Madura people group. Pray that they would abide in Christ, zealously serve him, and live in the power of His Spirit. Pray for these brothers and sister to be bold witnesses for Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the Lord to speak to the Madura. Ask the Lord to draw many into His Kingdom, leading to a movement to Christ. Pray for mission workers to preach and demonstrate Gods love to the Madura, assisting them with their education and occupational needs.
