LocationInCountry: Sulawesi Selatan Province, southwest corner of the peninsula, most of Pangkajene Dan Kepulauan, Maros, Gowa, Bantaeng, Jeneponto, and Takalar regencies.

ProfileText.Summary: The primary source of income among the Makassar is rice farming; however, they are also well known throughout Indonesia for their skill in trading. Polygamy is accepted; however, it is only practiced among the wealthy since a separate house must be provided for each wife. Siri (respect and honor) is the social code by which the Makassar live. Anyone seriously offending another person's siri runs the risk of being killed and the external authorities will often refuse to become involved. The Makassar people are almost all Muslims, nevertheless traditional beliefs are still influential, especially in the remote areas.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: All these things my hand has made, and so all these things came to be, declares the LORD. But this is the one to whom I will look: he who is humble and contrite in spirit and trembles at my word.
ProfileText.Obstacles: To follow Jesus among the Makasar is likely to upset community harmony, and to risk becoming an outsider.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps mature Christian believers in other Indonesian tribes will become burdened for their Makasar neighbors. Pray they will act in response to the prompting of the Lord's Spirit, out of love as well as duty.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray the faith of the few followers of Christ among the Makasar people will be strengthened. Pray they will grow in their knowledge of Christ, and that their love for each other will also grow. Pray they will be excellent witnesses to the goodness of Christ to family and friends.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: At this time the Makassar people need training to increase their agricultural production. Medical personnel and nutritional information are also needed, because the Makassar people in rural areas still suffer from poor nutrition. Pray for these needs to be met.

They accept polygamy, but only the wealthy practice it since the man must provide a separate home for each wife. Siri (respect and honor) is the social code by which the Makassar live. Anyone seriously offending another person's siri runs the risk of being killed; external authorities often refuse to become involved. ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Here is a call for the endurance of the saints, those who keep the commandments of God and their faith in Jesus.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Following Jesus among the Makassar is likely to upset community harmony and to lead to excommunication.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps mature Christian believers in other Indonesian peoples will become burdened for their Makassar neighbors.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray the faith of the few followers of Christ among the Makassar people would be strengthened. Pray they would grow in their knowledge of Christ, and that their love for each other would also grow. Pray they would be excellent witnesses to the goodness of Christ to family and friends.

LocationInCountry: Kalimantan Timur Province; east central coastal area, from Mahakam river basin east to Celebes Sea coast, north from Cape Pandan along coast south to Samarinda city area.

ProfileText.Summary: Partially due to their frequent relocations, the Kutai live spread out along the eastern coast of East Kalimantan. In the past, the Kutai had a system of social classes that included nobleman, ordinary people, and slaves. The nobility used to be called Kramas, Mas, Aji, and Radenor Pangeran Datu. Today, respect is given to people based on their education and wealth, not their title. Generally, the Kutai are Muslims. However, in their daily lives, they still worship spirits. Previously, the Kutai were Hindu and they were called 'Kaharingan '. Since then, however, most people in the Kutai area have turned to Islam. This has resulted in much mixing between the faiths of Islam and Hinduism.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And he said with a loud voice, Fear God and give him glory, because the hour of his judgment has come, and worship him who made heaven and earth, the sea and the springs of water.
ProfileText.Obstacles: No Christian resources are reported as available in the language of the Kutai. No scripture, no Jesus film, no Gospel recordings or other resources.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps Christians in other Indonesian tribes will be led to take the news of Christ to the Kutai. Pray especially they will make contact with Kutai Christians, and will be able to help these people grow to spiritual maturity.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: The few people in the Kutai people group who identify themselves as Christians need prayer support. Pray they will clearly understand the distinction that must be made between a real disciple of Jesus Christ and that of a casual commitment to the Christian religion. Pray they will learn to live in the power of Christ's Spirit, demonstrating love, joy, peace, and all the fruit of the Spirit.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Kutai need better transportation infrastructure to assist the remote villagers in taking their crops and commodities to the market. At present, the main form of transportation is by sea and river, as land transportation is very difficult.

ProfileText.Summary: The Malay people are believed to have originated in Borneo and then expanded outwards into Sumatra and other regions, including Indonesia. These people were descendants of Austronesian-speakers who migrated from the Philippines and originally from Taiwan. Malays practiced Buddhism, Hinduism, and their native Animism before converting to Islam in the 15th century.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Young men and maidens together, old men and children! Let them praise the name of the LORD, for his name alone is exalted; his majesty is above earth and heaven.
ProfileText.Obstacles: A strong commitment to Islam dating from the 15th century establishes strong ethnic group identity with that religion. To change religions threatens a person's place in family and society.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for God's blessing, strengthening and healing of families and communities within the Malay through the abundant life Jesus offers to all who call on His name.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the few Christian believers among the Malay, that they will have Scripture resources made available in their language, as well as other resources to help them grow and mature. Pray they will keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Malay of Indonesia will hunger to know more of Jesus (whom Muslims call Isa al-Masih) and will be drawn to this Man. Pray their hunger will be satisfied, that the Spirit of Christ will help them.

LocationInCountry: Sulawesi Barat Province, Majene, Polewali Mandar, and Mamuju regencies. Main area near Cape Mandar and Majene city; 3 coastal enclaves north of Majene city; northernmost point of province, coastal area between Parangkayu and Simajo towns. Also, south Sulawesi Province, Pangkep regency, Pabbring islands near Makassar city, other areas.

ProfileText.Summary: The Mandar people live on low coastal plains and mountains in the province of West Sulawesi. The Mandar region is surrounded by mountains with a large area in the middle suitable for rice fields. As a society that used to be an independent kingdom, the Mandar recognize three social classes. The high class consists of the nobility, the middle class are the commoners, and the lowest class is the slave class. The nobility are referred to as Daeng for "royal class" and Puang for the "common class". There is a king of the Mandar, chosen by traditional leaders. The Mandar people are Muslims. At the same time, traditional animistic beliefs are still strong in daily life. They believe in the power of unseen spirits that inhabit sacred places. The services of a dukun (shaman/healer/occultist) are often sought.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: One generation shall commend your works to another, and shall declare your mighty acts.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Some scripture has been published in the Mandar language. Please pray for scripture to actually become available to the people such that they can learn from it.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps church planters from other Indonesian people groups will come to the Mandar. Pray they won't be overlooked.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray the few followers of Christ among the Mandar will learn to put on the full armor of God, being protected against all that will harm their faith and their testimony.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Mandar need assistance in management of their commercial agricultural enterprises so that they can obtain maximum profit. They need help to professionally market sea products (sea turtle and cakalang fish) to obtain the highest market values.

LocationInCountry: Widespread in the Indonesian Archipelago; west central Sumatra, Padang area. Nearly half live outside central Sumatra; South Sumatra, west coast Mukomuko area

ProfileText.Summary: These people are well known for their tradition of merantau (going to distant areas to seek success). Many of them have moved to other islands in Indonesia. In the 1800s, the Dutch took advantage of a conflict between the Minangkabau cultural guardians and Muslim leaders and intervened to gain control of the area. Islam was used as a rallying point in the struggle against the Dutch and resulted in Islam being incorporated into Minangkabau traditions.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But this I call to mind, and therefore I have hope: The steadfast love of the LORD never ceases; his mercies never come to an end; they are new every morning; great is your faithfulness. The LORD is my portion, says my soul, therefore I will hope in him.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Minangkabau are a very large people group with very few Christian believers. Challenges are many with such a ratio.
ProfileText.HowReach: Individuals living outside their original home area are often somewhat open to new perspectives. Perhaps workers can seek out such individuals for purposes of sharing the love of Jesus with them.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray the few believers among the Minangkabau will become firmly established in the faith, understanding and believing the good news of grace found in Jesus Christ. Pray they will tactfully share this faith with family and friends.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for improved educational opportunities for the children of the Minangkabau.

ProfileText.Summary: The Minangkabau people are well known for their tradition of merantau, which is going to distant areas to seek success. Many of them have moved to other islands in Indonesia to accomplish this. In the 1800s, the Dutch took advantage of a conflict between the Minangkabau cultural guardians and Muslim leaders, intervening to gain control of the area. Islam was used as a rallying point in the struggle against the Dutch and resulted in Islam being incorporated into Minangkabau traditions.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Behold, the LORD God comes with might, and his arm rules for him; behold, his reward is with him, and his recompense before him.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Islam is firmly entrenched in the Minangkabau people as part of their identity.
ProfileText.HowReach: Individuals living outside their original home area are often somewhat open to new perspectives. Perhaps workers can seek these individuals and share the love of Jesus with them.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the few believers among the Minangkabau to become firmly established in the faith. Pray for them to share their faith with family and friends, leading to a movement to Christ. Pray that they would be known for their love and kindness, drawing Muslims to the Lord.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the Lord to move mightily in this people group this decade. Ask him to establish his kingdom and church among the Minangkabau.

ProfileText.Summary: Palembang is the name of a city and a people group. The Palembang people live mostly in Palembang city, but also live in other areas. A typical Palembang house is designed in a distinctive pyramid shape. Most of their houses are raised, standing above water or land. A child is free to draw family lineage by choosing his family or clan name from the father's or the mother's clan. Other traditions are also "free". For example, a newlywed couple is free to live wherever they want. Although Islamic commitment is very high, the role of the shaman is still prominent in many areas of life. For example, if something is lost or someone is sick, a shaman is usually consulted first.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Let them praise the name of the LORD! For he commanded and they were created.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Palembang is a very large people group, and has a long history of strong commitment to Islam.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray the very few followers of Jesus among the Palembang will grow in maturity and numbers, such that they will be able to take the good news of Christ to all their own tribe. They will need help from Christians outside the tribe, since the task is large.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray the few followers of Jesus among the Palembang will learn to be joyful always, to pray continually, and to give thanks in all circumstances.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Because of their dependence on rice as their livelihood, the Palembang people need irrigation technology so they can make use of the river water for irrigating their rice farms in order to have two or even three harvests a year.

ProfileText.Summary: Palembang is the name of both a city and a people group. Though the Palembang people live mostly in Palembang city, they also live in other areas. A child has the choice to go by his mothers clan name or his fathers. Although Islamic commitment is very high, the role of the shaman is still prominent in many areas of life. If something is lost or someone is sick, they usually start by consulting a shaman.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Behold, he is coming with the clouds, and every eye will see him, even those who pierced him, and all tribes of the earth will wail on account of him. Even so. Amen.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Palembang is a very large people group and has a long history of strong commitment to Islam.
ProfileText.HowReach: Indonesian believers could reach out to the Palembang people. Some are being trained to make disciples.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the few followers of Jesus among the Palembang would grow in number and in commitment to the Great Commission among their people. May they lead joyful lives, pray continually, and stay strong in Gods word no matter the circumstances.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Because of their dependence on rice as their livelihood, the Palembang people need irrigation technology so they can make use of the river water for irrigating their rice farms in order to have two or even three harvests a year. Pray for believers to help them meet this physical need.

LocationInCountry: Widespread in Peninsular Malaysia; also in Sarawak state: Kuching, Samarahan, Sri Aman, and Betong districts.

ProfileText.Summary: The Riaus are peaceful farmers and fishermen living on the northern coast of central Sumatra. They are closely related to the Malays living across the sea from them in Malaysia. It would be safe to call them a Malay subgroup. They keep to themselves and don't mingle with outsiders.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The LORD is good to all, and his mercy is over all that he has made.
ProfileText.Obstacles: They cling tightly to Islam, the one outside idea this people group has embraced. The Riau tend to be distrustful of Christian missionaries, or anyone else bringing them strange religious ideas.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are believers from other people groups on Sumatra Island who can go to the Riau Malay people. Pray this will happen soon.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the few followers of Christ among the Riau Malay people will be so full of the love and joy of the Holy Spirit that others will be willing to put their faith in Jesus as well. Pray that these believers will be protected from persecution.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
When a Riau Malay person decides individually to follow Christ, they are usually viewed as a rebel who has rejected their own people. Therefore, pray that the Lord will give dreams and visions to Riau Malay family leaders that will open their hearts to Jesus. 
Pray for a movement to Christ among the Riau Malay people.

LocationInCountry: Nusa Tenggara Barat Province, Lombok island.

ProfileText.Summary: Most Sasaks are farmers, some are laborers, some are fishermen and some are craftsmen. One can find weavings and earthenware crafts made by skilled Sasak workers in several villages. Many of these are sold to tourists or even exported to Western countries. Many Sasaks look for work in larger cities, both on Lombok and on other islands.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: May our granaries be full, providing all kinds of produce; may our sheep bring forth thousands and ten thousands in our fields;
ProfileText.Obstacles: For newcomers, the Sasak seem very unrefined, frightening and aggressive. But once you get to know them, the Sasak are actually very friendly and open. It will take people who are willing to persevere and overcome obstacles to reach the Sasak people.
ProfileText.HowReach: There have been Discovery Bible Studies among the Sasak people resulting in many turning their hearts to Jesus. More workers can use this foundation to introduce more Sasak people to the Savior.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the believers in Sasak communities will understand biblical principals and share them with others who need God's guidance. Pray that they will not fall away from the Lord but be ready to disciple others in His ways.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray that God will continue to go ahead of missionaries with undeniable signs and wonders that point to Christ. 
Pray for spiritual hunger among Sasak leaders.
Pray that local and foreign missionaries will be filled with boldness to start many Discovery Bible Study story groups among Sasak households that will reproduce rapidly and cause a movement to Christ.

ProfileText.Summary: Sasaks are farmers, laborers, fishermen and craftsmen. Some also weave and create earthenware. They are increasingly looking for work in larger cities, both on Lombok and on other Indonesian islands.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Now war arose in heaven, Michael and his angels fighting against the dragon. And the dragon and his angels fought back, but he was defeated, and there was no longer any place for them in heaven.
ProfileText.Obstacles: To visitors, the Sasak seem unrefined and even aggressive. They are actually very friendly and open to those they accept into their community. Reaching them with the gospel will require perseverance and a willingness to overcome these obstacles.
ProfileText.HowReach: There have been Discovery Bible Studies among the Sasak people resulting in many turning their hearts to Jesus. Mission workers can use this foundation to introduce more Sasak people to the Savior.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for believers in Sasak communities to understand biblical principles and share them with others who need God's guidance. Pray that they would not fall away from the Lord but be ready to disciple others in his ways.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for God to reveal himself through signs and wonders that point to Christ. Pray for hearts to be softened and prepared to receive the good news. Pray for spiritual hunger among Sasak leaders. Pray that missionaries would be filled with boldness to start many churches among the Sasak that would reproduce rapidly and become a movement to Christ.

LocationInCountry: Nusa Tenggara Barat Province. Sumbawa island, west of the isthmus, Moyo island off northern coast.

ProfileText.Summary: The Sumbawa (or Samawa) people group live on the island of Sumbawa in West Nusa Tenggara Province, and are mostly farmers. They are Muslim, but many Sumbawa professing Islam still rely on the advice and help of shamans, especially in times of crisis. They also believe in various spirits and genies, such as samar and bakek.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And he asked them, But who do you say that I am? Peter answered him, You are the Christ.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Sumbawa worldview (Islam/Animism) makes it difficult for them to place their faith in the Son of God, Emmanuel.
ProfileText.HowReach: Indonesian Christians on adjacent islands may bring the Gospel message to the Sumbawa. Pray they will be given a desire to do this.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are a few believers among the Sumbawa. Pray they will be properly instructed in the faith, and that they may stand firm and hold to the teachings of Scripture.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Sumbawa will find improved markets for their agricultural products.

LocationInCountry: Java island, Jawa Barat and Banten provinces; western third of the island, though generally inland from north shore; across border, Jawa Tengah Province, Cilacap regency.

ProfileText.Summary: The Sunda are the largest Indonesian unreached people group. Almost all Sunda are Muslims. In many areas, Islam is mixed with Sunda traditional customs. The Sunda seek to protect their harmony with the natural world. In the legend of Lutung Kasarung, there is a belief that God incarnated a little of himself in the world in order to protect the life of man. This incarnation is called dewata (gods).
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: My soul longs, yes, faints for the courts of the LORD; my heart and flesh sing for joy to the living God.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Following Jesus in a strongly Muslim society invites the loss of much that is important in this life: status, friendships, family, employment, educational opportunities.
ProfileText.HowReach: Christians can assist the Sunda by helping them to become more productive in farming and livestock production and also with small business development.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are only a few followers of Jesus among the very large Sunda community. Pray for them to cling strongly to the truth of Scripture, to be firmly established upon God's character and promises. Pray they would faithfully fellowship together even in spite of opposition.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Data from the West Jawa Statistical Department shows a high rate of poverty. Because of this, the Sunda need help and guidance to raise their standard of living. There is a need for agricultural investment and modernization, and in development of small to medium-sized businesses.

LocationInCountry: Buton island, Sulawesi Tenggara Province, Kota Bau-Bau city; southwest coast towards Buntung strait; adjacent areas in Buton regency, northeast and east.

ProfileText.Summary: The Wolio primarily live on the island of Buton. Their ancestors were immigrants from Johor, Malaysia at the beginning of the 15th century, who also founded the Buton dynasty. In 1540, the sixth king became a follower of Islam. He reshaped the kingdom to become a sultanate and set himself up as the first sultan. Wolio people live as farmers on the land and sea. Primary land crops are rice, corn, and cassava. In the sea, especially from June to September, vast stretches of water are used to cultivate agar-agar (seaweed) that is ground up and used to make a variety of products. Almost all Wolio have beliefs centered in Sufi Islam. They practice meditation in order to receive visions from God, or to find hidden truths far beyond their own reasoning. Belief in reincarnation is also adhered to as a result of Hindu influence.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But I do not account my life of any value nor as precious to myself, if only I may finish my course and the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus, to testify to the gospel of the grace of God.
ProfileText.Obstacles: No scripture is reported as available in the Wolio language, though Gospel recordings are available.
ProfileText.HowReach: Workers are needed to take Gospel recordings and other resources to the Wolio people. Pray for a church planting movement to develop that will take the good news of Jesus to each person in the tribe.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There may be a few followers of Jesus today among the Wolio of Indonesia. Please pray for these and the many others who will soon join them. Pray they will live holy lives, and will fellowship together for encouragement and edification.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Wolio need greater opportunities for work that can provide enough money for their livelihood. Because of the Wolio people's geographical situation, along a major sea lane through Indonesia, there is a great deal of tourism potential for the city. Their fishermen need better training and more knowledge to improve production and distribution of their sea products.

ProfileText.Summary: Jawa Mancanegari are primarily farmers, and have been blessed with extremely fertile land supporting up to four crops per year. Cultural events and ceremonies include dances whereby the dancer will go into a trance by inviting spirits to enter into his body in order to perform extraordinary acts. The majority of Jawa Mancanegari call themselves Muslim. However, most mix Muslim beliefs with Hindu and pre-Hindu beliefs. This mixture of beliefs is called Agami Jawi. Many Jawa Mancanegari learn to read the Qur 'an; however, they seldom understand the meaning.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: They will make war on the Lamb, and the Lamb will conquer them, for he is Lord of lords and King of kings, and those with him are called and chosen and faithful.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Following Jesus will likely bring disfavor in this community, including the loss of friendships and opportunities.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps Indonesian Christians will be led by the Lord's Spirit to carry the Gospel to the Jawa Mancanegari. Pray they will be given this desire and opportunity.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the few followers of Christ among the Jawa Mancanegari, that they will be committed to fellowship faithfully, and will live holy lives. Pray they will be an excellent testimony to family and friends.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Jawa Mancanegari need more employment opportunities due to the high unemployment rate and economic recession in Indonesia. Also, outside the major cities, any type of medical care is basically nonexistent and educational opportunities are very limited.

LocationInCountry: Sumatera Selatan Province, widespread in northern 2 thirds of province; Musi river upstream to Bukit Barisan mountains, downstream to eastern coastal swamplands; into northeast Lampung Province; a few small border areas in Jambi and Bengkulu provinces.

ProfileText.Summary: The Musi name comes from the Musi river along which the people live, in the regencies of Musi Banyuasin and Musi Rawas. Almost all of the Musi are Muslim. Building a house of worship other than a mosque is not allowed in the Musi area by the local government. Marriage between people of different religions is not allowed. The non-Muslim partner must change their religion to Islam. The people follow the Islamic religion because it has been passed down to them and is a part of their culture and not because they understand it or have faith in it. Because of this, religious worship is not an important factor in their lives but rather, it is a part of their identity.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Who made heaven and earth, the sea, and all that is in them, who keeps faith forever;
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Musi strongly resist the presence of a religion other than Islam.
ProfileText.HowReach: We should pray the Musi Christians will grow in maturity and in numbers such that they can effectively carry the good news of Jesus to all of their own people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are reported Christians among the Musi people. Please pray they will not be ostracized or persecuted by their Muslim neighbors, but will be faithful witnesses to the goodness of Christ to all those around them.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray the Musi people will gain no satisfaction from following a religion of works, and instead will yearn to know the love of a God who will relate to them as persons.

LocationInCountry: Sumatra island, Sumatera Selatan Province; east down Lematang and Ogan river valleys, south of Muaraenim town, east and southeast of Lahat town; Bengkulu Province; central Bukit Barisan highlands west to Indian Ocean along Bengkulu coast; Lampung Province, 4 separate enclaves.

ProfileText.Summary: The Pegagan, like other inhabitants of South Sumatra, are generally friendly, easy to get along with and quite open. People who move into their area find it easy to adapt to living with Pegagan neighbors. Rice farming is the mainstay of the Pegagan people's livelihood. Additionally, they raise fish in rivers, produce cloth embroidered with gold and silver thread, and raise small livestock in order to supplement their income. All Pegagan are Muslims. In many places, Islam is intertwined with traditional customs. Many mosques in the Pegagan area are quite large and the Pegagan are very active in religious devotion.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: By this it is evident who are the children of God, and who are the children of the devil: whoever does not practice righteousness is not of God, nor is the one who does not love his brother.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Lack of Christian workers, especially workers who are well prepared, is an obstacle to the advance of the Gospel. Jesus said to pray for workers.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray that indigenous Indonesian Christian workers will be led to take the Gospel to the Pegagan. Pray for financial provision for these workers, and for love to be given them for the Pegagan people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There may not be a single person within the Pegagan tribe who knows and follows Jesus. However, pray for the many who will soon come to saving faith. They will need teachers to help them, and they will need scripture and other resources. Pray they will live holy lives, in obedience to the commands of Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: One Pegagan district, Indralaya, is slated to become a buffer zone for the capital city of Palembang. Because of this, the area is beginning to develop. A need of the Pegagan is to leverage the advantages of this development for their benefit.

LocationInCountry: Widespread in Peninsular Malaysia; also in Sarawak state: Kuching, Samarahan, Sri Aman, and Betong districts.

ProfileText.Summary: The Ketapang Malay live along the western edge of West Kalimantan Province on islands in the Karimata Straits. They are a Muslim group descended from a mix of Malay and Dayak people. Dayak people who are Muslim consider themselves to be Malay. Most Melayu Ketapang are farmers, although some work as fishermen. Crops are shipped to Pontianak and Semarang (on the island of Java) for sale. They are Muslims, though not extremely devout. Currently there are no reports of even a single Melayu Ketapang person who adheres to a religion besides Islam.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: From new moon to new moon, and from Sabbath to Sabbath, all flesh shall come to worship before me, declares the LORD.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Ketapang people consider all of their tribe to be Muslim. To leave the religion is to leave the tribe.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for a growing desire among the Christians in West Kalimantan Province to take the good news about Jesus to all of the tribes in the province.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray the Lord will prepare the hearts of the Ketapang Malay such that when the Gospel comes they will be eager to receive it.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Many potential tourism sites exist in the Ketapang area. It is hoped that raising the rate of tourism to the area will provide economic benefits to the local community. Improvement of transportation facilities whether by land, air, rivers and sea are needed to make easier it to transport farm produce to markets and to encourage tourism.

LocationInCountry: Widespread in Peninsular Malaysia; also in Sarawak state: Kuching, Samarahan, Sri Aman, and Betong districts.

ProfileText.Summary: The Melayu Pontianak are an agrarian people whose livelihoods depend on crops from their farmland as well as freshwater and saltwater fish. The land where they live consists of swampy lowlands only 0-100 meters above sea level, making it difficult to obtain clean water. Generally, Melayu Pontianak houses are built on stilts two meters high in order to protect the inhabitants from wild animals. They are devout followers of Islam. Their art forms and culture are heavily influenced by Islamic culture. However, they still hold animistic beliefs. This is evident in local rituals that blend Islamic culture with animistic elements. Shamans are still very influential.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Now I know that the LORD is greater than all gods, because in this affair they dealt arrogantly with the people.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Pontianak Malay are devout followers of Islam. Islam influences so much of their day-to-day living, even though Animism also has influence.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are any number of good resources available in the Malay language. Workers are needed to take these to the people, and to help them understand the Gospel. Those who are already Christians need to be discipled so they will grow in understanding and holiness, as well as in numbers.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the Pontianak Malay who are Christians. Pray they will live holy lives, and will be zealous to know and serve Jesus Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: One of the greatest needs of the Melayu Pontianak is better transportation access. Accessibility issues have caused the Melayu Pontianak to lag behind other Malay peoples in Southeast Asia in terms of education, industry, and standard of living.

LocationInCountry: Widespread in Peninsular Malaysia; also in Sarawak state: Kuching, Samarahan, Sri Aman, and Betong districts.

ProfileText.Summary: This Malay people group in North Sumatra (that is, Sumatera Utara) is not actually an ethnic group, but rather a culture influenced by Islam. The North Sumatra Malay often avoid speaking frankly for fear they will offend someone. They use signs, parables, and traditional poetry instead. Other elements of their culture are theater and dance. In the dance, they believe they get supernatural power by using incantations and occult puppets called lukah. Most North Sumatra Malay are Sufi Muslims. However, they still hold to their old animistic beliefs. They believe that the teachings of Islam come from their own traditional values which give priority to orderly, harmonistic life together, where each person respects the other. They also believe that spirits are everywhere and influence people's lives.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The LORD is righteous in all his ways and kind in all his works.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Harmony is a priority for these people. For someone in the group to follow Jesus will disrupt this harmony.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray that nearby believers will reach out to them with careful help to improve their industries as well as to present the gospel to them clearly.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the few Christian believers within this community, that they will have a strong and faithful testimony for the Lord, and will honor Him with their lives.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The North Sumatra Malay need help in how to better use their land and sea. They need help to raise their standard of living through more efficient farming methods and fishing technology. Up to the present, they have had difficulty creating new jobs or obtaining new skills.

LocationInCountry: Nusa Tenggara Barat Province; eastern third of Sumbawa island, east of the isthmus; northeast, Sangeang and Banta islands; Nusa Tenggara Timur Province, Komodo island area.

ProfileText.Summary: The Mbojo are also called the Oma ("move") because they often move from one place to another. The main livelihood of the Mbojo is farming. Bima women are usually skilled at making plaited mats from bamboo and palm leaves. The village leader is assisted by highly respected village elders. The Mbojo are not closed to outside influence. Although most Mbojo are devout Muslims, they still believe in spirits and practice forms of animism, even still visiting healers, who are numerous in the area. The Mbojo are afraid of local gods like Batara Gangga (chief of the gods), Batara Guru, Idadari Sakti and Jeneng, as well as other spirit types called Bake and Jin, which live in trees and high mountains. They also believe in sacred trees in Kalate and Murmas, where the god Batara and the gods of Rinjani Mountain dwell.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Every day I will bless you and praise your name forever and ever.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Fear of offending the local gods will make it difficult for the Mbojo to place their faith in Christ.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray that strong movements to Jesus will bring whole families into rich experiences of God's blessings.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: In the 1930s, hundreds of Mbojo in the mountain areas around Dompu heard the gospel and received it. Today there are four villages in the mountains with a 'Christian' population of 90 percent, but they do not fully understand the Gospel. They are very isolated and poor.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Medical assistance is greatly needed, especially for the Mbojo who only make use of the healers. They also need agricultural training and farming equipment. Helping increase the people's awareness of the benefits they could find in the ocean would help improve their economic state.

LocationInCountry: Sumatra island, Sumatera Selatan Province; east down Lematang and Ogan river valleys, south of Muaraenim town, east and southeast of Lahat town; Bengkulu Province; central Bukit Barisan highlands west to Indian Ocean along Bengkulu coast; Lampung Province, 4 separate enclaves.

ProfileText.Summary: The Besemah of Indonesia are an energetic and enthusiastic people. On the Besemah plateau, there are 26 historical sites that have been considered holy since before 100 A.D. Enormous stones were sculpted into amazing forms such as soldiers riding elephants, a man wrestling with a snake monster, and ocean waves. Although Muslim, the Besemah still use these large statues as places for making sacred pledges, calling out to their ancestors' spirits to give blessings, and for protection from misfortune.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But let justice roll down like waters, and righteousness like an ever-flowing stream.
ProfileText.Obstacles: This fairly large people group has only a few followers of Jesus Christ.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Jesus film and audio recordings are available in the Besemah language. Indonesian believers may be able to use these tools to reach their Besemah neighbors with the Gospel message.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the few Besemah believers to be filled with the Holy Spirit, to make music in their hearts to the Lord, always giving thanks to God the Father for everything.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: One of the main needs of the Besemah people is improved medical care, and they also need training in managing their agricultural produce more effectively.

LocationInCountry: Sulawesi Selatan Province, Luwu and North Luwu regencies. Main area along the northwest coast; Bone bay; west in Bastem subdistrict, along Rongkong river valley past Salutallang village; Seko Lemo subdialect spoken in its own enclave in Uro valley, northwest of Sallutallang; enclave of Rongkong speakers in East Luwu regency, Nuha subdistrict near Soroako.

ProfileText.Summary: Luwu villages are fairly small and either located on hills or spread along a plain. These villages consist of extended families, with four to six families living together in one house. They stress the importance of diligence, respecting their elders, and putting the needs of the family before the needs of the individual. An unusual form of adoption is frequent among the Luwu. They believe that family bonds can be broadened and made stronger by allowing relatives or friends to adopt their children. The children end up being raised by both their original parents and their adoptive parents. In 1605, Luwu's ruler became the first South Sulawesi ruler to embrace Islam. Since that time, nearly all Luwu have followed Sunni Islam. Despite this history, all sorts of animistic practices influence their culture.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Then the cloud covered the tent of meeting, and the glory of the LORD filled the tabernacle. And Moses was not able to enter the tent of meeting because the cloud settled on it, and the glory of the LORD filled the tabernacle.
ProfileText.Obstacles: No scripture is reported as available in the primary language of the Luwu, nor are other resources such as the Jesus film.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps Christians in other Indonesian tribes will be led to take the news of Jesus to the Luwu. Pray they will be successful in helping Luwu who are already Christians grow in depth of understanding and commitment to the Lord.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few Luwu who identify themselves as Christians. Pray the peace of God, which transcends all understanding, will guard their hearts and minds in Christ Jesus. Pray they live holy lives in the power of the Lord's Spirit.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Luwu need to be introduced to modern farming of a more practical and productive nature to replace their traditional methods.

LocationInCountry: Banten and West Java provinces: western third of Java; Central Java province: Cilacap regency.

ProfileText.Summary: Most Banten people make their living as farmers or merchants. In both cases, they need to be prepared to face stiff competition in this modern era. They need better educational facilities, as well as joint business ventures with outside companies to achieve a higher level of competitiveness. They live in their own province of the highly-populated island of Java. The Banten people are noted for working together for a common goal such as finishing a rice harvest or repairing a bridge.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: O LORD, what is man that you regard him, or the son of man that you think of him?
ProfileText.Obstacles: Though the Banten people are officially Muslim, many participate in the dark arts of the occult. Many people from different regions of Indonesian come to Banten to learn their spells or to ask for help.
ProfileText.HowReach: As a tourism area, Banten is open to the outside world, but their traditions and culture are still protected by their social mores. Tourists can offer them copies of the JESUS Film in their own language. There are also many Javanese believers living on the same island who can reach out to the Banten people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the believers among the Banten people will live such victorious lives that they will draw others to the Savior. Pray for them to be protected from persecution.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for the Lord to open a way for Banten people to get the training they need to thrive economically.
Pray for a spiritual hunger among the Banten people that will lead them to follow Christ, and share Him with others until there is a church planting movement.

LocationInCountry: Xekong and Saravan provinces, Thateng, Lamam, Karum, Dakchung, and Saravan districts

ProfileText.Summary: The Alak have retained most of their customs and many women wear traditional dress. In the past, Alak women tattooed their faces, but this custom is now dying out. Alak society is traditionally matriarchal. The women lead the family, keep control of finances, and make all major decisions that affect the community. In times of sickness or calamity, or if a poor crop is produced, the Alak believe they have provoked the spirits and a ceremony is held in order to find the offended deity. A chicken is boiled and a shaman summoned to study the liver patterns and stomach of the chicken.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And you will say in that day: Give thanks to the LORD, call upon his name, make known his deeds among the peoples, proclaim that his name is exalted.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Scripture is not reported as available in the Alak language, but Gospel recordings are available.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for workers who will pray for the Alak, and who will take Gospel recordings to them and befriend them.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There may be a tiny number of Christians among the Alak. Pray they will increasingly meet together and encourage one another in Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Alak will have improved medical care available, and will learn improved farming practices.

ProfileText.Summary: The overwhelming majority of the East Katuic-speaking tribes in Laos are ethnic religionists. Although they may recognize a creator god, they also worship and fear a large group of spirits called phi. These spirits have much influence over the daily activities of the people. The people are known to be very skilled in dealing with the spirits that inhabit the rivers, forests, and mountains. Sacrifices are used to manipulate and appease the phi. Some of these people groups were still involved in human sacrifices until recent times.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But he answered, It is written, Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that comes from the mouth of God.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Lack of prayer support and lack of workers hinder the advance of the Gospel.
ProfileText.HowReach: Gospel recordings are available in the Ir language. Please pray for workers to share these with those who speak that language.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There has been no indication of any Christians among the Ir people at this time. But it is not too early to pray for those who will become believers in the days ahead.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for protection from evil spiritual forces for these people. Pray also the people will be completely set free from their influence and control.

ProfileText.Summary: The Ir people group live in the highlands of Laos. They are usually included in other people groups, but they are distinct, and our heavenly Father wants them to be his children. They live in long houses on stilts, and they keep pigs and chickens underneath. During the Vietnam War, US warplanes dropped cluster bomblets over this region. Many of these bomblets remain and can explode when touched by farmers or children.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The next day he saw Jesus coming toward him, and said, Behold, the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world!
ProfileText.Obstacles: The place where the Ir people live is not easily accessible and is not inviting to missionaries. Wet rice farmers using traditional hoes to turn the soil have accidentally set off bomblets as have children playing in the fields. A Western religion, as they consider Christianity, is a strong reminder of American bombers.
ProfileText.HowReach: Medical teams as well as those who make prostheses could make a huge difference in reaching the Ir people. Also, reaching the Ir with radio broadcasts in their language and sharing gospel stories about Jesus could make a difference. There are many strong believers from nearby Vietnam who can reach them.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for the Lord to call forth medical missionary teams to work with the Ir people.
Pray for God to raise up prayer teams to pray that a people movement may begin among the Ir people this decade. 
Pray for spiritual hunger that will turn their hearts to the Light of the world.

ProfileText.Summary: In the past the Jeng lived in the mountains of Vietnam, but they migrated en masse to the plains of southern Laos in 1936. Their culture and worldview has been greatly influenced by the Lao since then, although they have firmly resisted Buddhism. Jeng men and women are easily distinguishable by wearing large cylinders in their earlobes. The Jeng are traditionally animists, although many of their animistic ceremonies have now been abandoned. Their continuing fear of spirits can clearly be seen in their custom of building a miniature model village just for the spirits. Within these villages, which may measure up to 100 meters in length, each particular spirit has its own house. People come here to make offerings and sacrifices.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Beware of false prophets, who come to you in sheeps clothing but inwardly are ravenous wolves. You will recognize them by their fruits. Are grapes gathered from thornbushes, or figs from thistles?
ProfileText.Obstacles: Laos is generally not open to overt Christian missionary activity, and creative means of access to the Jeng people may be necessary.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray the Lord will lead Christians in neighboring villages to reach out to the animistic Jeng people. Pray they will overcome barriers such as difficulties with the Jeng language.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Some Jeng may have heard the Gospel from the small number of Brau and Oy Christians nearby. Please pray the Lord will nurture any seed that has been planted.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Thank the Lord the Jeng have been able to resist Buddhism. Pray the Lord will give them an increasing hunger to know himself, the creator God. Pray for workers who will go to the Jeng with the Gospel message.

ProfileText.Summary: In 1936, the Jeng fled Vietnam for Laos, where they lost some of their cultural uniqueness. Today they live in six villages where they engage in rice farming along main highways. One thing they did not lose was their traditional animism. Indeed, they resisted Buddhist efforts to convert them. They are linguistically and historically related to the Oy and Brau peoples of Laos, among whom are some followers of Christ.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Jesus answered him, Truly, truly, I say to you, unless one is born again he cannot see the kingdom of God.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Resistance to Buddhism conditions them to resist any belief system which denies the trappings of animism.
ProfileText.HowReach: Their residence along major communication arteries opens them to outside ideas; and thus, to evangelism by Oy and Brau followers of Jesus.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray that the small Brau and Oy churches would take advantage of the communication routes to evangelize the Jeng through word, deed and power encounter. 
Pray that God would work in the Jeng people to embracing the ways of Jesus Christ for all of their families and villages.

LocationInCountry: They are concentrated in the Xam-Tai District of Houaphan Province, near the Vietnam border, while a diaspora group lives further south in the Viangthong District of Borikhamxai Province.

ProfileText.Summary: There is some doubt as to whether the main religion of the Tai Khang should be listed as Buddhism or as Animism. Traditionally, they have been animists, but more recently they have come under the influence of Buddhism. The twin strongholds of animistic spirit-worship and Theravada Buddhism continue to grip the hearts of the Tai Khang to this day. They believe in a pantheon of spirits who inhabit the earth. The spirits of their ancestors supposedly roam the earth, and, if treated properly, are benign and bring good luck. Deities are the souls of people who lived especially virtuous lives.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Go therefore to the main roads and invite to the wedding feast as many as you find. And those servants went out into the roads and gathered all whom they found, both bad and good. So the wedding hall was filled with guests.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Laos does not provide a welcome to overt Christian missionary efforts, and there is no scripture reported in the Kang language.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for Christian workers who will be able to communicate clearly in the language of the Tai Khang people and who will be accepted by the Tai Khang.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are no reported followers of Jesus among the Tai Khang but there may be a few among the Tai Khang of China. Please pray for any believers among this people group.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Tai Khang need much prayer to enable them to break free from their current belief systems, which they have followed for hundreds of years.

LocationInCountry: Saravan province, Damouay district
Salavan province: centered in Toumlan district; Savannahkhet province: Nong and Phin districts.

ProfileText.Summary: The Katang are dispersed over a widespread area of southern Laos. In some of the more remote locations, the Katang live in houses made of braided leaves. In recent decades, however, many Katang have moved down from the hills onto the plains, where they have lost much of their cultural heritage and are on the way to assimilation into Lao culture and language. Although most Katang have absolutely no awareness of the Gospel or the claims of Jesus Christ, there is one Katang church in Laos, with approximately 100 known believers. They have faced great opposition from local authorities, shamans, and community leaders, who believe the presence of the Christians will bring a curse on the village from the spirits they have worshipped for countless generations. Most Katang are too bound by fear to consider converting to Christianity.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Then the proconsul believed, when he saw what had occurred, for he was astonished at the teaching of the Lord.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Fear of change and fear of spirits form formidable obstacles to the Gospel.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps the Lord will lead people who know how to tell stories from scripture to the Katang tribe. Pray for prepared hearts among the Katang.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the Katang church, that the people will be fully delivered from their past history of folk beliefs and the worship of created things.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Katang tribe will understand the importance of providing a good education for their children, and will be able to provide that education.

LocationInCountry: Bokeo, Luang Namtha, Oudomxai, and Xaignabouri provinces.

ProfileText.Summary: The large Northern Thai community dominates north and northwest Thailand, being centered around the city of Chiang Mai. They have followed Buddhism for 1,000 years. Like other Theravada Buddhists, they today mix their beliefs with numerous animistic rituals. Protestant missionaries have worked in northern Thailand for about 150 years, but response from the Northern Thai has been painstakingly slow.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: As soon as Solomon finished his prayer, fire came down from heaven and consumed the burnt offering and the sacrifices, and the glory of the LORD filled the temple. And the priests could not enter the house of the LORD, because the glory of the LORD filled the LORDs house.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The belief system of the Thai people doesn't emphasize the reality of sin, and the need for forgiveness. They may not know they need a Savior.
ProfileText.HowReach: Much sustained prayer is needed to cause the Thai to become aware of their spiritual need. May the Lord open the eyes of the Thai.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are some followers of Christ among the Northern Thai. Pray they will not mix Buddhist or animistic beliefs with the pure Gospel of Jesus Christ. Pray for strong commitment to Christ, and for holy living.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for Thai families to be drawn to Jesus and to the Bible to find out more about this man, Jesus. Pray the Thai will increasingly desire a solution for their sin problem. Pray they will desire a Savior, someone who can provide forgiveness for sin and power to live this life victoriously.

ProfileText.Summary: The Lamet have retained their customs and traditional dress and have not allowed themselves to be assimilated by other ethnic groups in the area. Their villages are not easily entered and visitors are not always welcomed. For several years after a wedding the couple lives with the wife's relatives. Only after 3-4 years are the couple allowed to start their own home. The Lamet build a house to accommodate the spirits they believe control their lives. The spirit house is positioned in the center of the village.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The Mighty One, God the LORD, speaks and summons the earth from the rising of the sun to its setting.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Visitors to this tribe may be viewed with suspicion and hostility, and spiritual opposition can be expected.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps people who know how to tell stories from scripture will be able to win the trust of this tribe and communicate the good news of Jesus to them. Gospel recordings are also available.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few followers of Jesus among the Lamet tribe, that they will completely forsake honoring evil spirits and cling fully to the Holy Spirit of Christ. Pray they will learn to live in the power of God's Spirit, which will produce love, joy, patience, and all the fruit of the Spirit.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the Lamet tribe to see the need for their children to attend school, becoming literate and able to help their people cope with the changing world of the 21st century.

ProfileText.Summary: The Lao belong to the Tai linguistic group which began migrating southward from China in the first millennium after Christ, and which are now the politically and culturally dominant group in Laos. Theravada Buddhism is a dominant influence in Lao culture, but many elements of Lao culture predate Buddhism. The government strictly censors content from the outside world, but many Laotians access the outside world through Thai television programs.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Incline your ear, and come to me; hear, that your soul may live; and I will make with you an everlasting covenant, my steadfast, sure love for David.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The religion of the Lao creates a very different worldview than that of the Judeo-Christian Scriptures. Changing worldviews is difficult and stressful.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for Lao followers of Jesus to be effective in demonstrating how Jesus blesses and heals families and communities.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the Christian believers among the Lao, that they will fellowship together faithfully, being instructed adequately in the faith. Pray that Christ may dwell in their hearts through faith.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Lao will not find satisfaction in their current religion, but rather will hunger to know the living Christ.

ProfileText.Summary: The Lao belong to the Tai linguistic group, which began migrating southward from China in the first millennium after Christ, and which now politically and culturally dominate other Laotian groups. Theravada Buddhism plays a dominant influence in Lao culture, but many elements of Lao culture predate Buddhism. The communist government strictly censors content from the outside world, but many Laotians access the outside world through Thai television programs.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Not like these is he who is the portion of Jacob, for he is the one who formed all things, and Israel is the tribe of his inheritance; the LORD of hosts is his name.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The religion of the Lao creates a very different worldview than that of the Judeo-Christian Scriptures. Changing worldviews presents a difficult and stressful obstacle to their finding their way to the only Savior.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for Lao followers of Jesus to effectively show how Jesus blesses and heals families and communities.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the Christian believers among the Lao would fellowship together faithfully and nurture true teachings about the faith. Pray that Christ may dwell in their hearts through faith.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Lao would not find satisfaction in their current spiritual condition, but rather would hunger to know the living Christ. Pray for the Lord to lead the Lao people to a relationship with Christ that will bless their entire nation.

Resources.WebText: Topical Scripture booklets and Bible studies

LocationInCountry: Champasak, Xekong, Saravan provinces

ProfileText.Summary: The ancestors of the Laven (or Bolaven) were part of the great Khmer empire that flourished from the ninth to thirteenth centuries. The empire, which encompassed present-day Laos, Thailand, Cambodia, and parts of Vietnam, declined after the Thai and Vietnamese invasions. They raise a number of crops, including Irish potatoes, which were introduced by the French when Laos was ruled by the French. The influence of Buddhism is clearly seen in Laven society, but it serves more as a veneer to their traditional ethnic religions, such as ancestor worship and animism. The Laven believe that the ancestral spirits remain actively involved in their lives and should be cared for and fed.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Jesus said to them, Is this not the reason you are wrong, because you know neither the Scriptures nor the power of God?
ProfileText.Obstacles: No scripture is reported as available in the Laven language.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are as many Laven people in the United States as there are in Laos. Please pray the Lord will be calling many in the USA to himself and then will send some back to their countrymen in Laos to bring them news about the Savior.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are likely no followers of Jesus today among the Laven people. Prayer is needed.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray the Lord will raise up a strong church for his name among the Laven, both in Laos and in the USA.

LocationInCountry: Luang Namtha province, Nale, Viangphoukha, and Luang Namtha districts

ProfileText.Summary: The Nguan live in stilted houses. Craftsmen carve images into the stilts. Their villages are arranged with the houses in a circular pattern, facing towards a communal house in the middle. The Nguan divide into two main clans, which are named after two different kinds of birds: Sim Takok and Sim Ome. To the clan members, these birds are sacred and must never be killed. The Nguan are animists. They sacrifice chickens to appease the spirit of the forest, kill pigs to placate the spirit of the village, and cows or buffaloes to the spirit of the house. Shamans are still active among the Nguan. Their main job is to preside over the annual rice festival, when a pig is sacrificed.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: For my thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways my ways, declares the LORD. For as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways and my thoughts than your thoughts.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Laos does not offer a welcome to Christian workers. Creative means of access is helpful.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps workers will be sent to the nominal Christians in this tribe, to disciple them such that they will grow in numbers and maturity. They have the potential of reaching their own people with the Gospel.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are several Nguan who would identify themselves as Christians, but they may have only a superficial understanding of what knowing and following Christ means. Pray the Lord's Spirit will give them understanding.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Nguan tribe will be set free from worshipping created things, and will come to understand there is a way they can know the Creator God. Jesus is that Way.

LocationInCountry: Phongsali, Oudomxai, and Luang Namtha provinces.  17 villages.
Saravan province, Laongam and possibly Khongxedon districts

ProfileText.Summary: The Khlor have gradually lost their culture over the course of the past century. They have not practiced their traditional dances or used their ancient swords and shields for about 50 years. Shamans are still used today by the Khlor to mediate between the community and the spirits in time of great need. In the past the influence of shamans was far greater, but today they still have a lot of respect in the eyes of the Khlor people. Even politicians in Laos are afraid of the influence shamans, or spirit mediums, have over people. To placate their fears, Communist officials have tried to stamp out spirit worship among many of the groups in Laos. Khlor shamans once presided over the annual buffalo sacrifice ceremony, which was the focal point of the year to the Khlor. This practice appears to have been discontinued.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in other tongues as the Spirit gave them utterance.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Christians are watched in Laos by Communist officials, and persecution occurs periodically.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for indigenous Christians in Laos to increasingly be able to step up to taking the Gospel to each of the tribal groups in the country. They need to acquire a vision for accomplishing this.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: A small number of Christian believers have been reported among the Khlor people, the fruit of pre-1970 missions work by OMF. Please pray these Christians will learn to fellowship together for edification and encouragement.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray the Khlor people will be set completely set free from the influence of shamans.

ProfileText.Summary: The Khlor people have gradually lost their culture over the course of the past century. They have lost their traditional dances and the use of their ancient weaponry. They still use shamans to mediate between their community and the spirits. Though they are still held in respect, the shamans' influence has greatly dimmed. Controlling communist officials have tried to stamp out spirit worship among many of the groups in Laos, including the Khlor.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The law of the LORD is perfect, reviving the soul; the testimony of the LORD is sure, making wise the simple;
ProfileText.Obstacles: Religious persecution is common in Laos and government officials interfere with religious beliefs' spreading through the country.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Khlor people can hear the life-changing gospel from believers from other people groups.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the followers of Jesus in Laos would be able to share Christ with their neighbors with boldness and love. Pray that the people and communities in Laos would be allowed to follow whatever beliefs they may choose without being punished.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray that the Khlor in Laos would find the clarity to seek out the truth that can be found in Jesus. Pray that they would find peace in Christ. Pray for a network of family-centered fellowships.

In Laos they inhabit six different provinces and regions in the central and northern parts of the country.  The main location of the Phuan is near the Plain of Jars in Xiangkhoang Province.

ProfileText.Summary: The Lao people are renowned for being gentle, friendly and peace-loving. Their communities revolve around close-knit family ties. They have a high birth rate, perhaps because of how they value families. The ancestors of these people are believed to have migrated southward from China approximately 1,000 years ago.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Behold, his soul is puffed up; it is not upright within him, but the righteous shall live by his faith.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Not wanting to acknowledge the reality of sin and the need for forgiveness of sin is sometimes an obstacle to accepting the Gospel message.
ProfileText.HowReach: Ask the Lord to raise up and send out a new generation of fruitful, multiplying witnesses from among the Lao Phuan people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are Christian believers among the Lao; pray they will be united in love, around truth. Pray they will be without any kind of impurity, or greed.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Lao community will retain the good features of their culture while also learning to follow Christ. Pray they be given the gift of faith to trust in him.

They live on both sides of the Laos-Thailand border, especially in northern Savannakhet Province and southern Khammouan Province in Laos.  An additional group of So people inhabit 53 villages in north-east Thailand.

ProfileText.Summary: The So of Laos are primarily farmers. They cultivate a wide variety of crops, such as rice, fruit, and vegetables, for both consumption and trade. They are poorer than most of the surrounding ethnic groups and are therefore dependent on the Lao for many goods and services. Among the So, the village is considered the most significant political unit of society. Each village is led by a headman, and each family is led by the father. "Although the So often show an intense interest in scripture, they have not yet overcome the spiritual barriers that keep them from embracing the King of Kings. Their families and relatives all fear that if any one of them abandons worship of the spirits, the entire family will be punished."
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: I will sprinkle clean water on you, and you shall be clean from all your uncleannesses, and from all your idols I will cleanse you. And I will give you a new heart, and a new spirit I will put within you. And I will remove the heart of stone from your flesh and give you a heart of flesh.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Fear is one of the obstacles to the Gospel experienced by the So. Please pray they will be set free from fear.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for spiritually mature, indigenous workers to take the liberating news of Christ to the So tribe. Laos has a number of evangelical churches, and people in these churches can take the Gospel to unreached tribes in their own country.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few individuals in the So tribe who identify themselves as Christians. They need to be taught how to quickly confess sin, and then trust God's Spirit to fill them and give them the fruit of the Spirit: love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the poor So tribe will be able to improve their standard of living, and will care for those unable to care for themselves.

ProfileText.Summary: Between the first and sixth centuries AD, the area inhabited by the Talieng was a center of the Mon-Khmer Funan Kingdom, and then part of the Chenla Kingdom (sixth to eighth centuries). Many ruins remain today from that golden area of the Khmer civilization. The Talieng today are animists. They have never embraced Buddhism. The Talieng believe spirits can destroy crops, bring sickness and epidemics, and can disguise themselves as people or animals. A host of different deities and spirits are appeased, in order to bring peace and prosperity to their community.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Come, everyone who thirsts, come to the waters; and he who has no money, come, buy and eat! Come, buy wine and milk without money and without price.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Laos does not provide easy access to Christian workers coming from outside the country.
ProfileText.HowReach: Two Gospel recordings exist in their language. Pray for the vision of nearby believers to use these tools to bring them the gospel.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are likely no followers of Jesus Christ in this tribe today, but pray that hearts will even now be prepared to receive the Gospel and its messengers.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Ask the Lord to protect the Talieng from the control of evil spiritual influences. Pray for freedom for them to understand and believe the Gospel when it comes.

They are dispersed over three districts, Akat Amnuai, Phang Khon, and Sawang Daen Din.  An additional group of Yoy make their homes in the central Laos province of Khammouan.

They live in north-east Thailand and central Laos.  Most are found in the Thai provinces of Sakhon Nakhon, Naknon Phanom, Mukdahan and Nong Khai.  All of these locations are near the Thai-Lao border.

ProfileText.Summary: The Nyaw live in northeast Thailand and central Laos. Many live along the Mekong River, where they fish. Their language is said to be similar to the Lao language. The Nyaw believe in many spirits and gods. Buddhism has made little impact on them, despite the fact they have lived alongside the Lao for a considerable time. Some of the major spirits worshipped include the spirit of rice, water, forest, village and trees. They also worship the spirit of heaven. Important to the Nyaw people is the tutelary (protector) spirit of the village. In years past the Nyaw were said to be headhunters. There are a small number of known Christians on both sides of the Lao-Thai border.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The law of the LORD is perfect, reviving the soul; the testimony of the LORD is sure, making wise the simple;
ProfileText.Obstacles: Lack of workers continues to hold back the advance of the gospel throughout SE Asia.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Lord is moving to draw many to himself in Laos. Pray the Nyaw people won't be overlooked.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few Christians among the Nyaw people, in both Laos and Thailand. Pray they will learn to live in joyful obedience to Jesus Christ. Pray they will come to trust God's Holy Spirit to guard their villages.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Nyaw people will soon be set free from following evil spiritual forces and superstition.

LocationInCountry: Attapu province, Sanxai district.

ProfileText.Summary: The Thae (or The) ethnic group inhabits the Sanxai District of Attapu Province in southern Laos. Sanxai District is one of the most sparsely populated areas of Laos, with a total population of only 12,329 in 2,273 families according to the 1995 census. In southern Laos, people from different ethnic groups are so mixed together that some people do not even know what tribe or people group they belong to. Their original languages have also blended together to a large degree.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Bless the LORD, O my soul, and all that is within me, bless his holy name!
ProfileText.Obstacles: This tribe lives in a remote portion of Laos, and is so small in number it may be difficult to find them. They likely have no knowledge of Christianity.
ProfileText.HowReach: No Christian resources are known to be available in the language of this tribe. Pray for those trained in storying from scripture to be able to contact this group and somehow communicate the Gospel of Christ to them.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are quite likely no followers of Christ in this group today. But pray for those the Lord will soon call to himself, that they will learn to be filled with God's Spirit according to Ephesians 5:18-20.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray this small tribe will be able to care adequately for their families, and will be able to provide a good education for their children.

ProfileText.Summary: Laos is a small, land-locked nation in Southeast Asia. The Tai Lue people of Laos live in the northern part of the country near the Chinese border. The Tai Lue dwell in villages near rivers. Most Tai Lue make their living growing and selling wet rice and other crops. Other Tai Lue fish and make jewelry from silver. Their women are expert weavers and embroiderers.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: They read from the book, from the Law of God, clearly, and they gave the sense, so that the people understood the reading.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The region where the Tai Lue live in Laos is isolated. Foreign missionaries are not allowed to enter the area.
ProfileText.HowReach: The JESUS Film and God's Story video are both available in the Lu language. The Tai Lue are primarily an oral culture, so these would be good resources for them.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the tiny numbers of believers among the Tai Lue would be strengthened in the faith and share the good news with their families and neighbors.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Ask the Holy Spirit to soften the hearts of the Tai Lue so that they will be receptive to the gospel. Pray that the gospel would spread rapidly throughout the Tai Lue people and that Christ would be glorified.

ProfileText.Summary: The Luma Akha inhabit several villages in the Boun-Tai District of Phongsali Province in northern Laos. They live in an opium producing area, and today, one in ten Akha are said to be addicted to opium. In addition to being able to recite their long genealogies, which reach back more than 60 generations, the Akha are also able to remember the migration routes their ancestors took to arrive at their present locations. The Luma Akha are animists and ancestor worshippers. One Burmese evangelist, when he visited an Akha village in Myanmar, reported, "As we approached the village, we saw evidence that the battle we would be fighting was spiritual, not physical. Above the entrance way to the village were animal skulls and demonic symbols.... altars around the perimeter of the village still fresh with blood from sacrificed dogs, goats and chickens."
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Blessed is everyone who fears the LORD, who walks in his ways!
ProfileText.Obstacles: Workers can expect spiritual opposition as they present Jesus to the Akha. They need to be prepared for this, but not intimidated.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are believers in tribes near the Luma Akha. Pray they will be obedient to the command of Christ to share the good news they have received.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few Luma Akha who are Christians. They need spiritual protection, and they need mentors and teachers to help them.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray the Luma Akha will be set free from opium addiction, and will find other crops to raise that will generate as much profit as opium.

ProfileText.Summary: The Pala live in a mountainous area near the Oma, a group with whom they share some cultural and linguistic similarities. They are an isolated group, and are considered relatively closed to new ideas and development. They mostly trade with the Lao and the Khmu. On occasions they venture down to the market in Koua where they buy and barter for products they need. Animism and ancestor worship are the dominant religious beliefs among the Pala. Every home has a sacred ancestral altar, where rituals and offerings are made at appointed times. Numerous spirits and deities are also worshipped by the Pala. Every June, after the rice has been planted, a ceremony called Tgelapeu is held to honor the spirits of the village and the harvest.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Blessed is the man who remains steadfast under trial, for when he has stood the test he will receive the crown of life, which God has promised to those who love him.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Christian workers should be prepared for spiritual opposition as Jesus is presented to the Pala tribe.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps churches in Laos which are working to take the Gospel to unreached people groups in their own country will be led by the Lord's Spirit to the Pala tribe. Pray they won't be overlooked.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are no known followers of Jesus among the Pala tribe at this time. Please pray there will soon be many who will become Christ's disciples.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Pala tribe will soon be set completely free from wrong beliefs and the worship of created things.
