ProfileText.Summary:
Most Aceh people live on the northern tip of Indonesia's island of Sumatra in Aceh Province. In the 21st century, there have been a couple of times when Aceh people have fled to Malaysia. This has either been because of civil unrest and the resulting marshal law, or because of natural disasters. 
Some Acehnese are able to find low-paying jobs as construction workers and venders in Malaysia, but a large number of them cannot find work. They are at risk of being trafficked into slave-like conditions. Those who find work are expected to send money back to their families in Indonesia.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Those who look to him are radiant, and their faces shall never be ashamed.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Known throughout Indonesia as devout followers of Islam, the Acehnese are very proud of their Muslim faith. Their devotion to Islam has sometimes led to militancy and violence against the Indonesian government, which has resulted in mayhem and death in their homeland.
ProfileText.HowReach: Believers can find creative ways to hire Acehnese men. Through their interaction they can share Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are no known Acehnese believers in Malaysia. Pray for the Holy Spirit to move among them.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for Chinese and Indonesian believers to help them gain work skills that will allow them to earn a good living. 
Pray for the Holy Spirit to break through to Aceh people so that they will forsake the darkness and seek the One who is the Light of the World.
Pray for a church planting movement among Aceh people in Malaysia that will spread to those living in Indonesia.

ProfileText.Summary: In 1350, sailors saw a glimpse of light around an island in South East Asia and named it Bawean, from a Kawi phrase meaning, "having the sunlight." The island is home to the Bawean people. Bawean also live in the neighboring country of Malaysia. The Bawean are majority Sunni Muslims with some influence from traditional local beliefs. Many grow rice, maize and coconuts for a living.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Truly, truly, I say to you, whoever hears my word and believes him who sent me has eternal life. He does not come into judgment, but has passed from death to life.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Sharing the gospel with Muslims in Malaysia is very challenging; the government equates focusing on Christ as lord with "converting" out of Islam.
ProfileText.HowReach: Many Bawean people live in Singapore, where there is freedom of religion. Perhaps Christ followers can reach out to the Bawean in Singapore first, and new Bawean believers can take Christ to their people in Malaysia and Indonesia.

Pray that there would be a movement to Christ among the Bawean.

ProfileText.Summary: The Bisaya are an indigenous people of the northwest and the coastal area of Borneo, Malaysia. Bisayas' indigenous people settled in Borneo thousands of years ago. The traditional musical instruments consist of Kulintangan, gong, and many small gongs. "It is as if somebody just beats the gong and everyone - men, women, young, and old - just starts to dance." Most Bisaya are Muslims, but usually mixed with traditional religions. The dukun, or herbalist-curer, acts as a witch doctor. A spirit medium uses trances at public ceremonies to cure people.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: To whom then will you liken God, or what likeness compare with him? An idol! A craftsman casts it, and a goldsmith overlays it with gold and casts for it silver chains.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Spiritual opposition will be encountered as Jesus Christ is presented to this Muslim / Animist people. Pray against this.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are quite a number of evangelical Christians in Malaysia. Please pray that some will be given an interest in and a burden for the Bisaya people. Pray the Lord will lead them to share Christ with the Bisaya, and will remain to disciple them.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There may be a few Christians among the Bisaya people today, but even this much is not certain. Pray for those followers of Christ who will soon be coming to faith, that they will learn to be devoted to one another in brotherly love.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray all of the Bisaya tribe will be drawn away from worshipping created beings, and will be set free to worship the one and only Creator God.

ProfileText.Summary: Have you heard of the "middle people," the Bisaya of Western Saba and Brunei Bay, Malaysia? They live along the "middle" stretches of the Limbang River, hence they are known as "people of the middle" or "people of the river," where they live in stilt long houses on the river front where they fish. They also farm inland. Their houses are divided into apartments where extended families live. This indigenous people group is overwhelmingly Muslim, but they mix orthodox Islamic beliefs with animistic and shamanistic practices.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But the hour is coming, and is now here, when the true worshipers will worship the Father in spirit and truth, for the Father is seeking such people to worship him.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Obstacles to ministry include a lack of Scripture in their language, lack of Spirit-empowered witness and evangelism, and a lack of intercessory prayer for them.
ProfileText.HowReach: Outreach is possible through Scripture portions and gospel messages in their language. There are other indigenous peoples with a gospel witness who can reach out to them if motivated by the Holy Spirit. Medical clinics are replacing shamans. Pray that the churches on Sarawak would pray for their kinsmen in Western Saba and Brunei Bay and seek to evangelize them as the Spirit leads. Pray that Christian doctors and clinics would be established among the Bisayas of Malaysia.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray that the Middle People would become open to the gospel and Christian witness.
Pray for a mighty movement to Christ among them this decade.

LocationInCountry: South China seacoast, Sabah State, from Kota Kinabalu southwest along shoreline to Labuan Federal Territory and Brunei border; Sarawak State, north Lawas district; continuing southwest from Batang Baram river mouth to Bintulu town.

ProfileText.Summary: The Mamak live a simple life. They are not attracted to technology or education, and most live in settlements that are spread throughout rubber tree forests. Most Mamak people fuse animistic and Islamic beliefs. They believe in spirits that inhabit various places and things and they believe that ancestral treasures, such as a keris (a ceremonial knife), certain weapons and clothes, have magical powers. The Mamak believe that they are descended from one of the nine children of Adam and Eve. The duty of those involved in leadership is to rule on social conflicts, divorce and carut (accidentally or wrongly saying things that hurt other persons).
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But let justice roll down like waters, and righteousness like an ever-flowing stream.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Malaysia is trying to get tribal peoples to become Muslim, and Christian work among them is not welcome.
ProfileText.HowReach: There is a need for faithful prayer warriors, pounding the gates of heaven for the Mamak people. Pray the Lord will raise up prayer warriors for this purpose.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Mamak have a variety of needs. Their most urgent need is the establishment of a healthier living environment and better healthcare. They also need teachers and help with their educational facilities. Pray for a movement to Christ among them in Malaysia.

LocationInCountry: Peninsular, Pahang and Johor states, Pekan district south along east coast to south of Johor river.

ProfileText.Summary: The Jakun are believed to have lived in Peninsular Malaysia for 7,000 years, and are one of the Orang Asli ("original people") groups. They traditionally hunt game with blowpipes and poison darts, and gather fruit and forest products for bartering. Some are farmers. Jakun have intermarried with Malays, Chinese, Senoi, and Semang people, and tribal boundaries have become blurred. The Jakun bomoh or witchdoctor is both feared and respected in their society. He deals with the spirits in each Jakun village and is more influential than the village chief. If questioned on their religious beliefs, some Jakun who have considerable contact with the Malay people would say that their god is the Lord Allah.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: You are the light of the world. A city set on a hill cannot be hidden.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Please pray for workers because the fields are white unto harvest.
ProfileText.HowReach: Animists have been sometimes termed "pre-Christian", as their belief system can be expanded and corrected to become Biblical. They need Christian workers to help them make this transition.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Even though there may be no followers of Jesus today among the Jakun people, please pray for those who will soon come to saving faith. There is presently no scripture available in the Jakun language, so pray that scripture will become available at the right time.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Many Jakun are in a state of transition. They have largely given up hunting and foraging for food for agriculture in order to survive. Some will need educational and agricultural assistance during this transition period.

ProfileText.Summary: In the hustle and bustle of our lives, it's hard to imagine a world without clocks. For the Bunku Bajau people of Malaysia, time flows not by the clock but by when the sun rises and sets. Birthdays have little meaning. They are masters of the waters, focused on fishing and hunting to support their families. They spend hours on the water and many are expert deep-sea divers.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Blessed is everyone who fears the LORD, who walks in his ways!
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Bunku Bajau are a Muslim people who have deep roots in Islamic culture. If one converts out of Islam, they lose their cultural identity and their position in the community. Many followers of Christ also fear reaching out to the Bunku Bajau due to possible repercussions.
ProfileText.HowReach: Many of Jesus' disciples were fishermen. Jesus' parables about fishing would speak to the hearts of the Bunku Bajau. Believers can use fishing as a way to connect with this community.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Due to the increase in competition in the global fish trade, the Bunku Bajau are pushed to use more commercial fishing methods, which are less sustainable. Pray that they would be able to diversify their economy. 
Pray that followers of Christ in surrounding communities would share him with the Bunku Bajau people. 
Pray that the love of Jesus Christ would touch these masters of the sea in such a way that there would be a spontaneous church planting movement.

LocationInCountry: Widespread in Peninsular Malaysia; also in Sarawak state: Kuching, Samarahan, Sri Aman, and Betong districts.

ProfileText.Summary: In Malaysia, people are classified as Malay by the federal constitution if they speak their national language, Bahasa Malaysia, practice Malay customs, and are Muslim. The Malay people are seen in all levels of Malaysian society. There are urban Malays who are well educated and hold white collar or government positions. Then there are rural Malays who typically occupy jobs such as farming, trading, logging and fishing.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The heavens proclaim his righteousness, and all the peoples see his glory.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Malay people embrace the Islamic religious system, though they allow for spiritual compromises. Although Islam forbids the use of a shaman or witch doctor, many Malays seek their services when they are experiencing a difficult situation. They have allowed no place in their hearts for a Savior.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Malays need the opportunity to hear that Jesus is the only way to salvation and an abundant life. As it stands, there are harsh laws against telling Malay Muslims about Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are millions of followers of Christ in Malaysia, but there are powerful forces keeping them from taking the only Savior to the Malay Muslims. Pray for boldness among Malaysian believers.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray that each Malay person would have the opportunity to hear the good news in an understandable way.
Pray that Malay Bibles would become available and get into the hands of seeking Malays.
Pray that Christian living in Malaysia would share the gospel with Malays no matter what the cost.
Ask the Lord to raise up a Disciple Making Movement among the Malay people in this decade.

ProfileText.Summary: As descendants from the Minangkabau people from West Sumatra, Indonesia, the Minangkabau of Malaysia have a distinct culture and their own royal line that dates back several centuries. The Minang place great emphasis on their women. In order to protect the rights of the female, the name and property are passed down through the line of the mother. The Minang are devout Muslims in spite of their matrilineal heritage. The practice of female inheritance and men being unable to take a second wife draws criticism from more fundamental Islamic people groups.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Let everything that has breath praise the LORD! Praise the LORD!
ProfileText.Obstacles: Malaysia does not provide easy access for Christian workers, and this people group is devoted to their current religion.
ProfileText.HowReach: The people feel that that their culture is in danger of dilution by outside influence. Efforts to share the gospel with them will need to be very sensitive to the preservation of this culture.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Although there are likely no followers of Jesus Christ among the Minangkabau at this time, pray for the preparation of their hearts to receive those who will need to come with attitudes of patience and sensitivity.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: May the unique culture of the Minangkabau be preserved and blessed as a culture designed by the All-Compassionate One. Pray for preservation of the culture while accommodating the truth personified by Jesus.

ProfileText.Summary: As descendants from the Minangkabau people from West Sumatra, Indonesia, the Minangkabau of Malaysia have a distinct culture and their own royal line that dates back several centuries. The Minangkabau highly honor their women, as they pass their names and property through the mother. The Minangkabau are devout Muslims in spite of their matrilineal heritage. The practice of female inheritance and prohibition of polygamy draws criticism from more orthodox Islamic people groups.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: For behold, he who forms the mountains and creates the wind, and declares to man what is his thought, who makes the morning darkness, and treads on the heights of the earth the LORD, the God of hosts, is his name!
ProfileText.Obstacles: Malaysia does not provide easy access for Christian workers, and the Minangkabau are devout Muslims.
ProfileText.HowReach: The people feel that their culture is in danger of dilution by outside influence. Efforts to share the gospel with them will need to be very sensitive to the preservation of this culture.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Although there are likely no followers of Jesus Christ among the Minangkabau at this time, pray for the preparation of their hearts to receive those who will need to come with attitudes of patience and sensitivity.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: May the unique culture of the Minangkabau be preserved and blessed as a culture designed by a compassionate God. Pray for preservation of the culture while accommodating the truth personified by Jesus. Pray that Jesus would stir the hearts and minds of all Minangkabau people in Malaysia.

ProfileText.Summary: The Tausug are also known as Suluks or Sulu in Sabah. In the past, the Tausug made their living as pirates but now rely on farming, fishing, and livestock production. Sunni Islam is the majority religion of the Tausug. As the children grow, they have tutors that give them religious instruction from the Qu 'ran. Despite the influence of Islam, they retain some of their animistic beliefs and practices associated with the spiritual world. Their view of life after death mixes Islamic beliefs with non-orthodox beliefs in spirits. They believe that a person has four souls which leave his body when he dies. The body of the deceased goes to hell, where the punishment of his sins will be revealed according to his wrongdoings while he was living.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Ask of me, and I will make the nations your heritage, and the ends of the earth your possession.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Lack of workers and lack of prayer are two of the largest obstacles to the advance of the gospel.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for good quality Christian radio to be available in the Tausug language, in Malaysia, the Philippines, and Indonesia. Pray the people will learn of these broadcasts and will listen with understanding and faith to believe.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are reports of some Christians among the Tausug of Malaysia. Please pray these Christians will be able to fellowship together and will grow in the nurture and admonition of the Lord. Pray they will be faithful witnesses for Christ to family and friends.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Many of the Tausug people are living below poverty level. More efficient farming methods and more innovative fishing techniques will help raise the standard of living among the people. There is also a need for improved health care.

ProfileText.Summary:
In the 16th century, there was a sea-based kingdom called Uranen. The people who came from this kingdom we now call the Iranun. They were led by a sultan (Islamic political leader), and the kingdom exerted power in Mindanao Island in the southern Philippines and what is now Brunei and Malaysia's state of Sabah.

Today we associate the Iranun people with Mindanao Island, but some are also in Malaysia. Since the economy of Malaysia is stronger than that of the Philippines, some Iranun people have migrated to Malaysia to earn a living. We call these people the Sabah Iranun.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Then he opened their minds to understand the Scriptures,
ProfileText.Obstacles: Their attitude towards Christianity is still marked by indifference. Pray for them to gain a healthy spiritual hunger that will lead them to the Savior.
ProfileText.HowReach: Before there is any outreach, there needs to be much prayer so that these Muslim people will see their spiritual need, and that only Jesus can offer them help.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are no believers among the Iranun people in Malaysia. Pray for a work of the Holy Spirit that will draw them to Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for protection, wisdom, strength, and encouragement for those ministering to the Iranun of Sabah.
Pray that God will provide opportunities for the gospel to be shared with the Iranun people in Malaysia as well as the Philippines.
Pray for the Holy Spirit to open the hearts of the Iranun people and turn their hearts to the King of kings.
Pray for a disciple making movement among the Iranun in both the Philippines and Malaysia.

ProfileText.Summary: Rohingya refugees flee the violent oppression of the government in Myanmar. Some of them wind up in deadly jungle camps, where women are commonly raped, and all Rohingyas risk being killed, even the children. Others are trafficked and wind up as virtual slaves on fishing boats. Most of the Rohingyas are hoping to relocate to Malaysia. Malaysia is a Muslim majority nation where they expect better treatment. But they must go through southern Thailand on the way, leaving them vulnerable to human traffickers, and Thai government officials who suspect them of aiding Muslim insurgents on their southern border.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And he said to them, The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few. Therefore pray earnestly to the Lord of the harvest to send out laborers into his harvest.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Rohingya people are almost all Sunni Muslims. Their hope is in the teachings of the Koran and the Hadith, not in the person of Jesus Christ.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are many believers in Malaysia who can employ Rohingya refugees or teach them job skills that will help them to adjust to their new home.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are no known followers of Christ among the Rohingya people in Malaysia. Pray this will soon change.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for the Rohingya people to find safe refuge in Malaysia and other nations.
Pray for them to find jobs and schools where they can flourish.
The Rohingya people have very little chance to hear that Jesus Christ offers them much more than they could ever imagine. Pray for the Rohingyas in Malaysia to be reached by the Lord through dreams, visions, and through Christian materials on the Internet.
Pray for a disciple making movement among the Rohingya people in Malaysia that will reach those living in Myanmar.

ProfileText.Summary:
There is very little information about the Central Thai people in Myanmar. However, they have retained their cultural values no matter where they live in Southeast Asia.

The Central Thai are unusually polite, respectful, and hospitable people. Their children are brought up to respect those of a higher rank.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The Spirit of the Lord GOD is upon me, because the LORD has anointed me to bring good news to the poor; he has sent me to bind up the brokenhearted, to proclaim liberty to the captives, and the opening of the prison to those who are bound; to proclaim the year of the LORDs favor, and the day of vengeance of our God; to comfort all who mourn.
ProfileText.Obstacles: "Mai ben rai" is heard often on the lips of Central Thai Buddhists. Roughly translated it means "That's not an issue." The phrase expresses a deeply held Thai belief that things are not worth getting agitated over because that would cause one to leave the "middle path" of calmness as taught in Buddhism.
ProfileText.HowReach: Myanmar is a closed country, so it will be especially difficult to reach the Central Thai people in that country. Perhaps online resources will work.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are almost no followers of Christ among the Central Thai people in Myanmar, so pray this will soon change.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Ask God to raise prayer teams who will begin breaking up the soil through worship and intercession. 
Ask the Holy Spirit to soften the hearts of the Central Thai people in Myanmar towards Christians so that they will be receptive to the gospel. 
Ask the Lord to raise up strong local churches among the Central Thai people throughout Southeast Asia.
Pray for a flourishing disciple making movement among the Central Thai in both Thailand and Myanmar.

LocationInCountry: According to author and researcher Richard Diran, 100,000 or more Danau people live in central areas of Shan State and the northern part of Kayah State in Myanmar.  One of the main centres for the Danau seems to be the town of Pindaya, located about 50 kilometres north of Kalaw and Taungghi.

ProfileText.Summary: An estimated 95 per cent of Danau people adhere to Theravada Buddhism, mixed with spirit worship and occult practices. One of the main centers for the Danau seems to be the town of Pindaya. Pindaya is home to the famous Pindaya limestone caves, overlooking picturesque Boutaloke Lake. 'Inside the cavern there are more than 8,000 Buddha images - made from alabaster, teak, marble, brick, lacquer and cement - which have been put there over the centuries.' The Danau are reportedly fishermen and cotton farmers.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: He has told you, O man, what is good; and what does the LORD require of you but to do justice, and to love kindness, and to walk humbly with your God?
ProfileText.Obstacles: Geographical restrictions coupled with Myanmar's military rule make access to this group quite difficult.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for Christian radio to become available in the language of the Danau people. They speak the language of the same name, and some also speak the Pa 'O language. Pray the Danau will learn of these broadcasts and will listen with understanding.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Some 500 of the Danau are reportedly Christians. Please pray for these folks to not mix Buddhist and animistic beliefs with the purity of the Christian Gospel. They need teachers to help them with an accurate understanding of spiritual matters.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Thank the Lord the Gospel has penetrated this people group to an extent. Pray this will be the beginning of a church planting movement.

LocationInCountry: North Shan State, centered in Nam Hsan.

ProfileText.Summary: In the past the Shwe were great hunters, but today most earn their living by growing tea or bamboo. On the rare occasion of a Shwe Palaung becoming a Christian, the new believer is usually persecuted and driven from the village. Most Palaung are Buddhists. However, they have also maintained their ethnic animist religion which is a system of beliefs based on evil spirits called nats. The Palaung believe that while all of the nats are inherently evil, some are more evil than others. One must spend their life trying to appease the nats.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Enlarge the place of your tent, and let the curtains of your habitations be stretched out; do not hold back; lengthen your cords and strengthen your stakes.
ProfileText.Obstacles: There will be opposition from spiritual forces as the good news of Jesus is presented to the Shwe Palaung. Pray against this, so the people will be free to understand and believe.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for workers to take Gospel recordings (which are available) and other resources to these people. Pray the Lord will help them prepare well for this assignment.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There is only a small handful of Shwe Palaung who follows Jesus Christ. Please pray they will somehow be taught to live victorious lives in the power of God's Spirit. They need teachers to help them, and they need people to pray for them.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Palaung have been tremendously affected by the fighting and bloodshed of the past. They need healing and new spiritual hope.

LocationInCountry: East Shan State, Kentung valley area.
PhotoCredits: Peoples of the Buddhist World, Asia Harvest

LocationInCountry: Mandalay Region, Katha and Pyinoolwin townships; Shan State, Taunggyi district.

ProfileText.Summary: The Palaung are one of Myanmar's most ancient indigenous peoples. They have a 40-plus year history of armed resistance to the government through the Palaung State Liberation Army. Their women are very distinct in their dress, including a bright red skirt, worn like a sarong. Like many others in Myanmar and Thailand who are nominally Buddhist, the Palaung still practice various forms of Animist ritual from their religious past. The most famous such ritual is known as "nat worship." Nats are believed to be the spirits of otherwise inanimate objects.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: I will return again to my place, until they acknowledge their guilt and seek my face, and in their distress earnestly seek me.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Accurately communicating the Gospel of Christ is always a challenge. Foreign words and foreign concepts are difficult to grasp.
ProfileText.HowReach: Oral methods of communicating will be helpful. Stories from Scripture can be told, and Gospel films and recordings will be useful.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the few followers of Jesus among the Silver Palaung, that they will faithfully fellowship together, spurring one another on to love and good deeds. Pray they will be fully delivered from worshiping nature instead of the Creator.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the Lord to multiply the reception and influence of His Word among the Palaung people, leading them to love Him with their whole being. Pray they will establish peace with their government, and be able to raise their families in safety.

LocationInCountry: Kachin State: Bhamo district, Mansi township; Shan State: Lashio area; the road north to the border, Nam Kham and Muse, Mantong, North Hsenwi, and Tawngpeng (the ancient Palaung State).

ProfileText.Summary: The Palaung traditionally have practiced a mixture of Animism and Buddhism. Many associate Buddhism with a pacifistic lifestyle, but the Palaung in Myanmar have a 40-year history of armed resistance through the Palaung State Liberation Army. Some practice nat worship, nats being the spirits of inanimate objects such as rocks, mountains and rivers, as well as the spirits of deceased ancestors.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Myanmar is difficult for missionaries to enter and work freely. Also, the animistic Palaung need the Holy Spirit, not the "nats", to lead them to a knowledge of the Son of God.
ProfileText.HowReach: Gospel radio broadcasts in the language of the Palaung would be very helpful. The Jesus film is available in their language.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Give thanks for the believers among the Palaung, even though they are few. Pray the Lord will give them the Spirit of wisdom and revelation, to know him better.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for God's blessing, strengthening and healing of families and neighborhoods within the Rumai Palaung people through the abundant life Jesus offers to all who call on His name. Pray they will be given a desire to know God's salvation in Jesus, and that the Lord will soon satisfy that desire.

LocationInCountry: They are concentrated throughout Shan State, in north-east Myanmar.  In Thailand, they inhabit the provinces of Chiang Rai, Chiang Mai and Mae Hong Son.  A small group lives on the other side of Thailand in Mukdahan Province.

ProfileText.Summary: The Shan are one of the most prestigious of the Tai groups in Southeast Asia. They are concentrated in Shan state, Myanmar. For a generation, the Shan Independence Army has fought against the Burmese military to gain independence. The Shan call themselves "Tai Yay", meaning Great Tai. The Shan have been firm believers in Theravada Buddhism since it was introduced in Myanmar in the fifth century, AD.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: This is why I left you in Crete, so that you might put what remained into order, and appoint elders in every town as I directed you
ProfileText.Obstacles: To follow Jesus within a strongly Buddhist culture brings the risk of losing much that is important in this life: friends, status, family, and so forth.
ProfileText.HowReach: Much prayer for the Shan people is needed, to prepare the ground for the coming of the good news of Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray the Christians among the Shan will be properly instructed in the faith, and will grow to become zealous disciples firmly established on the truth of Scripture.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray that many of the Shan people will come to love God with their whole being and will walk in His ways. Pray the Shan will live in peace, and will increasingly desire to find a Savior and forgiveness for sin. Pray that Jesus may be known among them.

ProfileText.Summary: Does death scare you? For the Tai Man of Myanmar, death is not a threat. For those who have done good deeds, death is simply passing from one life to another. The Tai Man largely rely on agricultural crops such as rice, tea and soybeans. It is also estimated that 50 percent of the world's opium is grown in the Shan State.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: I wait for the LORD, my soul waits, and in his word I hope;
ProfileText.Obstacles: Ethnic division in Myanmar (formerly called Burma) dates back to the first Burman kingdom of the 11th century. The government of Myanmar continues to persecute ethnic minorities today, including the Tai Man. This situation has created an extremely divided nation and many Tai Man have joined the secessionist Shan State Army in response to the government's abuse. This war-torn environment has made it difficult to share the gospel.
ProfileText.HowReach: The JESUS Film is available in the Shan language. Local churches can host showings of the film to the Buddhist community.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for unity and mercy in Myanmar. 
Pray for the persecution of ethnic minorities to stop. 
Pray for wisdom for the church leaders and that they would rise up to reach out to their Buddhist neighbors and help them to build a network of disciples.
Pray that their many crops would flourish and bring them prosperity.

The Tai Man largely rely on crops such as rice, tea and soybeans. About 50 percent of the world's opium is grown in the Shan State, where many Tai Man live.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Go therefore to the main roads and invite to the wedding feast as many as you find. And those servants went out into the roads and gathered all whom they found, both bad and good. So the wedding hall was filled with guests.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Ethnic division in Myanmar (formerly called Burma) dates back to the first Burman kingdom of the 11th century. This situation has created an extremely divided nation and many Tai Man have joined the secessionist Shan State Army in response to the government's abuse. LocationInCountry: East Shan State, Muang Yong township.

ProfileText.Summary: China is the original homeland of the Tai Lue people (pronounced as Dai in China), but many have migrated south due to pressure from the Chinese. During World War II, when the establishment of a communist regime ended the Tai Lue kingdom, they fled to Burma and Northern Thailand. The Tai Lue have preserved much of their traditional way of life. Most are farmers living in river valleys where they grow wet rice for both consumption and sale. They still use wooden equipment drawn by buffalo. Households are tight knit and generally have a large network of extended family in their village. The Tai Lue people practice Theravada Buddhism mixed with animism. Each village has a temple with novice and head monks, and every family is expected to visit the temple for Buddhist festivals and give to the temple in order to gain merit for their next lives. They put great emphasis on reincarnation.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Beware of false prophets, who come to you in sheeps clothing but inwardly are ravenous wolves. You will recognize them by their fruits. Are grapes gathered from thornbushes, or figs from thistles?
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Tai Lue face great social pressure to continue their Buddhist and animist practices. Those who choose to follow Christ may be forced out of their village or face other kinds of persecution.
ProfileText.HowReach: Because the Tai Lue are oral communicators, an oral approach to sharing the Gospel is important. Several videos and recordings are available in their language.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There may be a few Christians among the Tai Lue of Myanmar. Pray for these, and for others who will soon come to faith. "May God Himself, the God of peace, sanctify them through and through."
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Tai Lue have been tremendously affected by the fighting and bloodshed of the past. They need healing and new spiritual hope.

LocationInCountry: The majority live in the delta regions east of Yangon in the country of Myanmar.  A further large group of Mon dwell on the Thai side of the border.

ProfileText.Summary: One of the earliest peoples to reside in Southeast Asia, the Mon were responsible for the spread of Theravada Buddhism in Indochina, and have been a major source of influence on the culture of Myanmar. They are said to be the first receivers of Theravada missionaries from Sri Lanka. They have a history of struggle with the Burmese, and have been a repressed and defiant group for many years. They have risen in revolt against the central Burmese government on a number of occasions. Most of the Mon are peasant farmers, although a few are merchants and craftsmen. Most Mon are bilingual, speaking Burmese as well as their own language.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: See, I have called by name Bezalel the son of Uri, son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah, and I have filled him with the Spirit of God, with ability and intelligence, with knowledge and all craftsmanship.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Mon have been Buddhist for many generations. Their religion is an important part of their identity.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for a growing missionary force in all of Myanmar, made up of both indigenous believers and outsiders. The need for workers is great.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few Christians among the Mon people, that they will have pastors to shepherd them effectively and biblically.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Lord will give the Buddhist Mon people a strong awareness of their own sin, and the need for forgiveness. Pray at the proper time Jesus will be revealed to them as their potential Savior, the one who offers both forgiveness and hope for life after death.

ProfileText.Summary: The Mon people were the first to receive Buddhism, and they were among those who spread this religion throughout Southeast Asia. They have been a major source of influence on the culture of Myanmar, yet they have a history of struggle with the Burmese. They have risen in revolt against the central Burmese government on a number of occasions. Most of the Mon are family farmers, although a few are merchants and craftsmen. Most Mon are bilingual and speak Burmese as well as their own language.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But the steadfast love of the LORD is from everlasting to everlasting on those who fear him, and his righteousness to childrens children,
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Mon have been Buddhist for many generations. Their religion is an important part of their identity, and there is a lot of community pressure to conform.
ProfileText.HowReach: In Myanmar, there are believers from other tribes who can potentially reach the Mon people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the few Christ followers among the Mon people would have pastors to shepherd them effectively and biblically.

ProfileText.Summary: Tai Laing is more of a language than a people group. This language is spoken by more than 100,000 people in Myanmar. Like other people groups in this region, Tai Laing speakers earn a meager living by farming rice and vegetables. Their meat supply comes from their livestock and by fishing.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Before I formed you in the womb I knew you, and before you were born I consecrated you; I appointed you a prophet to the nations.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Fear is a major obstacle for the Tai Laing people who might otherwise find Christ.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are tribes in Myanmar who have found the Lord. They can be His ambassadors to the Tai Laing people.

Pray for a disciple making movement among this people group to transform their communities in Myanmar.

LocationInCountry: North Rakhine State, Maungdaw and Buthidaung townships; Sittwe and Rathedaung townships.

ProfileText.Summary: The Rohingya are Muslims living in Rakhine state, Myanmar. Some people claim the Rohingya are indigenous to this area while others disagree and say most Rohingya are migrants from Bengal. The name "Rohingya" is a contentious term in Myanmar, with the government claiming the people should be called Bengali. They have been called one of the world's most persecuted minorities, and most have been denied Burmese citizenship and voting rights. Clashes with Burmese Buddhists in 2012 led to some 140,000 Rohingya now living in displacement camps. The turmoil in 2012 resulted in thousands of Rohingya being killed, many homes and mosques burned, and much looting.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: For behold, he who forms the mountains and creates the wind, and declares to man what is his thought, who makes the morning darkness, and treads on the heights of the earth the LORD, the God of hosts, is his name!
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Rohingya are strongly committed to their religion. They are a besieged people and this produces extra commitment to their religion and culture.
ProfileText.HowReach: Christians need to find ways to minister to the Rohingya people, both within Myanmar and in other countries where they reside. Humanitarian help is much needed and will be appreciated.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: It is likely there are no followers of Jesus among the Rohingya at this time, although a few secret believers are possible.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray for just treatment for this downtrodden people group. Pray for a change of heart by the Burmese government which will result in protection for the people and for citizenship to be granted. Pray that Burmese Christians will become advocates for the Rohingya.

LocationInCountry: The large majority inhabits the south-western part of Shan State in Myanmar.  The geographical centre of the Pa-O (Black Karen) could be considered the mountains around the towns of Taunggyi and Kalaw.  An additional 900 Pa-O live inside Thailand, inhabiting four villages within the Muang District of Mae Hong Son Province.

ProfileText.Summary: The Pa-O are called Taungthu by the Burmese, which means 'hill people '. The British colonialists called them Black Karen because most Pa-O women wear black or dark blue dresses. The Pa-O have been a strong Buddhist group for many centuries. Buddhism dominates every area of the lives and communities of the Pa-O, however, they still retain animist beliefs to some extent. Spirit shrines are located outside villages or near pagodas, where offerings can be made. Pa-O villages can often be identified by the magnificent wooden temples that are constructed on the outskirts of their villages. Most Pa-O Buddhists have steadfastly rejected all efforts to evangelize them.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Not like these is he who is the portion of Jacob, for he is the one who formed all things, and Israel is the tribe of his inheritance; the LORD of hosts is his name.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Missionaries translated scripture portions into the Pa-O language in the year 1912, yet there has been little growth of the church since that time. Buddhism and Animism have a strong grip on the people.
ProfileText.HowReach: Spiritual matters are spiritually understood. Please pray the Lord's Spirit will reveal truth in convincing ways to the Pa-O. Jesus is the way, the truth, and the life.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are Christians among the Pa-O. Please pray they will grow in the nurture and admonition of the Lord and will have a wonderful testimony to the goodness of the Lord among their own people.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray for Christian workers to be sent to the Pa-O people in sufficient numbers to really make a difference. Pray especially for workers to be raised up from among the Pa-O, since they will know the language and the culture.

ProfileText.Summary: The Pa-O are called Taungthu, which means "hill people," by the Burmese. The British colonialists called them Black Karen because most Pa-O women wear black or dark blue dresses. LocationInCountry: Widespread in central Myanmar.

ProfileText.Summary: The Burmese are the political, economic and religious leaders of Myanmar, formerly known as Burma. The Burmese have mixed Buddhist beliefs with animistic beliefs. Their animistic beliefs center around inherently evil spirits called nats. The Burmese spend their lives trying to appease the nats. Burmese homes often have altars for the spirits, as well as a statue of Buddha. Farmers may spend more in a year on their religion than on education, health and clothing for their families.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: O LORD, in your strength the king rejoices, and in your salvation how greatly he exults!
ProfileText.Obstacles: Following Christ for the Burmese may be threatening, risking attacks from evil spirits. They need spiritual protection and discernment.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for God's blessing on the leaders in the Burmese people group, along with their families, and for their communities to welcome and enjoy God's provision.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the few followers of Christ among the Burmese, that they would live holy lives, being zealous to grow into the image of Christ. Pray they would be kind and compassionate to one another and to their neighbors, drawing them to the Savior.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for peace tempered by justice in Myanmar and for the Burmese people to hunger to know forgiveness of sin and power for living, found only in the person and work of Christ.
Pray for a Disciple Making Movement among the Burmese this decade.

LocationInCountry: Approximately 150,000 Chaungtha people inhabit central parts of Myanmar....There is a coastal resort town in Myanmar that is also called Chaungtha, but the names are completely coincidental.
PhotoCredits: Peoples of the Buddhist World, Asia Harvest

ProfileText.Summary: The Chaungtha are historically and ethno-linguistically related to the Burmese. Because of this, in recent decades their identity has been eroded as an increasing number of Chaungtha choose to identify themselves as Burmese, hoping to benefit from being aligned with the majority ruling people in Myanmar. The central areas of Myanmar are among the most staunchly Buddhist in the nation. Whereas, generally speaking, the mountainous perimeter of Myanmar is occupied by tribal groups who practice Animism or Christianity, the heart of the nation where the Chaungtha live is overwhelmingly Buddhist. Most of the Chaungtha are Buddhist. However, they have also maintained their traditional ethnic belief in evil spirits, or nats.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Yet even now, declares the LORD, return to me with all your heart, with fasting, with weeping, and with mourning.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The worldview and value system of Buddhism is quite different from that of the Bible, even though there are some similarities. To accept the Biblical view is difficult for the Buddhist steeped in his belief system from birth.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for dedicated prayer warriors who will commit to sustained prayer for all the Buddhist groups of Myanmar.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: A few hundred Christians have been reported among the Chaungtha people. Please pray the Lord will provide teachers to give them proper instruction in how to quickly confess sin and to consistently live in the power of the Lord's Spirit, demonstrating the fruit of the Spirit. Pray they will learn to fellowship together for mutual encouragement and edification.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray the Chaungtha people will be completely set from the influence of evil spirits. Pray they will understand that the God of the Bible has power over all created beings.

LocationInCountry: Approximately 170,000 Intha people live in south-west Shan State of Myanmar....most Intha can be found living in villages surrounding Lake Inle, near Taunggyi.

ProfileText.Summary: The Inthas are an old tribe of Bama living in the midst of the Shan area. They are unique because of their villages built on stilts over the water of Lake Inle and their hydroponic farming based on floating gardens. Leg rowing, floating gardens, and villages on stilts over the water are unique features that have turned this area into a tourist destination. The floating gardens and surrounding area is extensively cultivated and produces a wide variety of vegetables, fruit, and flowers. Fishing and gardening is all done from small, traditional, flat-bottomed, teak boats. The Intha people are staunchly Buddhist. Around and on Inle Lake there are at least 1000 temples, pagodas, stupas, and monasteries. Buddhism pervades every part of Intha life and culture, but it is mixed with traditional animist beliefs. Fear plays a large part in their daily lives.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Then they left the presence of the council, rejoicing that they were counted worthy to suffer dishonor for the name.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The worldview of Buddhism is very different from the worldview of the Bible. Knowing and serving the Creator God may not be seen as a possibility.
ProfileText.HowReach: There is much tourism and outside interaction with this group. Missionary endeavors could begin by serving the needs of the Intha in the marketplace.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for any followers of Jesus who presently are in the Intha community, and pray for the many others who will soon join their numbers. Pray they will be accurately taught the ways of Christ, and will depend fully on him and his death on their behalf.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Intha tribe will soon be completely delivered from fear.

ProfileText.Summary: Centuries ago, the most feared pirates and sailors in the Bay of Bengal terrorized communities along the seacoast and far up the river channels of what is now Bangladesh. They were called maghs, or pirates. They now speak the Arakanese language, and may be known as the Arakanese or Rakhine, from the Arakan region of Myanmar. The people themselves dislike the term "Magh" and prefer to be called Marmas, which means "Burmese."
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And many peoples shall come, and say: Come, let us go up to the mountain of the LORD, to the house of the God of Jacob, that he may teach us his ways and that we may walk in his paths. For out of Zion shall go forth the law, and the word of the LORD from Jerusalem.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The devout, animistic/Buddhist traditions of this people have made them unreceptive to the Gospel in the past.
ProfileText.HowReach: Stories from Scripture may communicate effectively to these people. Trained storytellers, also using the Jesus film and God's Story video, can be equipped and sent.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the few believers among this people, for pastors to teach the Scriptures accurately and faithfully to them. Pray for them to grow in the nurture and admonition of the Lord.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for educational opportunities for the youth, and for employment opportunities for breadwinners.

LocationInCountry: They are primarily located in mountainous valleys of southwest Shan State and southeast Mandalay Division.  The centre of the Taungyo could be said to be the town of Pindaya in Shan State.

ProfileText.Summary: The Taungyo are primarily located in mountainous valleys of southwest Shan State and southeast Mandalay Division. The center of the Taungyo homeland could be said to be the town of Pindaya in Shan State. In many respects the Taungyo do not have a strong sense of self-identity as many other peoples in Myanmar do. They see themselves as linked to the Burmese people, with the main differences being cultural. Almost all Taungyo people believe in Theravada Buddhism. In rural areas they also practise nat (spirit) worship. Often the practitioners of this form of animism walk deep into the forests, where they conduct rituals to call on certain protective spirits. Some spirits are considered benevolent, while others are malevolent.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: You shall serve the LORD your God, and he will bless your bread and your water, and I will take sickness away from among you. None shall miscarry or be barren in your land; I will fulfill the number of your days.
ProfileText.Obstacles: No scripture or other resources are reported to be available in the Taungyo language. However, the people are widely bilingual in the Burmese language, which has scripture and resources.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for good quality Christian radio to be available throughout Myanmar, certainly in the Burmese language but also in the smaller languages.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few followers of Jesus among the Taungyo people, that they will be joyful and obedient disciples of Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray the Taungyo people will be completely set free from superstition and the control of evil spiritual powers.

ProfileText.Summary: Centered in the township of Pinlon, the Taungyo people live primarily in Myanmar's southern Shan State. Ethnically, they are a sub-group of the majority Burmese (or, Bamar) people although their dialect of Burmese is non-standard. The Taungyo maintain themselves as a unique people group, though they still live intermingled with other ethnicities. One way to pick out the Taungyo is by the distinctive apparel of the women  lots of silver on their jewelry and heavy brass rings on their legs that are used to signify their marital status. The Taungyo are fishermen and agriculturalists.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But when Jesus saw it, he was indignant and said to them, Let the children come to me; do not hinder them, for to such belongs the kingdom of God. Truly, I say to you, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a child shall not enter it.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Though some outreach is being performed by local evangelists and missionaries from other people groups, the Taungyo are almost entirely Buddhist. Buddhism centers around the pursuit of perfection, achieved over lifetimes of effort. It will be difficult for them to accept the idea that they need a sin-free Savior, who alone is perfect.
ProfileText.HowReach: Though the Taungyo people may not be drawn by printed material, audio and video materials might be very effective.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray that they would be open to receiving the good news of Jesus  the One who became sin that we might become the very righteousness of God. 
Pray for a mass awakening among the Taungyo and deep movements of discipleship as they pursue God's true righteousness and holiness.
Pray for dreams and visions that will allow Jesus to make himself known.

LocationInCountry: They inhabit a long coastal stretch of the Tanintharyi Division in southern Myanmar.  The Tavoyan inhabit the northern part of the state, centred around their ancient homeland of Dawei City.  A small number of Tavoyan people have made their way across the border and now live in refugee camps inside Thailand.

ProfileText.Summary: More than 400,000 Tavoyan people inhabit a long coastal stretch of the Tanintharyi Division in southern Myanmar. A small number of Tavoyan have made their way across the border and now live in refugee camps inside Thailand. They fled to Thailand to escape oppression at the hands of the Burmese authorities who conscripted many to work on a new railroad under inhumane conditions. For centuries the Tavoyan people have been a peace loving and gentle people. Their language is viewed as a "nonstandard Burmese with profound pronunciation and vocabulary differences from Burmese", by the Ethnologue. Missionaries working in their region for decades have found the Buddhist Tavoyans slow to respond to the gospel.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And Moses quickly bowed his head toward the earth and worshiped. And he said, If now I have found favor in your sight, O Lord, please let the Lord go in the midst of us, for it is a stiff-necked people, and pardon our iniquity and our sin, and take us for your inheritance.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Tavoyan have proven to be disinterested in the gospel in the past.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray the youth in this people group will find good quality Christian resources (videos, music, websites, etc.) as they search the media. Pray they will be given understanding as they are drawn to these resources.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few followers of Jesus today among the Tavoyan people, that they will be joyful always, praying continually, giving thanks in all circumstances.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray for continuing peaceful relations between the Tavoyan people and Burmese authorities.

ProfileText.Summary: The Illanon are a small Filipino Muslim group of sea-based people living on the coast of Sabah province. Most of the Illanon are engaged in fishing, while the rest raise food crops along with Muslim and non-Muslim neighbors. The Illanon are Muslim, but also believe in spirits and are in constant fear of them. Thus, there are many animistic rituals that they observe in addition to Islam.

ProfileText.Obstacles: The Illanon have resisted every effort to introduce Christianity to them. Their attitude towards Christianity is marked by indifference.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for Christians in other Filipino tribes to have a heart to share Christ with the Muslim Illanon Filipino community.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There has been one group trying to reach the Ilanun for a long time but with very minimal results. Pray that God will make their efforts fruitful.

ProfileText.Summary: The Kalagans are the Islamized-indigenous people in the Western Davao gulf area. They are primarily farmers, raising rice, corn, abaca, and coconut. Their lifestyle and culture are very similar to that of the Magindanaw. They have a fairly elaborate social structure with different rankings given to families. They are Muslim, yet incorporate some animistic beliefs and practices into their religion. Muslim religious leaders and teachers (imams and panditas) direct religious life and teach young boys to read and memorize the Koran. Muslim holidays and other observances are celebrated to varying degrees.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Other seeds fell on good soil and produced grain, some a hundredfold, some sixty, some thirty.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Islam teaches that Jesus was a prophet, a good man, but not deity, the Son of God. This teaching stands as a major barrier to the advance of the Gospel in Muslim lands.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray that Christian workers will be able to show the Jesus film to many of the Kalagan people, and will also be able to distribute scripture portions to the people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There is an indication there are several Catholic Christians among the Kalagan people. Please pray these Christians will be accurately taught the ways of Christ and will live in obedience to him.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray for all the Muslim groups in the Philippines to live peacefully with their non-Muslim neighbors. Pray for the government to know how to deal effectively with unrest in Muslim areas.

ProfileText.Summary: Traditional Magindanao settlements were located near waterways. This allowed ease of transportation and communication by boat. Several of the major trading centers were also seats of political power, while other settlements along or near the waterways were controlled by local chiefs. This traditional pattern of settlement has been slowly altered by the building of roads that do not follow the natural course of the waterways. Large towns have sprung up along these highways, becoming new centers of commerce. Today, the Magindanao still produce nearly all of their own food.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge; fools despise wisdom and instruction.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Muslim religious leaders and teachers preside over religious life. They teach young schoolboys to read and memorize the Koran. It is very difficult for them to accept the teachings of another holy book, especially when it comes from the Catholic Filipinos, whom many Muslims view as enemies.
ProfileText.HowReach: Some Christian radio and television broadcasts are available for the Magindanao, but there have been very few responses to them.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for God to encourage, strengthen, and protect and the small number of Magindanao believers.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Ask the Lord to raise up a strong local church among the Magindanao that will be a blessing to all Muslims in Mindanao.
Ask the Holy Spirit to prepare the hearts of the Magindanao people for the gospel. 
Ask the Holy Spirit to give mission agencies creative ideas with which to reach the Muslim Magindanao.

ProfileText.Summary: Maranao is the term used for the people of Lanao, a predominantly Muslim region on the island of Mindanao. They are famous for their artwork, sophisticated weaving, wood and metal craft, and their epic literature. The word Maranao means "people of the lake." Small communities of Maranaos, mostly traders, can be found in all major towns of the Philippines. They are the descendants of Muslim Malays. They are fair-skinned, probably attributable to Arab and Chinese admixtures. The native Maranao have a fascinating culture that revolves around kulintang music, a specific type of gong music.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Blessed is the man who trusts in the LORD, whose trust is the LORD.
ProfileText.Obstacles: To follow Jesus within this Muslim community is to invite criticism and ostracism, and may cause the loss of friendships.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps the Christians among the Maranao people will grow in maturity and in numbers to the extent they will be able to effectively carry the Gospel of Christ to their own people. Pray for a church planting movement.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for Maranao believers to become effective and fruitful in sowing God's Word among their own families and friends to fuel a movement of God's blessings spreading from household to household. There are some among the Maranao community who know and follow Jesus Christ. Pray for them to be zealous as they learn the ways of Christ. Pray they will be united around the truth of Scripture, and be faithful witnesses for Christ among family and friends.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Maranao community will increasingly be drawn to Jesus (whom Muslims call Isa al-Masih) as they read the Koran. Pray for curiosity about this Man. Pray the Lord will reveal himself to them.

ProfileText.Summary: The Tausug are the most dominant of the Muslim groups in the southern Philippines. The name Tausug means "people of the sea current." They make their living through fishing and agriculture. Their major cash crops are coconuts, coffee and fruit. The ideal marriage among the Tausug is still one arranged by the parents, although now young people may select their own mates. First and second cousins are favored as spouses.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: He answered, Whether he is a sinner I do not know. One thing I do know, that though I was blind, now I see.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Tausug are staunch Muslims. Children study the Koran and, when ready, recite the scriptures in a public ceremony. The Tausug showed great determination in their fight for independence from Filipino control. Conflicts between them and cultural Christians left deep wounds. There is a need for sensitive Christian workers to minister Jesus love to the emotionally scarred people.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Tausug believe that after death a person goes to hell, although eventually he or she can reach heaven. Christian workers can share assurance of immediate presence in heaven.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Ask Jesus, the Prince of Peace, to heal the wounded hearts of these people. Ask the Holy Spirit to grant wisdom and favor to mission agencies focusing on the Tausug people. Pray that God would use Tausug believers as bold witnesses to their own people leading to an unstoppable church planting movement.

ProfileText.Summary: The name Subanon means "river people". As the name implies, these people originally lived along riverbanks in the lowlands; however due to disturbances from others such as the Muslims, these peace-loving people are now found residing in the mountains. They do not practice division of labor based on gender. Men and women work in the fields together, and men can cook and care for the children when necessary. Subanons have little social stratification. The tribe is said to have no religion, yet they believe in a supreme being they call "Diwata Migbebaya".
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Whom have I in heaven but you? And there is nothing on earth that I desire besides you. My flesh and my heart may fail, but God is the strength of my heart and my portion forever.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Gospel needs to come to the Tuboy Subanen in ways they understand, probably orally as well as in print.
ProfileText.HowReach: Other Subanen tribes have substantial numbers of Christians. Pray some of these will be prompted to take the Gospel to their Tuboy cousins, even though the language may be somewhat different than their own.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There may be a few followers of Jesus among the Tuboy Subanen. Please pray they will live holy lives and learn to live in the power of God's Sprit. They need teachers to teach them how.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray these poor people will be able to care adequately for their families. Pray they will have good crops, and will be able to find employment as well.

ProfileText.Summary: Yakan people are probably the original inhabitants of Basilan, an island just off the southwestern point of Mindanao. They make up less than half of Basilan's population.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Every day I will bless you and praise your name forever and ever.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Yakan people are primarily farmers using plows drawn by water buffaloes to cultivate the soil. Sadly, few people grow enough rice to last from season to season. As Muslims, the Yakan are allowed to have as many as four wives. Divorce is common, initiated by either the man or the woman. Yakan people have incorporated many of their traditional animistic beliefs (belief that non-living objects have spirits) into their Islamic rituals. They believe in evil spirits that sometimes attack people, so they live in fear.
ProfileText.HowReach: The nuclear family, which consists of the husband, his wife, and their unmarried children, is the most common domestic unit. Perhaps they would respond to Christian families of disciples who could earn their trust and reach out to them with the truth of the gospel. The New Testament has been translated into Yakan, their spoken language. The JESUS Film, and audio resources are also available.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Ask the Lord to bring forth vigorous Yakan churches that will plant others for the glory of his name!
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Ask almighty God to raise up a church planting movement this decade.

ProfileText.Summary: The Madurese Bawean people come from Indonesia in search of a better life in prosperous Singapore. Those who live and work in Singapore send money back to relatives in Indonesia who struggle economically.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: That according to the riches of his glory he may grant you to be strengthened with power through his Spirit in your inner being, so that Christ may dwell in your hearts through faiththat you, being rooted and grounded in love,
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Madurese Bawean are Sunni Muslim. Because their goal is to earn enough to support family in Indonesia, they probably work long hours. This would prevent them from having time to develop meaningful relationships with local believers.
ProfileText.HowReach: Christian families who hire the Bawean as domestic help can share the gospel with them, especially in their times of loneliness and homesickness. These difficulties can soften their hearts to the love and warmth that Christians show them. Christian employers can also share gospel materials with them.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the Bawean who work in Singapore to make authentic Christian friends who will share their lives and the message of Christ. Pray God would raise up disciples among those who work in Singapore through strong believers. Pray they would return to their island home with the gospel. Pray for the Baweans to become Bereans who study and apply Gods word and share it with others.

ProfileText.Summary: Have you ever heard of the Bugi man? This came from the days when the Bugi people (aka, Buginese) were pirates, and they were greatly feared throughout what is now Indonesia. Today the Bugis are dynamic, highly mobile people, considered to be the dominant people group in South Sulawesi, and island in Indonesia. The most fortunate of them have managed to relocate to beautiful Singapore to make their fortune.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: For my thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways my ways, declares the LORD. For as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways and my thoughts than your thoughts.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Bugis are well known for their fervent adherence to Sunni Islam. However, many of them are still bound to their traditional system of animistic beliefs (panngaderreng). To reach the Buginese for Christ, one would have to overcome the strongholds of Islam and animism. They would also have to overcome the pride of this people group that is used to high status and wealth.
ProfileText.HowReach: The Buginese people need the humility and teachability to allow Jesus Christ to enter their lives. There are many believers in Singapore, and many mission agencies that can reach them. They only need to listen and open their hearts
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the few believers among the Bugi people in Singapore will exhibit the kindness and humility that will draw their Muslim neighbors and family members to the Savior.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Ask the Lord of the harvest to send out more workers into his harvest field among the Buginese in Singapore.
Pray that the eyes of the Bugis will be opened to see Jesus Christ as Lord and Savior.
Pray that many Bugis households will turn from strongholds of Islam to freedom in Christ.
Pray for a fast-moving disciple-making movement among the Bugi people in Singapore and Indonesia.

ProfileText.Summary:
The Sindhi people are an ethnic group native to the former Sindh province of the British colony of "India" which also included modern day Bangladesh and Pakistan. Today Sindh is one of the provinces of Pakistan. Most Sindhi peoples were originally Hindus or Buddhists, but the arrival of Muslim Arabs in the 7th century deeply influenced Sindhi religion and culture. Following the partition of India in 1947, most Hindu Sindhis migrated to India, leaving Sunni Muslims to dominate the Sindh province of Pakistan.

Though many went to India, a fair number have gone all over the world, usually as businessmen. The more fortunate Sindhis were able to go to Singapore, a nation that thrives on business.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Let the wicked forsake his way, and the unrighteous man his thoughts; let him return to the LORD, that he may have compassion on him, and to our God, for he will abundantly pardon.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Hindu Sindhis in Singapore are pragmatic in their approach to the supernatural. They hope the gods or supernatural powers will grant them wealth and favor. The God they need to find is not here to help them gain wealth, but instead, an abundant, transformed life. Few Sindhis in Singapore are seeking this.
ProfileText.HowReach: People with pastoral skills can befriend the Sindhis and show them the way to Jesus after they have lost hope in mammon.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are no Sindhi believers in Singapore, so pray for the Holy Spirit to penetrate their hearts.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray that Sindhis would discover that following Christ is more satisfying than storing up riches on earth.
Pray that Hindu-background believers would go to the Sindhi people and live godly lives among them. 
Pray for lasting fruit to come from efforts to reach Sindhi families around the world.
Pray for a church planting movement among Sindhis to begin in Singapore.

ProfileText.Summary: The majority of Indian migrant workers living in Singapore come from Tamil Nadu villages in southern India. These Indian migrant workers are scattered throughout Singapore in approximately three hundred work sites. Many workers are educated and literate, while others are illiterate. Life in Singapore is tough for migrant workers. They generally work six to seven days a week. Some migrant workers live in well-built flats, but a majority are poorly housed and live in small shacks or containers. Migrant workers can be exploited by their employers who take advantage of loopholes in the legal system. Due to hard work, pressure, loan repayment, new-found freedom, or loneliness, many migrant workers resort to alcoholism, prostitution, and gambling.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Let us then with confidence draw near to the throne of grace, that we may receive mercy and find grace to help in time of need.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Nominal Christians in Singapore do not provide a good example to the Tamil of what being a Christian is supposed to mean.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are many evangelical Christians in Singapore. Perhaps the Lord will show some their opportunity and responsibility to minister to Tamil speakers. They need friendship as well as spiritual assistance.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are some Christians among the Tamil of Singapore. Pray they will find good churches in which to fellowship, and will grow in their love for Christ and in obedience to him.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for Tamil workers to not be exploited by their employers. Pray for improved working conditions, also.

ProfileText.Summary: The Pattani Malay form an ethnic community in the rich southern provinces of Thailand. The Pattani, a devout Muslim people, are the descendants of Malaysian Muslims. Due to their dedication to the Islamic faith, the Pattani have a distinct identity in Thailand. They live in a place that is like a cultural ecotone between the Muslim Malay cultures to the south and the Buddhist Thai cultures to the north. Over the years, their unique Muslim culture has led to many separatist movements against the Thai government. Because the Pattani Province is located a great distance from the center of the Thai government, the Pattani have developed a feeling of uniqueness and independence. However, each time the government tries to centralize control in the state, Pattani Malay independence is threatened. This has resulted in a resentment towards the government. Most Pattani Malays are self-employed either as farmers or fishermen.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: By me kings reign, and rulers decree what is just; by me princes rule, and nobles, all who govern justly.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Islam teaches that one is saved through obeying the law. There is no room for a holy savior in Islam. Often Muslims hear negative things about Christian beliefs before they have a chance to hear from a Christian.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are churches in Thailand that can potentially reach the Pattany Malay people with church planting efforts. OneHope works to get Scriptures to children in all parts of Thailand, including Pattani Province.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are a few reported followers of Christ among the Pattani Malay, so pray they well be strengthened in the faith. Pray that many will soon accept the blessings of Christ for their families.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for God's peace in southern Thailand. 
Pray that the Holy Spirit will reveal Christ to Pattani Malay leaders. 
Pray that God the Son, Jesus Christ, will come to Pattani Malay leaders in dreams. 
Ask the Lord to raise up persons of peace among the Pattani Malay who will receive the gospel and pass it to many others.

Pray that God the Son, Jesus Christ, would come to Pattani Malay leaders in dreams. Ask the Lord to raise up persons of peace among the Pattani Malay who will receive the gospel and disciple others.

LocationInCountry: Central, centered in Bangkok. Khorat in Ratchasima

ProfileText.Summary: Thailand, which literally means "land of the free," is one of the most cohesive and integrated societies in Southeast Asia. The Thai people have a reputation for being easy-going, courteous, and hospitable. Wet-rice agriculture dominates the Thai economy, with about 50% of Thailand's population living in rural agricultural communities. Buddhism is a central and unifying force in Thai society. The Thai regularly make merit by giving gifts to the temple, attending festivals, and having their sons ordained. In Thailand, Buddhism is a syncretic religion: it incorporates a mixture of pre-Buddhist Hindu beliefs and practices, interwoven with animism and Theravada Buddhist philosophy and rituals. Signs of the religious tradition are everywhere in Bangkok and throughout the country.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Yet I will rejoice in the LORD; I will take joy in the God of my salvation.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Buddhism and Hinduism present a very different worldview than does the Christian Bible. To change one's worldview is very difficult.
ProfileText.HowReach: Much prayer is needed for the Thai people, that the Lord will increasingly give them understanding of who he is and how they can establish a relationship with him. Understanding is needed, and faith is needed. Pray for prayer warriors to uphold the Thai before God's throne.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the Thai who presently know Jesus Christ as Savior and Lord. Pray they will clothe themselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, and patience, and live holy lives.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for peace in Thailand, and also for a growing awareness by the Buddhist Thai of their need for a Savior from sin.

ProfileText.Summary: The large Northern Thai community dominates north and northwest Thailand, being centered around the city of Chiang Mai. They have followed Buddhism for 1,000 years. Like other Theravada Buddhists, they today mix their beliefs with numerous animistic rituals. Protestant missionaries have worked in northern Thailand for about 150 years, but response from the Northern Thai has been painstakingly slow.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: As soon as Solomon finished his prayer, fire came down from heaven and consumed the burnt offering and the sacrifices, and the glory of the LORD filled the temple. And the priests could not enter the house of the LORD, because the glory of the LORD filled the LORDs house.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The belief system of the Thai people doesn't emphasize the reality of sin, and the need for forgiveness. They may not know they need a Savior.
ProfileText.HowReach: Much sustained prayer is needed to cause the Thai to become aware of their spiritual need. May the Lord open the eyes of the Thai.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are some followers of Christ among the Northern Thai. Pray they will not mix Buddhist or animistic beliefs with the pure Gospel of Jesus Christ. Pray for strong commitment to Christ, and for holy living.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for Thai families to be drawn to Jesus and to the Bible to find out more about this man, Jesus. Pray the Thai will increasingly desire a solution for their sin problem. Pray they will desire a Savior, someone who can provide forgiveness for sin and power to live this life victoriously.
