ProfileText.Summary: The Southern Thai Islam people live in a cultural ecotone where Islam and Malay cultures are to their south, and Thai languages and Buddhism are to their north. Southern Thai Islam people speak a Thai language, but they are Muslims like their Malay neighbors to the south. They are in a way, torn between two worlds. Unfortunately, they have not had the chance to turn their hearts to Jesus Christ and make Him the center of their identity.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But I do not account my life of any value nor as precious to myself, if only I may finish my course and the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus, to testify to the gospel of the grace of God.
ProfileText.Obstacles: There are no known believers among the Southern Thai Islam people, so if they are going to hear the gospel, it will have to come from someone outside their community.
ProfileText.HowReach: There is a Christian couple in southern Thailand that is trying to share their faith with both Buddhists and Muslims. Pray that they will be used of the Lord to plant churches among Southern Thai speaking Muslims that will lead to more church planting.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are no known believers among the Southern Thai Islam community, so pray for this to soon change.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for a spiritual hunger to come to Southern Thai Muslim leaders that will lead them to find out about Jesus Christ and open the doors for others to do the same.
Pray for a movement of God's blessing to flow through Southern Thai Muslim families discussing and applying God's Word.
Pray for the Name of Jesus to be known by people in every Southern Thai village.

LocationInCountry: Nan and Phayao provinces; scattered in north.

The majority live in east-central Thailand in the four provinces of Surin, Sisaket, Buriram, and Ubon Ratchathani. Over 50,000 Kui inhabit more than 70 villages in neighboring parts of southern Laos, while another 20,000 make their homes in north-east Cambodia.

ProfileText.Summary: In appearance the Kui do not differ from the Cambodian Khmers. They have their own language, unwritten until recently. Most Kui people also speak Khmer and in some places they are losing their own language. The Kui have an oral culture with high illiteracy. They typically wear Western type clothing, though women often wear a sarong. Their beliefs are a mixture of animist and folk Buddhist ideas with animism being the older and more dominant belief structure. Many wear strings tied around the neck, waist, or wrists to ward off evil spirits. They mostly rely on traditional healers in the case of illness. Many have never heard of Jesus and few have had the opportunity to hear the Gospel presented in a way that makes sense to them.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Blessed is the man who trusts in the LORD, whose trust is the LORD.
ProfileText.Obstacles: A potential obstacle is that the Gospel may come to them only in written form. Since they are an oral society, it needs to come in both oral and written forms.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps committed Christian believers in other tribes in Thailand will be prompted by God's Spirit to take the good news of Jesus to the Kui people. Pray they will prepare well for this opportunity.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the few people in this tribe who identify themselves as Christians. They need prayer support, living in a Buddhist and animistic environment.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Kui have little access to good health care. They could really benefit from health and hygiene education, better access to clean water, and improved agricultural methods.

ProfileText.Summary: Islam among the Central Thai is highly influenced by Sufism, a mystical, emotional form of Islam. There are many mosques in Thailand with the largest number in Pattani Province. There are many Islamic schools and banks. A person called Chularatchamontri has the authority to rule in Islamic matters. Ethnic Thai Muslims live in central Thailand. Most of them speak Thai, and they sometimes intermarry with other communities. Some of the Central Thai Muslims are recent converts to Islam.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The end of the matter; all has been heard. Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the whole duty of man.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Islam has traditionally offered many incentives to stay in the fold, and strong punishments for those who leave. Muslims are taught that the Koran is the precise teachings of Allah, and that by contrast, the Bible has been changed.
ProfileText.HowReach: Since there is freedom of religion in Thailand, believers can have regular time with Central Thai Muslims comparing the Koran with the Bible. This can be the beginning of people learning the truth about Jesus Christ, so they can follow Him. Those who go to Central Thai Muslims will need to make a special effort to win their leaders to Jesus Christ which would open many doors to the rest of them turning to Him.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that soon there will be Muslims in Thailand who put their faith in Christ, learn His ways, and disciple many others.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray that Muslim leaders in Thailand will come to Jesus Christ and lead others to enjoy His blessings as well.
Pray that the Muslims in Thailand will have many chances to hear about Christ, and that they will be ready to give Him an honest hearing.

LocationInCountry: Surin, Buriram, Chanthaburi, Sisaket, and Ubon Ratchathani provinces.

ProfileText.Summary: The Northern Khmer are mostly found in the lower northeast of Thailand, in the provinces of Buriram, Surin, and Sisaket, which border Cambodia. They have lived in this area even longer than the Thai. In Thailand, many Khmer are migrant laborers, especially in the dry season, and can be found on construction sites in Bangkok and in fruit and sugarcane plantations. They dress much like the Thai, but with distinctive colors and patterns in their sarongs. Outwardly they are followers of the Thai national religion of Theravada Buddhism, with a strong admixture of spirit-worship and divination. The Khmer are known (and sometimes feared) within Thailand for their powers of witchcraft and sorcery.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: If any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask God, who gives generously to all without reproach, and it will be given him.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Spiritual opposition can be expected when Jesus is presented to people from a Buddhist/Animist background.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are many evangelical Christians in Thailand. Pray that some will be led by the Lord's Spirit to help disciple the Khmer who already know and follow Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the Khmer who know and follow Jesus. Pray they will live holy lives, zealous to know and follow their Lord.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray the Khmer will be completely set free from the powers of darkness, and will be brought into the Savior's marvelous light.

ProfileText.Summary: Ancestors of the Sinhalese people migrated from India to the island of Sri Lanka as early as the 6th century B.C. where they were known as Singhalese. The Singhalese King, court, and people converted to Indian Buddhism in the 2nd century B.C. The Sinhalese are now the dominant ethnic group in Sri Lanka. The majority of Sinhalese people live in Sri Lanka, but others have moved outside the country to earn a living. Among the Sinhalese diaspora are those who now live in Thailand, though most go to other countries. Few return to Sri Lanka.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: You will seek me and find me, when you seek me with all your heart.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Buddhism is a central part of the Sinhalese identity. Their families and friends do not take it well if someone wants to find out about the ways of Jesus. They see this as a threat to their community.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are many Christian materials online that Sinhalese speakers can download from their computers.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that Sinhalese believers will demonstrate the power and the fruit of the Holy Spirit in their daily lives so their neighbors will be drawn to Jesus.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Ask the Lord of the harvest to send missionaries who can witness to the Sinhalese people in Thailand in culturally relevant ways.
Ask the Lord to soften the hearts of the Sinhalese so they will be receptive to the gospel. 
Pray that God will use the few Sinhalese believers to share the love of Christ with their own people in Sri Lanka and in Thailand.
Pray for a strong church to emerge among the Sinhalese that will be defined by discipleship and obedience to the ways of Jesus.

ProfileText.Summary: Dirty, dangerous and difficult. These adjectives reflect the work of Burmese refugees who live in Thailand. These people have fled their own country in search of work, education and peace. Unfortunately, they rarely obtain legal status in Thailand and consequently they are often subject to violence, low wages and discrimination in the workplace. Muslim refugees have fled from Myanmar because of religious persecution, yet they cannot receive work permits in Thailand.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: For I know that the LORD is great, and that our Lord is above all gods.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Burmese embrace Buddhism, the goal of which is to seek Nirvana, or ultimate peace. This peace eludes them, as their circumstances in Thailand are fraught with poverty and adversityboth political and social.
ProfileText.HowReach: Nearly half of the migrants are women and are particularly susceptible to gender discrimination and violence. Outreach ministries can put extra efforts into reaching these women. In this way, believers can live out James 1:27 "Religion that is pure and undefiled before God the Father is this: to visit orphans and widows in their affliction."
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Burmese have left their homeland in pursuit of economic stability. Sadly, they are not finding it. Pray that the Lord Jesus would give them the kind of stability that lasts foreverpeace and assurance of a bright future. Pray for a movement to Christ.

LocationInCountry: Binh Thuan, Dong Nai, and Ninh Thuan provinces: Ho Chi Minh City.

ProfileText.Summary: The Eastern Cham is one of the most ancient ethnic groups in Southeast Asia. They live in the provinces along the coastline of southern Vietnam, and their villages are spread out in the coastal and Mekong Delta provinces. As a small minority group now overrun with poverty and persecution, one must remember that the Eastern Cham kingdom once reigned in Southeast Asia. The Cham are descendants from what was known as the Champa kingdom, which was located in Vietnam, areas of Cambodia, and southern Laos. The Eastern Cham are a mixture of Hindus and Muslims, but they are also highly influenced by traditional ancestor worship and animism.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: He entered once for all into the holy places, not by means of the blood of goats and calves but by means of his own blood, thus securing an eternal redemption.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Their religious beliefs contribute to their history and identity as a people group. This makes it difficult for Cham individuals to embrace Christianity, as doing so would result in expulsion from the community.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps Christians in other Vietnamese tribes will be led by the Lord's Spirit to the Eastern Cham, to tell them about Christ. Pray they will be able to overcome any tribal hostilities, and be able to travel to the areas where the Cham live.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are a number of individuals in this tribe who identify themselves as Christians. Pray they will grow in knowledge of what it means to live as a follower of Christ. Pray also they will be able to live as faithful followers of Christ, yet be able to stay in their culture.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: The Cham are still considered to be a minority in Vietnam and are looked down upon. Because of this discrimination, the Eastern Cham people have very low self-esteem and self-worth as individuals and as a people group. Yet, they have pride in their heritage, as they vehemently point out to people who visit their villages that they are Eastern Cham, not Vietnamese.

ProfileText.Summary: The Iu Mien originated in China, but some were hired to help the French, and later the Americans, in their efforts to defeat the communists in Laos and Vietnam. After the communists took over Vietnam in 1975, many fled to the Thailand, while others remained in Vietnam's northern regions.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The grass withers, the flower fades, but the word of our God will stand forever.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Unlike the animistic peoples of this region, the Iu Mien have blended their beliefs with Taoism, which is a much stronger hurdle for those who want to share Christ.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are Iu Mien believers in other parts of the world who can take the ways of Jesus to these people who are struggling to maintain their culture in Thailand.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch:
Pray that the Iu Mien believers will take it upon themselves to establish disciple making movements among the Iu Mien people in Vietnam.
Pray for Iu Mien believers to stand firm on the solid rock of Christ and not settle for traditional religion or secularism.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Ask the Lord of the harvest to send forth laborers to live and work among the Iu Mien. 
Ask the Holy Spirit to grant wisdom and favor to mission agencies that are focusing on them. 
Ask the Holy Spirit to complete the work begun in the hearts of the Iu Mien believers through adequate discipleship.

LocationInCountry: Gia Lai, Kon Tum, and Binh Dinh provinces; some in Dak Lak province.
Quang Nam, Thua Thien-Hue, and Da Nang provinces.

ProfileText.Summary: The Katu live in long rectangular houses in the forests, with each home containing two to eight families. They tend towards monogamous families, but rich men and village leaders are allowed to have two or more wives. Shamans (spirit priests) are active among the Katu. They must be paid with chickens or silver for their services. Weddings are very costly for the groom and his family. They are required to pay a dowry worth the equivalent of 15 buffaloes. If they are unable to pay, the groom must live with his wife's family after marriage and work the debt off.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Some trust in chariots and some in horses, but we trust in the name of the LORD our God.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The literacy rate of the Katu in their language is given by the Ethnologue as below 1%. However, many people speak Vietnamese, and their literacy rate in Vietnamese is given as 5-15%.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for a growing missionary movement among the indigenous Christians in Vietnam. Pray this movement will not overlook the Katu people.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are reports of some Christians among the Katu, even though few in number. Pray these Christians will grow strong in the nurture and admonition of the Lord, and will be able to impact all of their tribe for Christ. Since so many are illiterate they need to be discipled using oral means.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray for rising literacy rates and educational level for this people group. Pray for the availability of good quality schools, and for parents to understand the importance of a good education for their children.

LocationInCountry: Hau Giang, Tra Vinh, Vinh Long, Kien Giang, An Giang, Bac Lieu, Ca Mau, Bin Duong, Can Tho, Dong Thap, Long An, Soc Trang, Bin Phuoc, and Tay Ninh provinces; Ho Chi Minh City.

LocationInCountry: Bac Giang, Ha Giang, Lao Cai, Quang Ninh, Tuyen Quang, and Yen Bai provinces.

ProfileText.Summary: The Kim Mun believe that when bad people die they go to a terrible place, their perception of hell - a thick, dark forest with no villages or clearings. It is believed that good people will go to one of several levels of heaven, depending on how much care their eldest son gives the spirit of his dead parent. The Kim Mun worship their ancestors by sacrificing pigs three times each year to honor them.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Now my eyes will be open and my ears attentive to the prayer that is made in this place.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Scripture is not available in the language of the Kim Mun, although Gospel recordings are available. Pray for workers.
ProfileText.HowReach: Some of the more heavily Christianized groups in Vietnam, such as the Roglai, may be able to take the Gospel message to the Kim Mun. Pray for rapidly expanding movements of the Gospel message.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are a few believers among the Kim Mun. Pray they will become well grounded in the faith, sure of their relationship with Christ, growing in righteousness.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for Kim Mun families and neighborhoods to discover and embrace the free gift of life found by trusting Christ and his finished work. Pray these animistic people will increasingly hunger to know forgiveness for their sins.

ProfileText.Summary: "My daughter is a 72-ounce silver girl, not a 12-ounce one!" According to tradition, a Kim Mun young man has to pay a price in silver to his bride's parents to obtain her release. A young woman's price was based on her beauty and health. Another unusual Kim Mun custom was that a girl would bite the arm of her boyfriend to show her interest in him. The Kim Mun are an indigenous people who live in villages in forested areas of Vietnam near the Chinese border. Almost all Kim Mun practice folk religion and veneration of their ancestors.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: May our granaries be full, providing all kinds of produce; may our sheep bring forth thousands and ten thousands in our fields;
ProfileText.Obstacles: No written Scripture is currently available for the Kim Mun's language.
ProfileText.HowReach: Vietnamese tribal believers can take the gospel to the Kim Mun.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the Kim Mun believers would be established in the faith and share the good news of Jesus with their families and friends until there is a powerful movement to Christ among them.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for the Lord's abundant spiritual and physical blessings for the Kum Mun people of Vietnam.
Pray that the Bible would soon be translated into the Kim Mun languages.
Pray the Lord would bring whole families and villages into the kingdom of God.

LocationInCountry: Widespread.

LocationInCountry: Binh Thuan, Dak Nong, Dong Nai, Lam Dong and Ninh Thuan provinces.
San Chay mainly in Tuyen Quang, Lang Son, Bac Kan, and Thai Nguyen provinces; scattered in Yen Bai, Vinh Phuc, Phu Tho, Bac Giang, and Quang Ninh provinces.
Mostly north central mountains, Hoa Binh, Thanh Hoa, Phu Tho, Ha Noi, Yen Bai, Son La, and Ninh Binh provinces.

ProfileText.Summary: Until the revolution in 1945, Muong social organization was aristocratic, and a headman had absolute authority in his jurisdiction. Since the revolution, the Muong community has undergone enormous changes. Their nation has been transformed from a feudalistic society into a socialistic society. The Muong practice their traditional ethnic religion, worshiping ancestral spirits and other supernatural deities.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The king answered and said to Daniel, Truly, your God is God of gods and Lord of kings, and a revealer of mysteries, for you have been able to reveal this mystery.
ProfileText.Obstacles: There has been little missionary work among the Muong, even though they are a large people group.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray for the Muong people to be delivered from fear of "Christendom" and to embrace God's blessing through his Word for their families and communities.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray the few believers among the Muong will be united around the truth of Scripture, and will lead holy lives, zealous to know and serve Jesus Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Muong community will increasingly hunger to know the creator God. Pray also they will be able to live peacefully and safely.

ProfileText.Summary: Until northern Vietnams communist revolution in 1945, Muong social organization was aristocratic, and a headman had absolute authority in his jurisdiction. Since that time, the Muong community has undergone enormous changes. Their nation has been transformed from a feudalistic society into a socialistic one.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The one who conquers will be clothed thus in white garments, and I will never blot his name out of the book of life. I will confess his name before my Father and before his angels.
ProfileText.Obstacles: There has been little missionary work among the Muong, though they are a large people group. They practice their traditional ethnic religion which connects them to their ancestors. This is part of their identity as a people.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are strong believers in Vietnam who can take Christ to this people group. Some of them can help them with their physical needs, leading to an openness to hearing about the eternal blessings of Jesus Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray the few believers among the Muong would be united around the truth of Scripture and would lead holy lives, wanting to know and serve Jesus Christ. Pray for the gospel to spread from one family to the next, transforming them in beautiful ways.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the Muong community would increasingly hunger to know the creator God. Pray they would be able to live in peace and prosperity. Pray that the Muong would be able to embrace God's blessing through his Word for their families and communities.

LocationInCountry: Ninh Thuan, Dak Lak, Binh Thuan, Khanh Hoa, and Lam Dong provinces, in the mountains west and south of Nhatrang; some near Dalat.

LocationInCountry: North, mainly Cao Bang, Lang Son, Bac Kan, Tuyen Quang, Ha Giang, Lao Cai and Thai Nguyen provinces; possibly in Ho Chi Minh City and other sothern locations.

ProfileText.Summary: The Nung support themselves through agriculture, and are also known for their handicrafts. They have an abundant wealth of folk art and cultural activities including folksongs and alternative songs ("sli"). The smooth melodies of the "sli" are harmonious with the natural sounds of the forests and mountains. This type of folksong is a combination of verse and music. The Nung mainly worship their ancestors, spirits, saints, Confucius, and Kwan Yin.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: And to him was given dominion and glory and a kingdom, that all peoples, nations, and languages should serve him; his dominion is an everlasting dominion, which shall not pass away, and his kingdom one that shall not be destroyed.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Nung may well believe that to follow Christ will offend their ancestors.
ProfileText.HowReach: Christian workers can carry the Gospel message to the Nung by telling them stories from Scripture, as well as with films and Gospel recordings. Bridges of friendship are needed.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the followers of Christ among the Nung, that they will be sent teachers to help them, and mature believers to model Christ-like behavior.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray that many of the Nung people will come to love God with their whole being and will walk in His ways. Pray they will be able to live peaceful lives and be able to care well for their families.

ProfileText.Summary: The Nung support themselves through agriculture and are also known for their handicrafts. They have an abundant wealth of folk art and cultural activities, including folk songs and alternative songs which are known as sli. The smooth melodies of the sli are harmonious with the natural sounds of the forests and mountains. This type of folk song is a combination of verse and music. The Nung mainly worship their ancestors, spirits, saints, Confucius and Kwan Yin (a Buddhist goddess).
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Remember therefore from where you have fallen; repent, and do the works you did at first. If not, I will come to you and remove your lampstand from its place, unless you repent.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Many Nung may be hesitant to follow different beliefs, especially because of the feeling that it will disconnect them from their cultural roots. However, some have followed Christ in the past.
ProfileText.HowReach: Gods word could be shared with the Nung through stories from the Bible and by establishing personal connections with loving believers.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the followers of Christ among the Nung. Pray that they would become strong disciples, excelling in love and joy in the Holy Spirit. Pray for them to be a good example to non-believers.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray that many of the Nung people would come to love God and walk in his ways, leading to a movement to Christ. Pray they would be able to live peaceful lives and be able to care well for their families.

LocationInCountry: North central, Ha Tinh and Nghe An provinces; also in Laos.
Kon Tum, Quang Nam, and Quang Ngai provinces.
Hoa Binh and Son La provinces: Thanh Hoa province, south of Sam Nuea: Yen Bai province, in a small area.

ProfileText.Summary: Originally from China, the Tai Daeng (or Red Tai) followed the Red River to Vietnam in order to escape pressure from the Chinese. The Tai Daeng are closely related to the White Tai and the Black Tai. Together, they are part of a larger people group cluster that includes the Laotians and the Shan. The Tai Daeng live together as families and organize their communities by rank: merchants outrank craftsmen, who outrank farmers. The largest group are rice farmers, and priests are in a class of their own.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: Send out your light and your truth; let them lead me; let them bring me to your holy hill and to your dwelling!
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Tai Daeng believe in animism mixed with Buddhist teachings. The people revere "guardian spirits" and "locality spirits" but must be careful not to anger them unwittingly. The people must appease the spirits in order to stave off ill-fortune. There are very few Christian resources available in the Tai Daeng language.
ProfileText.HowReach: There is a need for more laborers to go to northern Vietnam and minister healing to these people whose heritage has been marked by war and foreign domination.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
May God show the Tai Daeng that he is the same yesterday, today and tomorrow. He is not fickle, and we do not have to appease him but instead we need to be devoted to him.
Pray that missionaries of Asian descent would bring God's international message of peace to the Tai Daeng, resulting in a Disciple Making Movement.

LocationInCountry: North, along Red and Black rivers, Son La, Dien Bien, Yen Bai, Lai Chau, Lao Cai, and Phu Tho provinces; south, Lam Dong province, Tung Nghia; Dac Lak province, Tho Thanh; Gia Lai province, Pleiku; elsewhere.

ProfileText.Summary: The Tai groups of Vietnam are only distantly related to the Tai people of Thailand. The Black Tai, primarily of Thailand, also live in northern Vietnam. They originated in southern China, but gradually migrated to southeast Asia. They are one of the few Tai groups never to have embraced Buddhism, but are animists. They believe that non-human objects have spirits, and that people have multiple souls.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: For he was teaching his disciples, saying to them, The Son of Man is going to be delivered into the hands of men, and they will kill him. And when he is killed, after three days he will rise.
ProfileText.Obstacles: The animistic worldview of these people presents an obstacle to understanding the God of Scripture and His only begotten Son, Jesus Christ.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray the few believers among the Tai Dam will grow in sharing and discussing God's Word with their families and communities.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: There are a few believers among the Black Tai. Pray they will live holy lifestyles, united around Truth. Jesus is the Way, the Truth, and the Life.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray for the Black Tai to have their eyes opened to the presence of their creator God, who loves them and sent his Son to die for them.

ProfileText.Summary: The majority of the Tai Dam (or Black Tai) live in northern Vietnam around the city of Dien Bien Phu, but some live in Iowa in the USA. The Tai Dam take pride in being cloth weavers. They derive their name from the traditional black skirts and headdresses worn by the women. They embroider the black silk with flowers, and a bright green belt typically complements the outfit. In their everyday lives, the men and women divide labor equally; both men and women plow, hoe, fish, tend to babies, cook, and clean.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The princes of the peoples gather as the people of the God of Abraham. For the shields of the earth belong to God; he is highly exalted!
ProfileText.Obstacles: The Tai Dam practice Theravada Buddhism mixed with folk animism. Often seeking help through supernatural spirits and objects, they have ceremonies for recalling the soul. They practice ancestor worship and believe that there are spirits within every object and person. These spirits must be appeased so that they might avoid curses and receive blessings.
ProfileText.HowReach: These people are dominated by spirits who rule their lives, who could curse them on a whim, and who must be appeased. Gifted believers can go to their villages and drive out these spirits in the name of Jesus Christ.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
May the Tai Dam come to know the God who is simultaneously good, just, and merciful.
May they know of the Holy Spirit who can dwell in them and guide them. 
Pray for a movement to Christ among them to thrive this decade.

LocationInCountry: Son La province: near the Laos border area.

ProfileText.Summary: This Tai Nua group is mostly found in southern China, but also in northern Vietnam and Myanmar. After a Tai Nua wedding ceremony the bridegroom goes to live with his bride's family. Traditionally he must take with him gifts of tea, rice, meat, bananas, four eggs, and two salted fish for his new in-laws. Upon arrival, the village elder takes the packets of tea and rice out to the road and calls on the spirits of heaven and earth to witness the marriage. He then ties a white thread seven times around the wrist of the bride and once around the wrist of the groom to indicate their unbreakable commitment to each other.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But let justice roll down like waters, and righteousness like an ever-flowing stream.
ProfileText.Obstacles: There are almost no believers among the Tai Nua people in Vietnam, and the region where they live is mainly animistic.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are Bible portions in this language. Believers can distribute them in Tai Nua villages.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the few Tai Nua people who call Jesus "Lord" will let the light of the Holy Spirit shine before their neighbors, friends and family members. Pray that they will have the gift of healing, so they can demonstrate the goodness and power of the Lord.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for at least 12 pioneer workers to go to the Tai Nua people in Vietnam with the gospel.
Pray for openness to the gospel among Tai Nua elders and commoners.
Pray for the Lord to send dreams and visions of the Risen Christ to these people who have very little chance to hear His name.
Pray for a disciple making movement to transform Tai Nua communities.

ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The heavens declare the glory of God, and the sky above proclaims his handiwork.
ProfileText.Obstacles: There are almost no believers among the Tai Nua people in Vietnam, and the region where they live is mainly animistic.
ProfileText.HowReach: There are Bible portions in this language. Believers can distribute them in Tai Nua villages.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray that the few Tai Nua people who call Jesus "Lord" would let the light of the Holy Spirit shine before their neighbors, friends and family members. Pray that they would have the gift of healing, so they can demonstrate the power and goodness of the Lord.

LocationInCountry: Northeast of Ha Noi city, near China border, widespread; 15 provinces, possibly in Laos.

ProfileText.Summary: The Tay, or Tho, are a large people group of northern Vietnam. Their literacy rate in their mother tongue is given by the Ethnologue as being 1-5%. Their language is considered to be "threatened" in that many Tay are now speaking Vietnamese. They are mostly farmers. They have a rich tradition of folklore with all kinds of poems, songs, dances, and music. The Tay worship a multitude of gods, and ancestor worship is commonly practiced. Altars for the ancestors are placed in a central location in a house and treated as sacred space. Buddhism has also affected their religious understanding.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: But in your hearts honor Christ the Lord as holy, always being prepared to make a defense to anyone who asks you for a reason for the hope that is in you; yet do it with gentleness and respect,
ProfileText.Obstacles: The low literacy rate of the Tay largely limits Christian ministry to oral approaches.
ProfileText.HowReach: Please pray for more Christian laborers in Vietnam, both indigenous and expats.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Please pray for the workers laboring to minister to the Tay people. Pray for their encouragement, good health, and financial provision.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Please pray for complete deliverance from false gods for the Tay. Pray they will be set free from superstition and spiritual practices that are harmful. Spiritual matters are spiritually understood, and we should pray the Lord's Spirit will reveal Jesus to the Tay people.

ProfileText.Summary: Can you imagine living in a small fortified village surrounded by a moat to protect your people from invaders? This describes the Tay people, who have survived centuries of political persecution. The Tay live in 15 provinces throughout northern Vietnam, including Lao Cai. Though mainly small time farmers, some Tay people live in urban centers.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: The Mighty One, God the LORD, speaks and summons the earth from the rising of the sun to its setting.
ProfileText.Obstacles: There are geographic challenges to reaching the Tay people, with small villages scattered across Vietnam's northern provinces. Also, Tay people commonly engage in ancestor worship, as well as Buddhism. They worship many gods and believe that non-living objects have spirits. This mix of religious beliefs and practices makes the Tay resistant to Christ. Pray for truth and powerful encounters to deliver Tay people from spiritual darkness.
ProfileText.HowReach: As of 2017, the Tay have the New Testament in their language, along with audio Bible teaching and limited radio broadcasting.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray these resources penetrate Tay families throughout northern Vietnam.
Ask that the small number of Tay believers would be discipled to boldly share Christ among their people.
Pray for Vietnamese churches to intercede for the Tay and send effective witnesses to Tay villages and urban communities.
Pray for a gospel harvest of Tay people, leading to Disciple Making Movements that bless Vietnam's entire Tay people group.

LocationInCountry: Son La, Nghe An, Dien Bien, Lao Cai, Thanh Hoa, Lai Chau, and Hoa Binh provinces; scattered areas.

Resources.WebText: Topical Scripture booklets and Bible studies

LocationInCountry: North, mainly along Red and Black rivers, Lai Chau, Dien Bien, Lao Cai, and Son La provinces; some in the south, Lam Dng province, Tung Nghia.

ProfileText.Summary: One of the Tai Don (or White Tai) legends teaches that their ancestors emerged from a pumpkin in which they had taken shelter during a flood that had been divinely wrought to drown all mankind because of evil-doing. The Tai Don live in France, the United States, and mostly northern Vietnam, but they originally came from southern China. They engage in agriculture and fishing, and they are proud of their distinct ethnic and linguistic heritage.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: By day the LORD commands his steadfast love, and at night his song is with me, a prayer to the God of my life.
ProfileText.Obstacles: Weekly radio broadcasts bring the gospel to the Tai Don. Scripture portions are available in their language, but the people continue to practice animism. Though they believe in a supreme God, they show no interest in Christ at this time.
ProfileText.HowReach: Pray that their pumpkin legend can be used as a point of connection to Noah and the redemption that God offers to all of sinful humanity. Pray for gospel recording materials in their language to find their way into every Tai Don village.
ProfileText.PrayForPG:
Pray for gospel materials to direct the Tai Don people to the only Savior.
Pray for their elders and family heads to embrace the gospel and quicken the day when Jesus will be given the honor he is due in every Tai Don village.
Pray for an abundant harvest this season that will give the Tai Don cause to praise the Lord of lords.

LocationInCountry: Chiang Rai, Nan, and Phayao provinces. Scattered throughout Thailand.
Dak Lak, Dak Nong, Gia Lai, Phu Yen and Khanh Hoa provinces, Banmethuot area.
North Nghe An province, highland areas, Cuoi Cham dialect in Tan Ky district, Tan Hop commune; also in Thanh Hoa province.
Lang Son province.

ProfileText.Summary: The Zhuang are the largest minority group in China, linguistically separated into 16 Zhuang language groups. Those speaking the Zuojiang Zhuang language are mostly located in SE China, but a sizable group resides in extreme NE Vietnam. They are typically engaged in agriculture, and are known as "people of the soil". A newly married woman stays with her parents until after the birth of the first child. Only then does she go to live with her husband in his village. The Zhuang are careful not to offend the spirit world that surrounds them. They believe in the spirits of the water, forest, mountain, village, etc.
ProfileText.ScriptureFocus: They read from the book, from the Law of God, clearly, and they gave the sense, so that the people understood the reading.
ProfileText.Obstacles: No scripture has been reported to have been translated into the Zuojiang Zhuang language. In fact, only one of the 16 Zhuang languages is reported to have scripture portions available.
ProfileText.HowReach: Perhaps the Lord will lead some of the millions of Han Chinese believers to take the Gospel of Christ to the Zhuang, not only in China but reaching into Vietnam as well.
ProfileText.PrayForChurch: Pray for the few followers of Jesus among the Zhuang people, that they will grow in the nurture and admonition of the Lord. Pray they will become strong in numbers and in Christian maturity, sufficient to make a real impact among their own people.
ProfileText.PrayForPG: Pray the supersitious Zhuang will be set free from the spirit world and will be given a heart to seek the living God.
